PREFACE
This code of the county of Lyon County, as supplemented, contains ordinances up
to and including ordinance 638, passed November 7, 2024. Ordinances of the
county adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this code to
the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult the
county office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of the
code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
American Legal Publishing
Cincinnati, Ohio

BILL NO._25-01_
ORDINANCE NO. __639_______
SUMMARY:  AN ORDINANCE AMENDING LYON COUNTY CODE TITLE 15, CHAPTER 348, SECTION
4, CREATING DESIGN STANDARDS RELATED TO THE ROOF FORM OF MULTI-FAMILY
RESIDENTIAL STRUCUTRES IN LYON COUNTY.
TITLE:  AN ORDINANCE AMENDING LYON COUNTY CODE TITLE 15, CHAPTER 348, SECTION
4, CREATING DESIGN STANDARDS RELATED TO THE ROOF FORM OF MULTI-FAMILY
RESIDENTIAL STRUCUTRES IN LYON COUNTY.
   THE BOARD OF COUNTY COMMISIONERS OF LYON COUNTY, NEVADA DOES HEREBY ORDAIN:
 
Section 1. The Lyon County Land Use and Development Code, Title 15, Chapter
348, section 4 is hereby amended as follows:
 
15.348.04: DESIGN STANDARDS:
All of the following design standards shall be met by all multi- family
residential developments:
   A.   Building Orientation: Multi-family residential developments, when
abutting a private street, local, collector, or arterial street that has
existing or planned on-street parking, shall have the building oriented to the
street along a minimum of fifty percent (50%) of the site's frontage (see
figure 15.348-2 of this subsection).
FIGURE 15.348-2
BUILDING ORIENTATION AND STORAGE
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/dd62f16ea91c6fb0d01da5553d0f3c050135725a/
IMAGES/0-0-0-2820_8447x5982.jpg]
 
The "orientation" standard is met when all of the following criteria are met:
      1.   Primary building entrances shall face the street;
      2.   The front of the buildings shall be within twenty five feet (25') of
the front lot/parcel line,
Exception: Open, courtyard space in excess of twenty five feet (25') may be
placed in front of building entrances. Open courtyard space is defined as
usable, hard-surfaced space with pedestrian amenities including benches,
seating walls or similar furnishings.
      3.   Off-street parking or vehicular circulation shall not be placed
between buildings and streets used to comply with this standard;
   B.   Building Form: New multi-family construction shall comply with the
following building form standards (see figure 15.348-3 of this subsection).
FIGURE 15.348-3
BUILDING FORM
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/dd62f16ea91c6fb0d01da5553d0f3c050135725a/
IMAGES/0-0-0-2842_8397x5467.jpg]
 
      1.   Structures shall not have continuous horizontal distance exceeding
one hundred feet (100') (measured from end wall to end wall).
      2.   A minimum of fifteen percent (15%) of the front facade (area
measurement) shall contain windows or doors. All windows and doors shall be
trimmed or be recessed (i.e., into the front facade) to provide shadowing.
      3.   Garages attached to living units and accessed from the street (front
setback) shall be recessed at least four feet (4') behind the front facade of a
dwelling structure; and
      4.   Exterior building elevations shall incorporate design features
including offsets, balconies, projections, window reveals, or similar elements
to preclude large expansions of uninterrupted building surfaces. Along the
vertical face of a structure, the features shall occur at a minimum of every
thirty feet (30'), and on each floor shall contain a minimum of two (2) of the
following features:
         a.   Recesses (e.g., deck, patio, courtyard, entrance, window reveals)
that have a minimum depth of three feet (3');
         b.   Extensions (e.g., floor area, deck, patio, entrance) that have a
minimum depth of two feet (2') and minimum length of four feet (4'); and/or
         c.   Offsets or breaks in roof elevation of two feet (2') or greater
in height. (Ord. 603, 11-1-2018)
C. Roof Form: New multi-family residential structure(s) shall comply with the
following building form standards
1. Roof Architecture
a. General Design Principles
1. No specific architectural style is required; however, within a development,
buildings shall incorporate complementary forms, materials, colors, and
rooflines that result in a cohesive and integrated design.
2. Roof massing shall avoid box-like or monotonous appearances. Articulation
shall be achieved through variations in roof planes, changes in materials, and
the integration of architectural elements.
3. Architectural detailing and materials shall be consistently applied on all
building elevations to retain a cohesive design.
2. Roof Form and Massing
a. Roof Design and Variation
1. Roof forms shall be used to break up long horizontal massing, reflect
internal building organization, and emphasize entries, corners, or unit
modules.
2. Roofs shall have variations in plane accomplished by changes in plane or by
the use of traditional roof forms such as dormers (pitched, shed-roof or
eyebrow), gables, hipped roofs and variations in pitch.
3. Flat roofs may be permitted if fully concealed behind architectural facade
roof elements that simulate sloped rooflines through construction of false or
partial roof forms integrated into the building’s exterior. These elements
shall be constructed along all exterior elevations of the building and shall
maintain a minimum height consistent with a 3:12 roof pitch measured from the
top of the primary roof surface to the peak of the facade roof. The facade roof
shall be continuous around the entire perimeter of the building to ensure a
consistent and integrated architectural appearance, which shall be compatible
with and complimentary to the architectural character of the surrounding
development.
b. Roof Function and Expression
1. Roof forms shall be aligned with and reinforce the layout of the building,
highlighting entrances, corners, and unit configurations.
2. Applied or purely decorative roof features that are not structurally or
visually integrated into the building are discouraged.
 
 
3. Rooftop Mechanical Equipment Screening
a. All rooftop mechanical equipment shall be fully screened from view from
public streets, adjacent residential uses, and publicly accessible locations
(e.g. sidewalks, parks, or other ground level areas open to the public).
Required screening shall be designed to ensure that rooftop mechanical
equipment is not visible when viewed from any adjacent public street, adjacent
residential use, or publicly accessible location located at or below the
elevation of the top of the highest occupied floor of the building.
b. Screening shall be accomplished through one or more of the following:
1. Locating equipment within recessed roof wells below the height of facade
roof elements;
2. Enclosing equipment within a rooftop structure designed and finished in a
manner architecturally consistent with the primary building; or
3. Using facade roof forms that are of sufficient height and design to fully
conceal equipment from all public views.
c.    Mechanical equipment shall not extend above the visible roofline or roof
screen.
4. Alternative Compliance
The Community Development Director may approve deviations from the standards
set forth in this section through the minor variance process if the applicant
demonstrates that the proposed design:
a. Meets or exceeds the overall intent of these design standards;
b. Provides an equal or greater level of architectural quality and visual
interest; and
c. Maintains compatibility with surrounding development patterns.
    
Section 2. If any section of this ordinance or portion thereof is for any
reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction,
such holding shall not invalidate the remaining parts of this ordinance
 
Section 3. All ordinances, parts of ordinances, chapters, sections,
subsections, clauses, phrases or sentences contained in the Lyon County Code in
conflict herewith are hereby repealed.
 
 Section 4. This ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its
passage, approval and publication as required by law.
 
 
Proposed on the 15th day of  May , 2025.
 
Proposed by Commissioner: Tammy Hendrix

BILL NO. 25-02
ORDINANCE NO.  640
SUMMARY: AN ORDINANCE AMENDING LYON COUNTY CODE TITLE 15,
CHAPTER 336, SECTIONS 6-9 and SECTION 12, AND CHAPTER 320, TABLE 320-1 AND 320-
4, AMENDING CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT STANDARDS FOR NEW COMMERCIAL WIND
GENERATION, GEOTHERMAL GENERATION, AND SOLAR GENERATION, AND ADDING CONDITIONAL
USE PERMIT STANDARDS FOR ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS, AMENDING
TABLE OF ALLOWED USES - RURAL RESIDENTIAL, COMMERCIAL MIXED USE, COMMERCIAL AND
AGRICULTURAL/RESOURCE ZONING DISTRICTS TO ADD ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS AS AN
ALLOWABLE USE, AND TABLE OF ALLOWED USES - EMPLOYMENT AND INDUSTRIAL ZONING
DISTRICTS TO ADD ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS AS AN ALLOWABLE USE IN LYON COUNTY.
TITLE: AN ORDINANCE AMENDING LYON COUNTY CODE TITLE 15,
CHAPTER 336, SECTIONS 6-9 and SECTION 12, AND CHAPTER 320, TABLE 320-1 AND 320-
4, AMENDING CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT STANDARDS FOR NEW COMMERCIAL WIND
GENERATION, GEOTHERMAL GENERATION, AND SOLAR GENERATION, AND ADDING CONDITIONAL
USE PERMIT STANDARDS FOR ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS, AMENDING
TABLE OF ALLOWED USES - RURAL RESIDENTIAL, COMMERCIAL MIXED USE, COMMERCIAL AND
AGRICULTURAL/RESOURCE ZONING DISTRICTS TO ADD ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS AS AN
ALLOWABLE USE, AND TABLE OF ALLOWED USES - EMPLOYMENT AND INDUSTRIAL ZONING
DISTRICTS TO ADD ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS AS AN ALLOWABLE USE IN LYON COUNTY.
THE BOARD OF COUNTY COMMISSIONERS OF LYON COUNTY, NEVADA DOES HEREBY ORDAIN:
23
24   Section 1. 
The Lyon County Land Use and Development Code, Title 15, Chapter 336, section 7 is
hereby
25   amended as follows:
26
27   CHAPTER 15.336.07: WIND ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEMS, COMMERCIAL:
28
29   15.336.07: WIND ENERGY CONVERSION SYSTEMS, COMMERCIAL:
30   A. Purpose:
 The purpose of this section is to regulate commercial wind energy conversion
systems
31   
(WECS) to protect the public health, safety and welfare while encouraging the development
of
32   wind energy within Lyon County.
 
1   B. Acknowledgment/Approval:
 Written acknowledgment and general approval from the property
2   owner as well as the public utility whose transmission lines to which the commercial WECS
is
3   proposed to connect into must be included in all commercial WECS
applications.
4   C. Siting Requirements:
5   1. Parcel Size: A minimum parcel size of ten 
(10) acres net is required. No part of the commercial
6   WECS shall be located within or over drainage, utility or other established
easements.
7   2. Setback: Each wind machine must be set back a minimum of two 
(2) times the total extended
8   height from any property line, railroad, aboveground utility lines or
public
9   roads. Setback increases to a minimum of one half mile 
(2,640 Feet) from a trail easement,
10   highway, and/
or adjacent properties with an existing residential use. Setback increases to
one
11   mile 
(5,280 Feet) from an airport, river, perennial or intermittent stream, and/
or lake. The
12   Board of County Commissioners may, at their sole discretion, approve setbacks that are
less
13   than the setbacks outlined in this chapter if the project is a part of a Planned
Unit
14   Development (PUD).
15   3. Comstock Historic District:
 In addition to all other requirements, all proposed commercial
16   WECS located within the Comstock Historic District, as established by the Comstock
Historical
17   Commission pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes chapter 384, shall receive a
review,
18   approval and a certificate of appropriateness from the Comstock Historic District
Commission
19   prior to submitting an application for a Conditional   use permit.
20   4. Height: Unless otherwise approved, 
the total extended height of the wind machine shall not
21   exceed two hundred feet (200'). The system must be in compliance with FAA
regulations
22   regarding height and lighting. Projects located in an area with military airspace shall
comply
23   with military height and lighting regulations.
24   5. Minimum Standards:
 Remaining standards regarding such things as access, noise, design and
25   installation, etc., shall meet or exceed those of private wind energy systems
(see
26   subsection 15.335.03FFF of this title). However, conditions placed on the
Conditional
27   Use Permit may be more restrictive than the minimum standards provided in this
chapter.
28   6. Building Permit:
 A permit from the County Building Department is required to install an
29   alternative energy system in Lyon County. In evaluating whether to approve a building
permit,
30   the building official may request and consider:
31   a. Supporting technical data,
32   b. Test reports, and
33   c. Appropriate documentation from approved sources.
34   7. Road Impacts:
35   a. Developer shall be responsible for all roadway improvements necessary to support
all
36   construction and ongoing operations of the WECS, to the satisfaction of the Lyon
County
37   Road Director.
38   b. The project shall require two separate traffic studies:
 one traffic study for the construction
39   phase of the project and a second traffic study for the operations and maintenance phase
of
40   the project. Traffic Studies shall be provided at the time of application for the
Conditional
41    Use Permit or Planned Unit Development process.
42   c. WECS projects shall not block, re-
route, or restrict access to public roads, including but not
43   limited to RS 2477 roads, which provide access to public lands. The developer may
propose
44   an alternate route as a part of the Conditional Use Permit process or Planned
Unit
45   Development process which the Board may approve at their sole discretion.
Factors
46   considered when determining approval of an alternate route include but are not limited
to
47   changes in travel distance/time, terrain, maintenance, granting of right-
of-way, and impact
48   to surrounding properties.
 
1   8.  Drainage:
 All improvements, including necessary road improvements, shall comply with the
2   most recent version of the Lyon County Drainage Guidelines.
3   9.   Fire Protection:
 All WECS projects located outside of the boundaries of a Fire Protection
4   District must enter into an agreement with the nearest Fire Protection District to provide
fire
5   protection, inspection, and emergency medical services. If the Fire Protection District
chooses
6   not to provide fire protection, inspection, and/
or emergency medical services to the project,
7   the project proponent must provide a plan for how they will provide for those
services.
8   10.  Decommission and Reclamation Plan:
 Developer shall submit a reclamation plan to the
9   department as a part of a Conditional Use Permit application. The reclamation plan
shall
10   identify the life expectancy of the project and a decommissioning timeline with
milestones
11   and shall comply with all requirements in L.C.C. 15.336.12.
12   11. Reclamation:
 The project must be reclaimed in accordance with the reclamation plan once the
13   project has reached the end of its useful life. If the project owner takes steps to increase
the
14   useful life of the project, the project owner must notify the Department in writing and
submit
15   a new reclamation plan reflecting the increased project life.
16       12.    Variance:
 Deviations from the standards established by this chapter shall require a variance
in
17   accordance with chapter 203 of this title. 18
19   Section 2. 
The Lyon County Land Use and Development Code, Title 15, Chapter 336, section 8 is
hereby
20   amended as follows:
21
22   CHAPTER 15.336.08: GEOTHERMAL GENERATING SYSTEMS
23
24   15.336.08: GEOTHERMAL GENERATING SYSTEMS:
25   A. Purpose:
 The purpose of this section is to manage the exploration, development and use
of
26   geothermal resources in Lyon County.
27   B. Other Permits:
 All geothermal projects shall be required to obtain all necessary permits from
the
28   regulatory agencies with authority over such developments including, but not limited to the
State
29   Division of Minerals, the State Department of Environmental Protection, the State Division
of
30   Water Resources, the State Health Department, U.S. Forest Service, Nevada State Lands,
  and the
31   U.S. Bureau of Land Management prior to the issuance of any building/
grading permits for the
32   project.
33   C. Consultant Services:
 If required, outside consulting services for data and modeling reviews shall
be
34   the financial responsibility of the applicant. The applicant and County shall enter into an
agreement
35   regarding the fees and confidentiality prior to the chosen consultant's review of the data
and
36   modeling. The chosen consultant shall act as the County's designated
agent.
37   D. Geothermal Exploration Project:
 A geothermal exploration project is for the purpose of evaluating
38   the presence and characteristics of geothermal resources prior to starting a geothermal
field
39   development project.
40   1. Prior to commencing a geothermal exploration project, the developer shall provide
Lyon
41   County Community Development Department with a written notice of intent including
the
42   following:
43   a. A description of the project including a map of appropriate scale showing the location
of
44   the proposed wells and effluent disposal.
45   b. A description of the potential impacts to the local community, existing authorized
uses,
46   and natural environment, and proposed measures to mitigate impacts.
47   c. Statement in which the applicant agrees to provide the County access to the data used
to
48   develop the conceptual aquifer model.
 
1   2. The Community Development Department shall not take possession of the written notice
of
2   intent; rather the applicant shall make the information available for inspection by
County
3   officials or their designated agents provided the County officials and/
or designated agents
4   agree not to disclose the information contained in the notice of intent or disseminate
the
5   information to the public.
6   3. Prior to commencing a geothermal exploration project, grading permits and a
reclamation
7   plan shall be submitted to Community Development for approval prior to
beginning
8   exploration activities. Any grading 
(including temporary access roads, drilling pads etc.) that
9   exceeds 50 cubic yards must have a mass grading plan approved.
10   E. Geothermal Well Field Gathering Systems
and Power Generation Facilities: In order to establish a
11   geothermal well field gathering system and/
or power generation facility, the following items shall
12   be submitted to the Community Development Department:
13   1. Monitoring Plan:
 A modeling plan shall be submitted in compliance with 40 CFR part 146
14   underground injection control program 
(unless waived by the County based upon the review
15   of the conceptual aquifer model). Prior to commencement of any operations of
the
16   geothermal well field and power generating facilities, baseline data representation
and
17   collection shall be established to the satisfaction of the County. Projection of
geothermal
18   fluids use and injection will be presented to the County as well as a conceptual model.
The
19   monitoring plan must be approved by the County and their designated agent prior to
the
20   operation of the facilities.
21   2. Numeric Aquifer Model:
 A numeric aquifer model shall be submitted based on the collection
22   of three 
(3) years of data following the commencement of operations. The numeric aquifer
23   model shall be designed to show hydrogeological and thermal data to enable modeling
of
24   impacts of pumping and injection to the aquifer and potential mitigation
actions. The model
25   shall include data on the following:
26   a. Thermal properties of the aquifer including local and large-
 scale impacts to local
27   aquifers;
28   b. Potential subsidence impacts based on analysis of existing and predicted
conditions
29   using the pumping and injection volumes proposed for the project;
30   c. Changes in the radioactive characteristics from pumping (if any); and
31   d. Groundwater aquifer physical and chemical changes before and after the
project
32    completion including pressure, temperature trends, volumes and water
chemistry.
33   e.
The County and their authorized representative will review and if necessary revise
the
49    numeric aquifer model.
35
36   3. Siting Of Geothermal Well Field Gathering Systems And Power Generation
Facilities:
37   Geothermal well field gathering systems and related power generation facilities shall be
sited
38   in areas with the appropriate zoning district as designated in the land use table contained
in
39   section 15.320.03  
of this title. If necessary, a zone change application as described in chapter
40   220 of this title must be requested and approved prior to any permits for the geothermal
well
41   field system being issued.
42   4. Proximity To Existing   Wells: Geothermal temperature gradient and
43   exploration/
development test wells shall be located a minimum of three thousand feet
44   (3,000') from any adjacent private domestic or agricultural well
(s) unless a lease agreement
45   exists between the domestic well owner and the geothermal developer, and 
46   a minimum of three thousand feet (3,000') from State-
permitted municipal and industrial or
47   quasi-
municipal and industrial purpose wells. A variance request as outlined in chapter 203
of
 
1   this title from this separation standards may be submitted if supported by the outcome of
the
2   conceptual aquifer models results.
3   5. Minimum Siting Requirements and Standards:
 A geothermal well field gathering system and all
4   related above-
ground structures related to power generation shall comply with the following
5   minimum standards:
6   a. Visual Appearance:
 Placement of facilities shall endeavor to minimize the visual impact of
7   the development from surrounding properties and public rights-of-way.
8   b. Height Limits:
 The maximum height of structures shall comply with the maximum building
9   height listed in the underlying zoning district as listed in chapter 330 of this
title.
10   c. Screening And Lighting: Screening and/
or buffering treatments may be required to
11   mitigate visual and noise impacts. Where possible, all equipment shall be of a color
that
12   blends into the natural surroundings. Lighting shall include light shields that minimize
light
13   pollution by eliminating glare into adjoining properties and minimizes light visible
from
14   public rights-of-way.
15   d. Noise:
 Geothermal well field gathering systems' wells and power generation equipment
16   shall not generate noise levels that exceed sixty five 
(65) dBA time weighted average as
17   measured at the property line located closest to the wells and/or power
generation
18   equipment or one-half (1/
2) mile from the facility, whichever is closer. Adjustments for
19   ambient noise will be acceptable and irregular short periods of exceeding the sixty
five
20   (65) dBA standard in association with operational anomalies or maintenance
is
21   permissible. Acoustical shielding may be required for well heads and power
generation
22   equipment in order to comply with this development standard.
23   e. Road Impacts:
24   1. Developer shall be responsible for all roadway improvements necessary to support
all
25   construction and ongoing operations of the Geothermal Generating System, to
the
26   satisfaction of the Lyon County Road Director.
27   2. The project shall require two separate traffic studies:
 one traffic study for the
28   construction phase of the project and a second traffic study for the operations
and
29   maintenance phase of the project. Traffic studies shall be provided at the time
of
30   application for the Conditional Use Permit or Planned Unit Development
process.
31   3. Geothermal Generation projects shall not block, re-
route, or restrict access to public
32   roads, including but not limited to RS 2477 roads, which provide access to
public
33   lands. The developer may propose an alternate route as a part of the Conditional
Use
34   Permit process or Planned Unit Development process which the Board may approve
at
35   their sole discretion. Factors considered when determining approval of an
alternate
36   route include but are not limited to changes in travel distance/time,
terrain,
37   maintenance, granting of right-of-way, and impact to surrounding
properties.
38   f. Drainage:
 All improvements, including necessary road improvements, shall comply with
39   the most recent version of the Lyon County Drainage Guidelines.
40   g. Fire Protection:
 All Geothermal projects located outside of the boundaries of a Fire
41   Protection District must enter into an agreement with the nearest Fire Protection
District
42   to provide fire protection, inspection, and emergency medical services. If the
Fire
43   Protection District chooses not to provide fire protection, inspection, and/
or emergency
44   medical services to the project, the project proponent must provide a plan for how
they
45   will provide for those services.
46   h. Decommission and Reclamation Plan:
 Developer shall submit a reclamation plan to the
47   department as a part of a Conditional Use Permit application. The reclamation plan
shall
 
1   identify the life expectancy of the project and a decommissioning timeline with
milestones
2   and shall comply with all requirements in L.C.C. 15.336.12.
3   i. Reclamation:
 The project must be reclaimed in accordance with the reclamation plan once
4   the project has reached the end of its useful life. If the project owner takes steps
to
5   increase the useful life of the project, the project owner must notify the Department
in
6   writing and submit a new reclamation plan reflecting the increased project
life.
7   F. Geothermal Direct Use Wells:
 Geothermal direct use wells for commercial or industrial space
8   heating, food dehydration, or other similar such uses shall be subject to the standards listed in
this
9   chapter and Nevada Revised Statutes 534A. 10
11   Section 3. 
The Lyon County Land Use and Development Code, Title 15, Chapter 336, section 9 is
hereby
12   amended as follows:
13
14   CHAPTER 15.336.09: SOLAR GENERATION, COMMERCIAL:
15
16   15.336.09: SOLAR GENERATION, COMMERCIAL:
17   A. Purpose:
 The intent of this section is to encourage the development of commercial solar
energy
18   conversion systems (SECS) while protecting the
public health, safety and general welfare. 19
20   B. Definitions: Solar Energy Conversion Systems  (SECS) -
 a facility for the generation of electricity
21   utilizing the energy in sunlight for the purpose of producing electricity to be used on site
and/or
22   sold and distributed through the established commercial power grid. Technologies
include
23   photovoltaics and concentrated solar power generators. SECS does not include facilities
that
24   are used to provide power to manufacturing and/
or data center uses, and are accessory to the
25   primary use of manufacturing or data center, if located on the same parcel or entitled
through
26   a common Conditional Use Permit or Planned Unit Development. 27
28   C. Shade Structures: Non-commercial building-
mounted solar systems, including solar energy
29   conversion systems 
(SECS) used as parking lot shade structures, shall not require a CUP
30   provided the structure is conforming, houses or is accessory to a permitted use, and meets
all
31   Building Code requirements.
32   D. Acknowledgment/Approval:
 Written acknowledgment and general approval from the public
33   utility must be included in all commercial SECS applications.
34   E. Siting Requirements:
35   1. Parcel Size: A minimum parcel size of ten 
(10) acres net is required. No part of the
36   commercial SECS shall be located within or over drainage, utility or other
established
37   easements.
38   2. Setback: Each commercial SECS array must be set a
39   minimum of one half mile (2,640 Feet) from a trail easement, highway and/
or adjacent
40   properties with an existing residential use. Setback increases to one mile 
(5,280 Feet) from
41   an airport, river, perennial or intermittent stream, and/
or lake. An SECS may be placed
42   closer than 2,640 Feet from a property with an existing residential use, trail easement,
or
43   highway if it is separated by a geologic feature or building of a height
sufficient
44   to completely obstruct views of the commercial SECS from a point sixteen 
(16) vertical feet
45   above the boundary of any Residential Zoning District.
The Board of County Commissioners 
46   may, at their sole
1   discretion, approve setbacks that are less than the setbacks outlined in this chapter if
the
2   project is a part of a Planned Unit Development (PUD).
3   3. Components:
 All components of the commercial SECS must be set back from the property
4   boundary a minimum of thirty feet (30').
5   4. Comstock Historic District:
 In addition to all other requirements, all proposed commercial
6   SECS located within the Comstock Historic District, as established by the
Comstock
7   Historical Commission pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes chapter 384, shall receive
a
8   review, approval and a certificate of appropriateness from the Comstock Historic
District
9   Commission prior to submitting an application for a conditional use permit.
10   5. Height:
 Unless otherwise approved the total extended height of a commercial SECS shall
11   not exceed twenty four feet 
(24'). The system must be in compliance with FAA regulations
12   regarding height and lighting.
13   6. Minimum Standards:
 Standards for access, noise, design and installation, etc., shall meet or
14   exceed the requirements of chapter 337, "Performance Requirements For Industrial
Uses",
15   of this title. However, conditions placed on the conditional use permit may be
more
16   restrictive than the minimum standards provided in this chapter.
17   7. Building Permit:
 A permit from the County Building Department is required to install a
18   commercial SEC system in Lyon County. In evaluating whether to approve a
building
19   permit, the building official may request and consider:
20   a. Supporting technical data,
21   b. Test reports, and
22   c. Appropriate documentation from approved sources.
23   8.  Road Impacts:
24   a.  Developer shall be responsible for all roadway improvements necessary to support
all
25   construction and ongoing operations of the
SECS, to the satisfaction of the Lyon
26   County Road Director.
27   b.  The project shall require two separate traffic studies:
 one traffic study for the
28   construction phase of the project and a second traffic study for the operations
and
29   maintenance phase of the project. Traffic studies shall be provided at the time
of
30   application for the Conditional Use Permit or Planned Unit Development
process.
31   c.   SECS projects shall not block, re-
route, or restrict access to public roads, including but
32   not limited to RS 2477 roads, which provide access to public lands. The developer
may
33   propose an alternate route as a part of the Conditional Use Permit or Planned
Unit
34   Development process which the Board may approve at their sole discretion.
Factors
35   considered when determining approval of an alternate route include but are
not
36   limited to changes in travel distance/
time, terrain, maintenance, granting of right-of-
37   way, and impact to surrounding properties.
38   9.  Visual Appearance:
 Placement of facilities shall minimize the visual impact of the
39   development from surrounding properties and public rights-of-
way. SECSs shall be
40   constructed and/
or screened as to not unreasonably infringe upon the use and enjoyment
41   of the surrounding properties and rights-of-
way. There shall be no reflection or glare
42   permitted to impact any public rights-of-
way. Developers shall submit a visual impact study
43   to the Community Development Department at the time of the Conditional Use
Permit
44   application or Planned Unit Development process.
45   10. Drainage:
 All improvements, including necessary road improvements, shall comply with the
46   most recent version of the Lyon County Drainage Guidelines.
 
1   11. Fire Protection:
 All SECS projects located outside of the boundaries of a Fire Protection
2   District must enter into an agreement with the nearest Fire Protection District to
provide
3   fire protection, inspection, and emergency medical services. If the Fire Protection
District
4   chooses not to provide fire protection, inspection, and/
or emergency medical services to
5   the project, the project proponent must provide a plan for how they will provide for
those
6   services.
7   12. Decommission and Reclamation Plan:
 Developer shall submit a reclamation plan to the
8   department as a part of a Conditional Use Permit application or Planned Unit
Development
9   process. The reclamation plan shall identify the life expectancy of the project and
a
10   decommissioning timeline with milestones and shall comply with all requirements in
L.C.C.
11   15.336.12.
12   13. Reclamation:
 The project must be reclaimed in accordance with the reclamation plan once
13   the project has reached the end of its useful life. If the project owner takes steps
to
14   increase the useful life of the project, the project owner must notify the Department
in
15   writing and submit a new reclamation plan reflecting the increased project
life.
16   14.   Variance:
 Deviations from the standards established by this chapter shall require a
17   variance in accordance with chapter 203 of this title. 18
19   Section 4. 
The Lyon County Land Use and Development Code, Title 15, Chapter 336, is hereby
20   amended to add section 6: Commercial Energy Storage Systems, as follows:
21
22   CHAPTER 15.336.06 ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS:
23
24   15.336.06: ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS:
25   A. Purpose: The intent of this section is to regulate the development of
Energy Storage Systems (ESS)
26   to protect the public health, safety and general welfare.
27   B. Definitions:
28   Commercial Energy Storage System  (ESS) - a system that uses mechanical,
chemical,
29   hydrological or thermal processes to store energy that was generated at one time for use
at
30   a later time and is designed to have a storage capacity of over 10 megawatt hours for
the
31   entire facility. Commercial Energy Storage System does not include Energy Storage
Systems
32   that are used to provide back-up power to manufacturing and/
or data center uses, and are
33   accessory to the primary use of manufacturing or data center, if located on the same
parcel.
34   Lithium Ion Battery Energy Storage System (LiBESS) 
– is a commercial Energy Storage System
35   
(ESS) that uses Lithium ion Batteries as a component of the energy storage system.
Lithium
36   Ion Battery Energy Storage System does not include LiBESS that are used to provide back-
up
37   power to manufacturing and/
or data center uses, and are accessory to the primary use of
38   manufacturing or data center, if located on the same parcel.
39   C.   Conditional Use Permit:
 A conditional use permit shall be required for an ESS project that is
40   located in Lyon County in order to review, identify and develop mitigation measures that
reduce
41   the potential negative impacts to abutting properties.
42   D. Siting Requirements:
43   1.  Parcel Size: A minimum parcel size of ten 
(10) acres net is required. No part of the ESS or
44   LiBESS shall be located within or over drainage, utility or other established
easements.
45   2.  Setback: Each LiBESS must be set a minimum of one mile 
(5,280 Feet) from a trail easement,
46   highway, river, perennial or intermittent stream, lake and/
or property with an existing
47   residential use. The Board of County Commissioners may, at their sole discretion,
approve
 
1   setbacks that are less than the setbacks outlined in this chapter if the project is a part of
a
2   Planned Unit Development (PUD).
3   3.  Components:
 All components of the ESS must be set back from the property boundary a
4   minimum of thirty feet (30').
5   4.   Comstock Historic District:
 In addition to all other requirements, all proposed ESS located
6   within the Comstock Historic District, as established by the Comstock Historical
Commission
7   pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes chapter 384, shall receive a review, approval and
a
8   certificate of appropriateness from the Comstock Historic District Commission prior
to
9   submitting an application for a conditional use permit.
10   5.   Height:
 Unless otherwise approved the total extended height of a commercial ESS shall
not
11   exceed twenty four feet (24'). The system must be in compliance with FAA
regulations
12   regarding height and lighting.
13   6.  Minimum Standards:
 Standards for access, noise, design and installation, etc., shall meet or
14   exceed the requirements of chapter 337, "Performance Requirements for Industrial
Uses",
15   of this title. However, conditions placed on the conditional use permit may be
more
16   restrictive than the minimum standards provided in this chapter.
17   7.  Building Permit:
 A permit from the County Building Department is required to install an ESS
18   in Lyon County. In evaluating whether to approve a building permit, the building official
may
19   request and consider:
20      a. Supporting technical data,
21      b. Test reports, and
22      c. Appropriate documentation from approved sources.
23   8.  Road Impacts:
24   a.  Developer shall be responsible for all roadway improvements necessary to support
all
25   construction and ongoing operations of the ESS, to the satisfaction of the Lyon
County
26   Road Director.
27   b.  The project shall require two separate traffic studies:
 one traffic study for the
28   construction phase of the project and a second traffic study for the operations
and
29   maintenance phase of the project. Traffic studies shall be provided at the time
of
30   application for the Conditional Use Permit or Planned Unit Development
process.
31   c.   ESS projects shall not block, re-
route, or restrict access to public roads, including but not
32   limited to RS 2477 roads, which provide access to public lands. The developer
may
33   propose an alternate route as a part of the Conditional Use Permit process or
Planned
34   Unit Development process which the Board may approve at their sole discretion.
Factors
35   considered when determining approval of
an alternate route include but are not limited
36   to changes in travel distance/
time, terrain, maintenance, granting of right-of-way, and
37   impact to surrounding properties.
38   9.   Visual Appearance:
 Placement of facilities shall minimize the visual impact of the
39   development from surrounding properties and public rights-of-way.
40   10.  Drainage:
 All improvements, including necessary road improvements, shall comply with the
41   most recent version of the Lyon County Drainage Guidelines.
42   11.  Fire Protection: All ESS
projects located outside of the boundaries of a Fire Protection
43   District must enter into an agreement with the nearest Fire Protection District to
provide
44   fire protection, inspection, and emergency medical services. LiBESS projects must
receive
45   approval from the appropriate Fire Protection District prior to construction. LiBESS
projects
46   must provide the necessary equipment and training, as the Fire Protection District
may
47   require, to effectively fight a fire at the facility. If the Fire Protection District chooses not
to
 
1   provide fire protection, inspection, and/
or emergency medical services to the project, the
2   project proponent must provide a plan for how they will provide for those
services.
3   12. Decommission and Reclamation Plan:
 Developer shall submit a reclamation plan to the
4   department as a part of a Conditional Use Permit application. The reclamation plan
shall
5   identify the life expectancy of the project and a decommissioning timeline with
milestones
6   and shall comply with all requirements in L.C.C. 15.336.12.
7   13. Reclamation:
 The project must be reclaimed in accordance with the reclamation plan once
8   the project has reached the end of its useful life. If the project owner takes steps
to
9   increase the useful life of the project, the project owner must notify the Department
in
10   writing and submit a new reclamation plan reflecting the increased project
life.
11   14. Variance:
 Deviations from the standards established by this chapter shall require a
variance
12   in accordance with chapter 203 of this title. 13
14   Section 5. The Lyon County Land Use and Development Code, Title 15, Chapter 336, is hereby
amended
15   to add section 12:
 Decommissioning and Reclamation of Commercial Wind Conversion Systems,
16   Geothermal Generating Systems, Commercial Solar Generation, and Commercial Energy
Storage
17   Systems.
18
19   CHAPTER 15.336.12 DECOMMISSIONING AND RECLAMATION OF COMMERCIAL WIND
CONVERSION
20   SYSTEMS, GEOTHERMAL GENERATING SYSTEMS, COMMERCIAL SOLAR GENERATION, AND
21   COMMERCIAL ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS:
22
23   15.336.12: DECOMMISSIONING AND RECLAMATION OF COMMERCIAL WIND CONVERSION
SYSTEMS,
24   GEOTHERMAL GENERATING SYSTEMS, COMMERCIAL SOLAR GENERATION, AND COMMERCIAL
25   ENERGY STORAGE SYSTEMS:
26   A. Purpose:
 The intent of this section is to regulate and ensure the proper decommissioning
and
27   reclamation of commercial wind conversion systems, geothermal generating systems,
commercial
28   solar generation, and commercial energy storage systems to protect the public health, safety
and
29   general welfare.
30   B. DECOMMISSIONING AND RECLAMATION:
 The Conditional Use Permit for commercial wind
31   conversion systems, geothermal generating systems, commercial solar generation, and
commercial
32   energy storage systems shall include the submission of a Detailed Decommissioning Plan. Prior
to
33   the issuance of construction permits, the cost estimate for the complete removal of
non-
34   operational above and below ground improvements must be submitted and financial
assurance
35   must be posted.
36   a. Decommissioning Plan:
 The Decommissioning Plan will address the following items:
37   i.  All physical improvements, materials, and equipment related to solar
energy
38   generation, transmission, and storage must be removed from the surface and
39   the subsurface to a minimum depth of forty-eight (48”) inches. The pre-
existing
40   soil grade shall also be restored following disturbance caused in the
removal
41   process. These shall include, but are not limited to, structures,
buildings,
42   equipment, cabling and wiring, solar electric systems, electrical
components,
43   security barriers, foundations, pilings, berms, storm water improvements,
and
44   any other associated facilities.
45   ii.  All fencing shall be removed and recycled or reused unless the
Community
46   Development Director grants approval for any existing perimeter fencing to
47   remain in place, in which case, the Nevada Department of Wildlife will be
48   consulted to ensure that the remaining fence will not negatively impact
wildlife.
 
1   iii.  All access roads located within the Project Area shall be removed unless
the
2   road was in existence prior to the development or the Community Development
3   Director approves a written request from the current or purchasing
landowner
4   to allow a portion of the access roads and associated culverts or related
5   materials to remain.
6   iv.  For any part of the facility on leased property, the Decommissioning Plan
may
7   propose to incorporate agreements with landowners regarding the retainment
8   of driveways, roads, landscaping, berms, fences, gates or repurposed
buildings
9   or other structures with approval by the Board of County Commissioners.
10   However, any proposed use of remaining buildings or other structures must
be
11   in conformance with the regulations for the zoning district in effect at the
time
12   of Board of County Commissioners approval.
13   v.  Ground cover and screening established as part of the Facility Development
Plan
14   and other existing vegetation may remain as part of the Decommissioning
Plan.
15   Land disturbed as part of the decommissioning process must be reseeded and
16   re-vegetated with certified weed free native seed mixes or other plant
species
17   suitable to the area. A list of such appropriate plant materials shall be
provided
18   by the Community Development Director. Such planting and associated
grading
19   or other land disturbance must be completed within one (1) year of removal
of
20   Facility structures and equipment, in accordance with the Decommissioning
21   Plan approved and adopted by the Board of County Commissioners.
22   vi.  Disposal and recycling of all facility materials and equipment, including but
not
23   limited to, PV panels, inverters, and batteries must fully comply with all
24   applicable County, state and federal laws, regulations, and code
requirements,
25   which includes a County-approved demolition permit for work to be
performed
26   by a licensed contractor and an approved location for disposal of such
materials
27   and equipment.
28   vii.  Guaranteed Funds: Financial assurance for the estimated cost of
29   decommissioning and reclamation, which may include the possibility of
salvage
30   value if allowed by the Board of County Commissioners must be guaranteed
by
31   the owner or operator of the Facility prior to issuance of construction permits
to
32   ensure that decommissioning and reclamation can successfully occur. Should
33   another authority having jurisdiction (e.g., NDEP, Bureau of Land
Management,
34   etc.) also require financial assurance for decommissioning and reclamation,
the
35   Board of County Commissioners may consider accepting the same or portions
of
36   the same financial assurance to satisfy both requirements, so long as the
37   assurance meets the specifications of both Lyon County and the separate
38   authority. Upon issuance of the financial assurance, the applicant shall name
the
39   County as a party to the financial assurance. The applicant may choose one
of
40   the following options (either the full cost option or the tiered
securitization
41   option) to provide financial assurance.
42   viii.  Full Decommissioning Cost: The full cost of decommissioning and
reclamation
43   will be guaranteed by one or any combination of the following as
determined
44   acceptable by the Board of County Commissioners.
45   1.  Trust Fund: The owner or operator of the Facility shall establish a
trust
46   fund into which money specifically earmarked for decommissioning and
47   reclamation is deposited. The Facility Conditional Use Permits and the
48   terms of the trust fund shall prohibit the release of these funds without
 
1   the written consent of the County. The County shall consent to the
2   release of the funds upon compliance with the Decommissioning Plan
3   approved by the Board of County Commissioners.
4   2.  Payment Surety Bond: The owner or operator of the Facility shall obtain
5   a surety bond satisfactory to and approved by the County in an amount
6   equal to the estimated cost of decommissioning and reclamation. A
7   standby trust fund must be established into which the surety company
8   will make payments if the owner or operator fails to comply with their
9   financial responsibilities. This money deposited into the standby trust
10   fund shall be used to pay a third party to perform the work described in
11   the Decommissioning Plan approved by the Board of County
12   Commissioners.
13   3.  Letter of Credit: A letter of credit issued by a financial institution
that
14   has a credit rating of at least A- or higher by Standard and Poor's or A3
15   or higher by Moody's; and financial ratios and capitalization
16   requirements that are acceptable to the County, in the full amount of
17   the decommissioning and reclamation estimate.
18   4.  Tiered Securitization: An amount equal to, or more than, ten (10%)
19   percent of the approved decommissioning and reclamation cost
20   estimate shall be either: deposited into a cash escrow account at a
21   financial institution acceptable to the County; or an amount equal to, or
22   more than, ten (10%) percent of the decommissioning and reclamation
23   cost estimate in the form of a payment surety bond or a letter of credit
24   issued by a financial institution that has a credit rating of at least A-
25   from Standard & Poor's or A3 from Moody's and assets (50%) and
26   capital surplus (50%) totaling at least $10,000,000,000, or an A.M. Best
27   financial strength rating of at least A- (Excellent) or other credit
rating
28   and capitalization reasonably acceptable to the County shall be
29   obtained. The amount deposited in the cash escrow account, or the
30   amount of the surety bond or letter of credit, shall increase by an
31   additional ten (10%) percent each year on the anniversary of the
32   commencement of operation of the Facility for nine (9) additional years
33   until 100% of the full cost estimate of decommissioning and reclamation
34   is achieved.
35   ix.  Cost Estimate Update: The estimated decommissioning and reclamation
costs
36   must be recalculated at an interval no sooner than every year but not later
than
37   every five years by an independent third-party Nevada licensed engineer,
38   following the requirements for the original decommissioning cost estimate,
and
39   using the most current industry standards. The cost of preparing this
update
40   must be paid by the owner or operator.
41   x.  If the recalculated estimated cost of decommissioning and reclamation
exceeds
42   the original estimated cost by two percent (2%) or greater, then the
Facility
43   owner or operator shall deposit additional funds into the trust fund or
cash
44   escrow account or make an update to the payment surety bond or letter of
45   credit to meet the new cost estimate.
46   xi.  If the recalculated estimated cost of decommissioning and reclamation is
less
47   than ninety-eight percent (98%) of the original estimated cost, then the
County
48   may consider approval of a written request by the owner or operator to
reduce
 
1   the required deposits or, payment surety bond, or letter of credit to the
2   recalculated estimate of decommissioning and reclamation cost.
3   xii.  Any increase or decrease in the decommissioning and reclamation
securitization
4   shall be funded by the applicant or refunded to the applicant 
(if permissible by
5   the form of security) within ninety (90) calendar days and shall be
similarly
6   readjusted for every subsequent five (5)-year decommissioning cost estimate
7   update.
8   B. Amendment to Decommissioning Plan:
 Any amendment must be approved by the Board of
9   County Commissioners prior to beginning decommissioning and reclamation.
Applications
10   for an amendment shall require a public hearing under the same procedures as
required
11   for the Facility Conditional Use Permit. Required timeframes for completion
of
12   decommissioning and reclamation shall not be extended due to the amendment
13   application process.
14   C. Partial Decommissioning:
 If decommissioning is triggered for a portion, but not the entire
15   Facility, then the owner or operator shall complete decommissioning and reclamation
in
16   accordance with the Decommissioning Plan for the applicable
portion of the Solar Facility.
17   The remaining portion of the Solar Facility shall continue to be subject to
the
18   Decommissioning Plan.
19   D. Date of Decommissioning:
 If the Solar Facility is to be decommissioned and reclaimed, the
20   Facility owner or operator must notify the Community Development Director in writing
of
21   the proposed date of discontinued operations and plans for removal.
22   E. Abandonment of Facility: Unless otherwise approved by the Community
Development
23   Director (e.g., to allow time to repair damage from severe weather or to
update
24   equipment), Facilities that have not been in active and continuous service for a period
of
25   twelve 
(12) months, as determined by the Community Development Director based upon
26   receipt of a valid Land Use complaint, an unsatisfactory report from a state of
federal
27   agency, unsatisfactory annual life and fire safety inspections and/
or unsatisfactory self-
28   inspection of battery units, or a failure to provide any of these reports, shall
be
29   decommissioned and reclaimed at the Facility owner or operator’s expense.
However,
30   following the first six 
(6) months of failure to maintain the site, the County will have the
31   option to hire appropriate professionals to perform needed maintenance using the
surety
32   funds required by the Conditional Use Permit.
33   F. The owner or operator or their successors, within six 
(6) months after the complete cessation
34   of use of the Facility and at their sole expense, shall initiate and provide
continuous
35   decommissioning of the Facility in accordance with the approved Decommissioning
Plan.
36   a. Following the completion of decommissioning of the entire
Facility and payment for any
37   such costs arising out of a default by the owner or operator or their successors,
any
38   remaining securitized funds held by the County shall be distributed to the
project
39   owner(s) in the same percentage of the securitized funds matched with the
percentage
40   of the project owner's acreage ownership of the Facility.
41   G. Default Decommissioning and Reclamation by the County:
 If the owner or operator, or their
42   successors, fail to decommission the Facility pursuant to the approved
Decommissioning
43   Plan, and the County has not approved a repowering of the Facility, the County shall
have
44   the right, but not the obligation, to commence decommissioning and reclamation
activities
45   and shall have access to the property, and shall have the right to draw on securitized
funds
46   up to the amount of the actual decommissioning costs, and the rights to the
generation
47   equipment and ESS equipment and materials remaining on the property. If applicable,
any
48   excess decommissioning and reclamation securitized funds shall be returned to the
current
 
1   owner(s) of the property after the County has completed the decommissioning
and
2   reclamation activities and paid all outstanding invoices, divided according to
the
3   percentage of the property owner's acreage ownership of the Solar Facility. Nothing
herein
4   shall limit other rights or remedies that may be available to the County to enforce
the
5   obligations of the owner or operator or their successors, including under the
County's
6   zoning powers.
7
8   Section 6. The Lyon County Land Use and Development Code, Title 15, Chapter 320, Table 15.320-

BILL NO. 25-03
ORDINANCE NO. 641
SUMMARY: An ordinance approving a development agreement concerning the
development of property in Silver Springs for data centers and related uses,
located within Assessor’s Parcel Numbers 015-111-01, 02, 04, 05, 06 and a
portion of 015-091-08.
TITLE: AN ORDINANCE APPROVING A DEVELOPMENT AGREEMENT BETWEEN TRACT CAPITAL
MANAGEMENT, LP CONCERNING THE DEVELOPMENT OF LAND IN SILVER SPRINGS FOR THE
SILVER SPRINGS TECHNOLOGY PARK (SSTP) SPECIFIC PLAN; A 460-ACRE DEVELOPMENT FOR
DATA CENTERS, HIGH VOLTAGE POWER LINES, ELECTRICAL POWER SUBSTATIONS, A WATER
TANK, AND OTHER ASSOCIATED UTILITY AND ACCESS IMPROVEMENTS IN SILVER SPRINGS,
LOCATED ON ASSESSOR PARCEL NUMBERS (APN) 015-111-01, 02, 04, 05, 06 AND A
PORTION OF 015-091-08, CONSISTING OF 460 ACRES OF SIX (6) SUBJECT PARCELS THAT
TOTAL APPROXIMATELY 1,070 ACRES; AND PROVIDING FOR OTHER MATTERS PROPERLY
RELATING THERETO.
THE BOARD OF COUNTY COMMISSIONERS OF LYON COUNTY, NEVADA DOES HEREBY ORDAIN:
WHEREAS, Lyon County desires to enter into a development agreement with TRACT
Capital Management, LP, for the Silver Springs Technology Park (SSTP) Specific
Plan for the 460-acre development for data centers, high voltage power lines,
electrical power substations, a water tank, and other associated utility and
access improvements in Silver Springs, located on Assessor Parcel Numbers (APN)
015-111-01, 02, 04, 05, 06 and a portion of 015-091-08, consisting of 460 acres
of six (6) subject parcels that total approximately 1,070 acres.
 
WHEREAS, the Lyon County Board of County Commissioners (“Board”) finds that the
contents of the development agreement conform to the Lyon County Development
Code Section 15.110 – Development Agreements and Nevada Revised Statutes
278.0201 and NRS 278.0203; and
 
WHEREAS, the Board finds that the provisions of the development agreement are
consistent with the Silver Springs Technology Park Specific Plan and the Lyon
County Master Plan.
 
SECTION 1: NOW, THEREFORE, the Board hereby approves by ordinance the
development agreement, attached and incorporated herein as Exhibit 1, between
Lyon County and TRACT Capital Management, LP, for the Silver Springs Technology
Park (SSTP) Specific Plan for the 460-acre development for data centers, high
voltage power lines, electrical power substations, a water tank, and other
associated utility and access improvements in Silver Springs, located on
Assessor Parcel Numbers (APN) 015-111-01, 02, 04, 05, 06 and a portion of 015-
091-08, consisting of 460 acres of six (6) subject parcels that total
approximately 1,070 acres.
 
SECTION 2: The Board further directs that the Clerk of the Board shall cause
the original agreement to be recorded with the county recorder within a
reasonable time after approval of the agreement.
  
SECTION 3. The county recorder shall be collecting the fee imposed by this
section.
 
SECTION 4.    If any section, paragraph, sentence or phrase of this ordinance
or portion thereof is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any
court of competent jurisdiction, such holding shall not invalidate the
remaining parts of this ordinance.
 
SECTION 5.   All ordinances, parts of ordinances, chapters, sections,
subsections, clauses, phrases or sentences contained in the Lyon County Code in
conflict herewith are hereby repealed.
 
SECTION 6.   This ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after
its passage, approval and publication as required by law.
 
PROPOSED THIS 1 st day of May, 2025.
 
PROPOSED BY Commissioner John Cassinelli.
PASSED on the 5th day of June, 2025.
AYES: John Cassinelli, Scott Keller, Tammy Hendrix, Robert Jacobson, Dave
Hockaday
NAYS: None
ABSENT: None
ABSTENTIONS: None
                  
 
 
BOARD OF LYON COUNTY
                  COMMISSIONERS
