CHAPTER 14
CENTRAL CASHIERING SYSTEM
SECTION:
1.14.01: Title
1.14.02: System Established
1.14.03: Purpose
1.14.04: General Policies
1.14.05: Bank Accounts; Establishment
1.14.06: Bank Accounts; Review
1.14.01: TITLE:
This Chapter shall be known as the Central Cashiering Chapter. (Ord. 370, 6-4-
92, eff. 6-19-92)
1.14.02: SYSTEM ESTABLISHED:
This Chapter is enacted pursuant to Nevada Revised Statute 244.207. (Ord. 370,
6-4-92, eff. 6-19-92)
1.14.03: PURPOSE:
The purposes of this Chapter are to:
   A.   Assure the separation of money-handling duties.
   B.   Assure the accountability for moneys received and disbursed.
   C.   Reduce the clerical effort needed to handle, process and account for
all moneys received. (Ord. 370, 6-4-92, eff. 6-19-92)
1.14.04: GENERAL POLICIES:
   A.   All moneys received by the offices of the County shall be deposited
into the banking system on the day of receipt. Exceptions to this practice
shall be limited to cases where the money received is nominal in amount, and
will be permitted only on written approval by the County Manager or his
designee.
   B.   To the extent possible all payments to County must be made to the
County Treasurer's office.
   C.   All moneys received shall be deposited intact; that is, moneys received
shall not be used to pay bills, cash personal checks, or be used in any other
type of transaction which will interfere with the concept that all moneys
received in a day will be deposited that day in the form in which they were
received.
   D.   Each department involved shall have fully documented procedure manuals
concerning all aspects of its handling of County funds. Such manuals shall be
maintained in an up-to-date manner and shall be readily available to all County
personnel. All County personnel involved in the handling of County moneys shall
be required to sign a statement to the effect that they have read and
understand the procedure manual.
   E.   Persons making payment shall be advised to make checks payable to the
office and not to the person currently holding the office.
   F.   Any bank account maintained by a department or office of the County
shall be formally reconciled each month, by the tenth day following the end of
such month. The reconciliation shall be:
      1.   In a form approved by the County Manager or his designee;
      2.   Dated and signed by the preparer and the department head; and
      3.   Kept as a permanent record.
   G.   The policies set forth in subsection A to F, inclusive, of this Section
shall be implemented on a gradual basis. Specific requirements implementing
these policies shall be proposed as part of the study of the cash procedures
followed by each department, and will be required only when incorporated in the
Central Receiving and Disbursing Ordinance by amendment. (Ord. 370, 6-4-92,
eff. 6-19-92)
1.14.05: BANK ACCOUNTS; ESTABLISHMENT:
New bank accounts shall be established only after the following actions have
been taken:
   A.   Transmittal of a letter from the requesting department to the County
Treasurer explaining the need for the bank account, with additional copies
being transmitted to the County Manager, the County Comptroller.
   B.   Receipt of responses from the County Manager and County Comptroller and
analysis by the County Treasurer.
   C.   Receipt by the Board of County Commissioners of specific
recommendations from the County Treasurer, after his evaluation of the initial
request and of the responses from the County Manager and the County Comptroller
and analysis, as well as his consideration of the purposes established for the
handling of moneys by Section
1.14.01 of this Chapter.
   D.   Affirmative action by the Board of County Commissioners. (Ord. 370, 6-
4-92, eff. 6-19-92)
1.14.06: BANK ACCOUNTS; REVIEW:
   A.   The County Treasurer shall maintain formal records on all County bank
accounts, including but not limited to reasons for establishment, authorized
signatures, and statistics covering the activity in the bank account and
estimated bank profitability.
   B.   At least once a year, the County Treasurer shall cause to be made a
formal review of cash-handling procedures in each office handling money. Such
review shall determine whether the policies and procedures set forth in the
Central Receiving and Disbursing Ordinance are being followed and whether bank
accounts should be added or closed. The County Treasurer shall recommend
procedural changes as needed, and shall provide the County Manager with a
formal report of each review. (Ord. 370, 6-4-92, eff. 6-19-92)
CHAPTER 15
PRISONER FEES
SECTION:
1.15.01: Intermittent Confinement
1.15.02: Fees
1.15.03: Conditions
1.15.01: INTERMITTENT CONFINEMENT:
Each person who is regularly employed and sentenced to serve a term of
confinement in the Lyon County jail may apply to the court to be allowed to
serve his term of confinement intermittently on days other than his regular
days of employment. (Ord. 373, 11-5-92, eff. 1-1-93)
1.15.02: FEES:
   A.   A person allowed to serve a term of confinement intermittently pursuant
to Section
1.15.01 above, must pay a fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) per day of
confinement.
   B.   The fee must be paid to the Lyon County Sheriff for deposit with the
County Treasurer in an account within the General Fund. The monies in the
account may only be used to defer the expenses of administering the Lyon County
jail. (Ord. 373, 11-5-92, eff. 1-1-93)
1.15.03: CONDITIONS:
If the court grants an application to serve a sentence intermittently it shall:
   A.   Establish the conditions of the intermittent sentence;
   B.   Direct whether the fee is to be paid weekly or monthly; and
   C.   If the person is unable to pay the amount of the fee, set the terms of
payment and set the amount of the fee, according to the applicant's ability to
pay. (Ord. 373, 11-5-92, eff. 1-1-93)
CHAPTER 16
COURT ADMINISTRATOR
SECTION:
1.16.01: Purpose
1.16.02: Court Administrator; Appointment
1.16.03: Court Administrator; Duties
1.16.01: PURPOSE:
Section 1 of article 3 of the Nevada constitution provides for a separation of
governmental powers, prohibiting the exercise of powers properly belonging to
the judicial department by any other governmental department. Pursuant to the
Nevada supreme court decision in State, ex. rel. Harvey v. The Second Judicial
District Court, a district court may exercise control over the court clerk's
office either directly, by assuming all or part of the court clerk's functions,
or indirectly, by supervising the county clerk in the performance of his or her
duties as the ex officio court clerk. The purposes of sections 1.16.01 through
1.16.03 of this chapter are to recognize that employees in the office of the
clerk of the district court are under complete jurisdiction and control of the
district judges (subject to the provisions of title 2 of this code and the
county personnel policies), and to provide a method, by the appointment and/or
designation of a court administrator, for the institution of administrative
methods and procedures for the improvement of the judicial system. (Ord. 559,
7-19-2012)1.16.02: COURT ADMINISTRATOR; APPOINTMENT:The district judges, for
the judicial district of the state of Nevada, in which Lyon County sits, shall,
by majority action, appoint and/or designate a court administrator. The
district judges have denominated the court administrator as clerk of the
district court. The court administrator shall be subject to the provisions of
title 2 of this code and the Lyon County personnel policies. (Ord. 559, 7-19-
2012)1.16.03: COURT ADMINISTRATOR; DUTIES:The administrator shall, under the
supervision and direction of the district judges:A. Supervise the deputy court
clerks that are hired to work in the district court;B. Complete all statutory
and legal duties required of the court clerk;C. Prepare and submit budgets to
the board of county commissioners necessary for the maintenance and operation
of the district court and make recommendations in respect thereto; andD. Attend
to such other matters as may be assigned by the district judges. (Ord. 559, 7-
19-2012)
CHAPTER 17
PUBLIC ADMINISTRATOR
SECTION:
1.17.01: Definitions
1.17.02: Authority Of The Board
1.17.03: Payment For Expenses
1.17.04: Public Administrator To Report To Board
1.17.05: Promulgation Of Regulations
1.17.06: Board To Review Reports
1.17.07: Investigation Of Complaints
1.17.08: Investigation Of Guardianships And Estates
1.17.09: Financial Reporting
1.17.10: Office Of Public Administrator Is Abolished
1.17.11: Duties Of Public Administrator May Be Accomplished By An Employee Or
Contractor
1.17.12: Qualifications For A Person To Be Employed Or Contracted As the Public
Administrator
1.17.01: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings ascribed to them by this section:
ADMINISTRATOR: A person duly qualified and legally appointed or otherwise
responsible for the management and settlement of the estate of an intestate, or
of a testator who has no executor, performed under the supervision of a court,
and usually involving:
   A.   Collection of the decedent's assets;
   B.   Payment of debts and claims against the estate;
   C.   Payment of estate taxes; and
   D.   Distribution of the remainder of the estate among those entitled
thereto.
BOARD: The Lyon County board of commissioners.
INTESTATE: Without making a will. A person is said to die intestate when he or
she dies without making a will, or dies without leaving anything to testify
what his or her wishes were with respect to the disposal of his or her property
after his or her death.
PUBLIC ADMINISTRATOR: The person appointed or contracted to carry out the
duties and responsibilities set forth in Chapter 253 of the Nevada Revised
Statutes.
WARD: A person who, for defect of age, understanding or self- control, is
considered incapable of administering his or her own affairs. (Ord. 586, 4-7-
2016; amd. Ord. 609, 10-17-2019)
1.17.02: AUTHORITY OF THE BOARD:
In all cases within Lyon County where an administrator of an estate is or may
be needed, the board is authorized to direct the public administrator or any
other suitable person to:
   A.   Investigate whether there is any qualified person who is willing and
able to serve as administrator of the estate of an intestate decedent, and to
determine whether there is a need for an administrator and whether the public
administrator or other suitable person designated by the board is eligible to
serve in that capacity.
   B.   Petition the court for letters of administration of the estate of a
person dying intestate if, after investigation, the public administrator or
other suitable person designated by the board finds that there is no other
qualified person having a prior right who is willing and able to serve, and the
estate exceeds one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) in gross value.
   C.   File an affidavit pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 253.0403 to
administer the estate if, after investigation, the public administrator or
other suitable person designated by the board finds that the gross value of the
decedent's property situated in this state does not exceed ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00).
   D.   Act, upon order of a court, as administrator of the estate of a person
dying intestate, regardless of the amount of assets in the estate of the
decedent, if no other qualified person is willing and able to serve. (Ord. 586,
4-7-2016; amd. Ord. 609, 10-17-2019)
1.17.03: PAYMENT FOR EXPENSES:
The public administrator, or other suitable person designated by the board, who
performs duties pursuant to section
1.17.02 of this chapter may file with the board a request for payment for
expenses incurred in the performance of such duties.
   A.   The amount to be paid as expenses must be determined by the board.
   B.   Payment must be made from the general fund of the county, if the board
approves the request and determines that there is sufficient money in the fund
to pay the public administrator or other suitable person designated by the
board to perform those duties.
   C.   The board need not authorize payment of any expense that can be paid
from the assets of a person or an estate subject to Nevada Revised Statutes
253.040 or section
1.17.02 of this chapter. (Ord. 586, 4-7-2016; amd. Ord. 609, 10-17-2019)
1.17.04: PUBLIC ADMINISTRATOR TO REPORT TO BOARD:
The public administrator shall file with the board, not less than quarterly, a
report of all activities conducted within the scope of his or her authority as
public administrator. The report shall include the following information:
   A.   A list of all estates being administered by the public administrator
including:
      1.   Name of the decedent;
      2.   Date of death;
      3.   Date file was opened;
      4.   Approximate gross value of the estate;
   B.   A list of all estates for which property was secured pursuant to Nevada
Revised Statutes 253.0405;
   C.   A list of estates under investigation by the board pursuant to Nevada
Revised Statutes 253.091(2);
   D.   All monies collected by the public administrator;
   E.   All monies expended by the public administrator. (Ord. 586, 4-7-2016;
amd. Ord. 609, 10-17-2019)
1.17.05: PROMULGATION OF REGULATIONS:
The board shall establish regulations for the form of reports made by the
public administrator, pursuant to section
1.17.04 of this chapter; and from time to time, will review and may amend those
regulations. (Ord. 586, 4-7-2016; amd. Ord. 609, 10-17-2019)
1.17.06: BOARD TO REVIEW REPORTS:
The board shall review the reports submitted to the board by the public
administrator; and it shall take any action concerning those reports deemed
necessary to assure compliance with the state statutes and this chapter. (Ord.
586, 4-7-2016; amd. Ord. 609, 10-17-2019)
1.17.07: INVESTIGATION OF COMPLAINTS:
The board shall investigate any complaint received by the board regarding the
activities of the public administrator; and it shall take any action it deems
necessary to resolve such complaints and to assure that problems found to exist
are remedied. (Ord. 586, 4-7-2016; amd. Ord. 609, 10-17-2019)
1.17.08: INVESTIGATION OF GUARDIANSHIPS AND ESTATES:
The board may at any time investigate any guardianship or estate for which the
public administrator is serving as guardian or administrator. (Ord. 586, 4-7-
2016; amd. Ord. 609, 10-17-2019)
1.17.09: FINANCIAL REPORTING:
The public administrator shall provide to the county comptroller financial
records annually for the period July 1 through June 30 on or before October 31
to the comptroller for examination. (Ord. 586, 4-7-2016; amd. Ord. 609, 10-17-
2019)
1.17.10: OFFICE OF PUBLIC ADMINISTRATOR IS ABOLISHED:
The board declares that the Office of Public Administrator is abolished in
accordance with Senate Bill 460, Section 3, approved and passed by the 2019
Nevada Legislature and approved by the Governor. (Ord. 609, 10-17-2019)
1.17.11: DUTIES OF PUBLIC ADMINISTRATOR MAY BE ACCOMPLISHED BY AN EMPLOYEE OR
CONTRACTOR:
The board shall employ or contract for the services of the Public Administrator
to perform the duties and responsibilities of the public administrator set
forth in Chapter 253 and other applicable provisions of the Nevada Revised
Statutes. (Ord. 609, 10-17-2019)
1.17.12: QUALIFICATIONS FOR A PERSON TO BE EMPLOYED OR CONTRACTED AS THE PUBLIC
ADMINISTRATOR:
A.   Be at least twenty one (21) years of age;
B.   Not have been convicted of a felony for which his or her civil rights have
not been restored by a court of competent jurisdiction; and
C.   Not have been found liable in a civil action involving a finding of fraud,
misrepresentation, material omission, misappropriation, theft or conversion.
(Ord. 609, 10-17-2019)
TITLE 2
PERSONNEL REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL PERSONNEL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
2.01.01: Merit Personnel System Established
2.01.02: Administration
2.01.03: Regulations, Policies And Procedures
2.01.04: Officer And Employee Travel Expenses
2.01.05: Conflict
2.01.01: MERIT PERSONNEL SYSTEM ESTABLISHED:
A merit personnel system for all employees of the county, except those exempted
by policy or regulation adopted by the Lyon County board of commissioners and
permitted by state and federal law to be exempt, is hereby established. (Ord.
450, 8-17-2000, eff. 9-4-2000; amd. Ord. 615, 6-3-2021)
2.01.02: ADMINISTRATION:
The Lyon County board of commissioners shall be responsible for the
establishment and administration of Lyon County personnel regulations, policies
and procedures. (Ord. 450, 8-17-2000, eff. 9-4-2000; amd. Ord. 615, 6-3-2021)
2.01.03: REGULATIONS, POLICIES AND PROCEDURES:
The board of commissioners shall adopt, by resolution, rules, regulations or
policies governing Lyon County personnel. The board of county commissioners may
amend or change, by resolution, the personnel regulations, policies and
procedures at any time. (Ord. 450, 8-17-2000, eff. 9-4-2000; amd. Ord. 615, 6-
3- 2021)
2.01.04: OFFICER AND EMPLOYEE TRAVEL EXPENSES:
   A.   Travel expenditures and reimbursement requested and received by county
officers and employees shall comply with the county travel policy or policies
adopted by the board under the authority of this Section and Nevada Revised
Statute 245.062.
   B.   The Board may adopt one or more separate policies for different
classifications of officers or employees, and may also include travel
expenditure and request in the administrative policies or personnel policies
adopted by the Board.
   C.   Each department of the county shall set forth in its annual budget the
maximum amount of money that it estimates will be necessary to pay for
necessary travel expenses for the fiscal year. (Ord. 615, 6-3-2021)
2.01.05: CONFLICT:
In the event of a conflict between the regulations, policies and procedures
adopted pursuant to this title and the provisions of a collective bargaining
agreement entered into pursuant to Nevada law, the terms of the agreement shall
prevail. (Ord. 450, 8-17-2000, eff. 9-4-2000; amd. Ord. 615, 6-3-2021)
CHAPTER 2
WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION
SECTION:
2.02.01: Purpose
2.02.02: Definitions
2.02.03: Reporting Improper Governmental Action; Prohibition On Reprisals And
Retaliatory Action
2.02.04: Obligations Of Lyon County Officers And Employees
2.02.05: Appealing Reprisals or Retaliatory Action And Other Violations Of This
Chapter
2.02.06: Appointment Of Hearing Officer
2.02.07: Appeal Proceedings
2.02.08: Disclosure Of Untruthful Information
2.02.09: Annual Summary
2.02.01: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to encourage disclosure, to the extent not
expressly prohibited by law, of improper governmental action and to protect the
rights of Lyon County officers and employees who make such disclosures in good
faith. This chapter is established pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 281.611
through 281.671, inclusive, with the intent to provide the same level of
whistleblower protections provided therein. (Ord. 546, 2-17-2011; amd. Ord.
612, 5-7-2020)
2.02.02: DEFINITIONS:
"Employee" means any person who performs public duties under the direction and
control of a Lyon County officer for compensation paid by Lyon County,
including Lyon County's judicial services personnel.
"Improper governmental action" is defined as action taken by an officer or
employee in the performance of official duties which is:
   A.   In violation of state law or regulation;
   B.   In violation of city code, ordinance, or regulation adopted by the
employer;
   C.   An abuse of authority;
   D.   Of substantial and specific danger to the public health or safety; or
   E.   A gross waste of public money.
“Officer” means a person elected or appointed to a position within Lyon County
that involves the exercise of a local governmental power, trust, or duty,
including:
   A.   Actions taken in an official capacity which involve a substantial and
material exercise of administrative discretion in the formulation of Lvon
County policy;
   B.   The expenditure of money of Lyon County; and
   C.   The enforcement of laws and regulations of Lyon County.
"Official authority or influence" includes taking, directing others to take,
recommending, processing, or approving any personnel action such as an
appointment, promotion, transfer, assignment, reassignment, reinstatement,
restoration, reemployment, evaluation, or other disciplinary action.
"Reprisal or retaliatory action" means adverse action taken, in whole or in
part, because of the disclosure of improper governmental action. It includes:
   A.   The denial of adequate personnel to perform duties;
   B.   Frequent replacement of members of the staff;
   C.   Frequent and undesirable changes in the location of an office;
   D.   The refusal to assign meaningful work;
   E.   The issuance of letters of reprimand or evaluations of poor
performance;
   F.   A demotion;
   G.   A reduction in pay;
   H.   The denial of a promotion;
   I.   A suspension;
   J.   A dismissal;
   K.   A transfer;
   L.   Frequent changes in the working hours or workdays;
   M.   If the employee is licensed or certified by an occupational licensing
board, the filing with that board, by or on behalf of Lyon County, of a
complaint concerning the employee; or
   N.   Knowingly placing false information, including without limitation, a
false complaint, in the personnel file of the employee. (Ord. 546, 2-17-2011;
amd. Ord. 612, 5-7-2020)
2.02.03: REPORTING IMPROPER GOVERNMENTAL ACTION; PROHIBITION ON REPRISALS AND
RETALIATORY ACTION:
Officers and employees may and are encouraged to report improper governmental
action to their supervisor, department head, or elected official. Officers and
employees may alternatively report improper governmental action to the Lyon
County Human Resources Director, County Manager, or the District Attorney. No
reprisal or retaliatory action shall be taken against an officer or employee
because the officer or employee made a report of improper governmental action.
(Ord. 546, 2-17-2011; amd. Ord. 612, 5-7-2020)
2.02.04: OBLIGATIONS OF LYON COUNTY OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES:
All Lyon County officers and employees:
   A.   Shall use their official authority or influence to remedy any reprisal
or retaliatory action of which they become aware.
   B.   Shall not:
      1.   Directly or indirectly use or attempt to use their official
authority or influence to intimidate, threaten, coerce, command, influence or
attempt to intimidate, threaten, coerce, command, or influence another officer
or employee in an effort to interfere with or prevent the disclosure of
information concerning improper governmental action, including, without
limitation, by intimidating, threatening, coercing, commanding, influencing, or
attempting to intimidate, threaten, coerce, command, or influence the other
officer or employee to take reprisal or retaliatory action: or
      2.   Fail to use their official authority or influence to remedy any
reprisal or retaliatory action of which they become aware. (Ord. 546, 2-17-
2011; amd. Ord. 612, 5-7-2020)
2.02.05: APPEALING REPRISALS OR RETALIATORY ACTION AND OTHER VIOLATIONS OF THIS
CHAPTER:
If an alleged violation of this Chapter occurs or if any alleged reprisal or
retaliatory action is taken against an officer or employee for the disclosure
of improper governmental action within two (2) years of such disclosure, the
aggrieved officer or employee (hereinafter "the appellant") may file an appeal.
The appellant must deliver this appeal in writing to the Lyon County Manager
within sixty (60) days of the alleged violation of this Chapter or the alleged
reprisal or retaliatory action. The appeal must state, with specificity:
   A.   All facts and circumstances pertaining to the improper governmental
action, including, without limitation, when, where, and how the improper
governmental action occurred, the individual(s) involved, and any laws,
regulations, codes, or ordinances alleged to have been violated.
   B.   All facts and circumstances pertaining to the disclosure of the
improper governmental action, including when, where, how, and to whom the
information was disclosed.
   C.   All facts and circumstances pertaining to the alleged violation of this
Chapter or alleged reprisal or retaliatory action, including, without
limitation, when, where, how, and by whom the alleged violation of this Chapter
or alleged reprisal or retaliatory action was committed.
Lyon County will provide on its website a form on which officers and employees
may submit an appeal containing the information set forth above. Copies of all
relevant documents, videos, or other physical evidence in the appellant's
custody or control shall be submitted with the appeal. In the event an appeal
submission is incomplete or otherwise deficient, the County Manager may, within
five (5) days, provide the appellant with written notice of any deficiencies
and afford the appellant no less than fourteen (14) days to correct them.
Failure to comply with any deadline in this Section may result in denial of the
appeal. (Ord. 546, 2-17-2011; amd. Ord. 612, 5-7-2020)
2.02.06: APPOINTMENT OF HEARING OFFICER:
Upon receipt of an appeal satisfying the requirements in the preceding section,
the County Manager shall appoint a hearing officer. The fees of the hearing
officer, if any, shall be borne by Lyon County. The hearing officer shall
adjudicate the matter consistent with this Chapter. In the event the hearing
officer determines that a violation of this Chapter or a reprisal or
retaliatory action occurred, the hearing officer shall be empowered to issue an
order directing: (1) the proper person to desist and refrain from engaging in
such a violation or action; (2) the termination of the employment of the proper
person; and/or (3) other relief as the hearing officer deems just and
appropriate. (Ord. 546, 2-17-2011; amd. Ord. 612, 5-7-2020)
2.02.07: APPEAL PROCEEDINGS:
The appointed hearing officer shall convene a hearing within sixty (60) days of
appointment, unless a later hearing date is agreed upon by the parties.
The parties may propound reasonable requests for discovery in advance of the
hearing. Discovery disputes shall be submitted to the hearing officer for
resolution. Failure to respond to a proper discovery request may, at the
discretion of the hearing officer, result in the exclusion of evidence or other
sanctions.
At the hearing, formal rules of evidence shall not apply. The hearing officer
may make evidentiary rulings as necessary to ensure the hearing is fair to both
parties. The parties shall have the opportunity to cross examine all witnesses
and provide rebuttal evidence. All testimony shall be under oath. In addition,
the hearing officer may adopt any additional procedural rules not inconsistent
with this section.
The burden of proof at the hearing shall be as follows:
   A.   It shall be the appellant's initial burden to establish: (1) the
appellant disclosed improper governmental action: (2) reprisal or retaliatory
action, or another violation of this Chapter, was taken against the appellant
in whole or in part because of the appellant's disclosure of improper
governmental action: (3) said reprisal or retaliatory action, or other
violation of this Chapter, was taken within two (2) years of the disclosure of
improper governmental action: and (4) the appellant was an officer or employee
of Lyon County at the time of the reprisal or retaliatory action or violation.
   B.   If the appellant meets this burden, the burden shall shift to the
employer to establish: (1) it did not engage in the alleged reprisal or
retaliatory action or other violation of this chapter; or (2) the alleged
reprisal or retaliatory action was taken for other legitimate, non-retaliatory
reasons.
   C.   If the employer meets this burden, the burden shall shift back to the
appellant to establish that the employer's reason is unworthy of credence and
is pretext for the reprisal or retaliatory again, or other violation of this
Chapter. (Ord. 546, 2-17-2011; amd. Ord. 612, 5-7-2020)
2.02.08: DISCLOSURE OF UNTRUTHFUL INFORMATION:
This chapter does not preclude an employer from initiating proper disciplinary
action against an individual who discloses untruthful information concerning
improper governmental action. (Ord. 546, 2-17-2011)
2.02.09: ANNUAL SUMMARY:
As required by Nevada Revised Statutes 281.661, a summary of this chapter will
be provided to employees upon hire and annually thereafter. (Ord. 546, 2-17-
2011; amd. Ord. 612, 5-7-2020)
TITLE 3
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
CHAPTER 1
CITIZENS' ADVISORY BOARDS
SECTION:
3.01.01: Purpose
3.01.02: Advisory Boards Established; Jurisdiction
3.01.03: Appointment; Organization
3.01.04: Service On And Removal From Citizens' Advisory Boards
3.01.05: Bylaws
3.01.06: Conduct Of Meeting Of Citizens' Advisory Boards
3.01.07: Budget And Compensation
3.01.08: Advisory Boards Dissolution
3.01.01: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to establish citizens' advisory boards covering
designated geographical areas of Lyon County and to set forth procedures by
which they function. Citizens' advisory boards are established to assist the
Board of County Commissioners with issues of concern in the designated
geographical areas. Citizens' advisory boards are a venue at which citizens
have an opportunity to interact with local County government and as such,
enable and enhance citizen participation at a local community level with
matters relating to specific community and County issues. Citizens' advisory
boards are advisory only and the creation of advisory boards does not diminish
or alter in any way the statutory and constitutional authority of the Board of
County Commissioners of Lyon County. (Ord. 599, 5-17-2018)
3.01.02: ADVISORY BOARDS ESTABLISHED; JURISDICTION:
The Board of County Commissioners may establish by resolution citizens'
advisory boards. The resolution by which a citizens' advisory board is created
shall specify the specific purposes for its creation, the number of members of
the board, the categories of membership on the board and the board's
geographical area of responsibility. (Ord. 599, 5-17-2018)
3.01.03: APPOINTMENT; ORGANIZATION:
   A.   Membership: In determining the number of members on a citizens'
advisory board and the categories of membership, the Board of County
Commissioners shall ensure that the advisory board consists of a representative
cross section of persons residing within the advisory board's geographical area
of responsibility.
   B.   Appointment: When applications are needed for an advisory board, the
Board of County Commissioners shall cause advertisements seeking applications
from interested citizens to be distributed throughout the represented
communities in the County. Such advertisements shall include, but are not
limited to, placement in a newspaper of general circulation in the County.
Applications received in response to the advertisements shall be kept on file
and remain valid for a period of one year from the date of receipt thereof.
The members of said boards shall be appointed by the County Commissioners.
   C.   Officers: Citizens' advisory boards shall select their own officers
from among their members. Each advisory board shall have at least a Chairman, a
Vice Chairman and a Secretary.
   D.   Term Of Office: Subject to the provisions of section
3.01.04 of this chapter, members of citizens' advisory boards serve two (2)
year terms commencing on January 1 and ending December 31. When a new citizens'
advisory board is created, one-half (1/2) of the members thereof shall be
appointed for an initial one year term and the remaining members shall be
appointed for an initial two (2) year term. A member may be reappointed by the
Board of County Commissioners at the end of his term in accordance with Board
of County Commissioner rules.
   E.   Vacancies: A vacancy occurring on a citizens' advisory board shall be
filled by the Board of County Commissioners for the remainder of the unexpired
term. Except as provided in subsection F of this section, if a member of an
advisory board misses three (3) consecutive meetings of the advisory board
without just cause as determined by the Chairman of the advisory board, a
vacancy in that member's position automatically occurs and the Board of County
Commissioners shall fill the vacancy as set forth in this subsection.
   F.   Elective Public Office: A member of a citizens' advisory board must
take a leave of absence from the citizens' advisory board during any period of
time in which he is a candidate or applicant for appointment to the Board of
County Commissioners. A leave of absence does not constitute absence without
cause as a member of the board and the Chairman of the advisory board may
request an alternate to serve in that member's place and stead until the member
is no longer a candidate. Election or appointment of a member to the Board of
County Commissioners will result in automatic termination of that person's
membership on the advisory board.
   G.   Appointments To Other County Boards Or Commissions: A citizens'
advisory board member may not concurrently serve as a member of the County
Planning Commission. Upon acceptance of an appointment to the Planning
Commission, the citizens' advisory board member must immediately resign from
the citizens' advisory board. (Ord. 599, 5-17-2018)
3.01.04: SERVICE ON AND REMOVAL FROM CITIZENS' ADVISORY BOARDS:
   A.   Although members are appointed to specific terms of office, citizens'
advisory board members serve at the discretion of the Board of County
Commissioners. Members of citizens' advisory boards may be removed at any time
during their term by a vote of the Board of County Commissioners.
   B.   Prior to a meeting of the Board of County Commissioners to consider
removal of a member of a citizens' advisory board, the Board or any
Commissioner may choose to address any issue giving rise to the removal at a
meeting of the affected citizens' advisory board. In addition, the Board or any
Commissioner may address the issue with the affected citizens' advisory board
member before the meeting of the Board of County Commissioners at which the
removal is to be considered.
   C.   Action regarding removal of a member shall be taken at a meeting of the
Board of County Commissioners where notice of possible action regarding the
member is noted on the agenda.
   D.   The member who may be removed at such meeting will be sent a letter
advising the member of the reasons for the proposed action. The letter will
also contain the date, time and location of the meeting. The letter will be
sent by certified mail approximately fourteen (14) days in advance of the
scheduled meeting.
   E.   At the meeting, the member may present information as to why he should
not be removed. If the member's character, alleged misconduct, professional
competence, or physical or mental health is to be discussed, the Board of
County Commissioners may close the meeting in accordance with Nevada Revised
Statutes 241.030. If a closed session is held, a copy of the minutes of the
closed session will be made available to the person who is the subject of that
meeting pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 241.035(2).
   F.   Prior to voting to remove a member, any persons who are in attendance
at the meeting who desire to be heard regarding the member's removal, will have
the opportunity to present their comments to the Board of County Commissioners.
   G.   At the meeting, and following a closed session if one is held, the
Board of County Commissioners may either remove the member from the citizens'
advisory board, take no action with respect to the member, or take any other
action the Board of County Commissioners deems proper under the circumstances
and which is permissible under the Nevada Open Meeting Law. (Ord. 599, 5-17-
2018)
3.01.05: BYLAWS:
   A.   The Board of County Commissioners shall adopt a standard set of bylaws
for citizens' advisory boards to govern the conduct of the affairs of such
boards.
   B.   Each citizens' advisory board shall adopt the standard set of bylaws.
   C.   If amendments or additions to the standard bylaws are adopted by a
citizens' advisory board, the bylaws become effective upon approval by the
Board of County Commissioners.
   D.   Bylaws of a citizens' advisory board may be amended at any time.
Amendments to the bylaws become effective upon approval of the Board of County
Commissioners. (Ord. 599, 5-17-2018)
3.01.06: CONDUCT OF MEETING OF CITIZENS' ADVISORY BOARDS:
   A.   Meetings of citizens' advisory boards shall be conducted in full
compliance with Nevada's Open Meeting Law and the bylaws adopted by the
citizens' advisory boards.
   B.   Citizens' advisory boards are required to keep written minutes of their
meetings in compliance with Nevada Revised Statutes 241.035. Citizens' advisory
boards shall file copies of their minutes with the Lyon County Manager's Office
within thirty (30) days after adjournment of the meeting at which the minutes
were taken. (Ord. 599, 5-17-2018)
3.01.07: BUDGET AND COMPENSATION:
The Board of County Commissioners may establish an annual budget to meet the
operating expenses of each citizens' advisory board. Members of citizens'
advisory boards shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for
their necessary expenses. (Ord. 599, 5-17-2018)
3.01.08: ADVISORY BOARDS DISSOLUTION:
The Board of County Commissioners, by resolution, may dissolve a citizens'
advisory board if the Board of County Commissioners determines that the board
is no longer needed to meet the purposes for which it was established. (Ord.
599, 5-17-2018)
CHAPTER 2
PLANNING COMMISSION
SECTION:
3.02.01: Commission Created
3.02.02: Membership; Appointment; Terms
3.02.03: Compensation And Expenses
3.02.01: COMMISSION CREATED:
There is hereby created and established a County Planning Commission, which
commission is authorized to act for and on behalf of the County and to fulfill
all the duties, perform all functions and exercise all powers of a County
Planning Commission, as the same are defined and set forth in Nevada Revised
Statutes sections 278.010 to 278.630, inclusive, and all acts amendatory
thereof, which body shall be known and designated as the Lyon County Planning
Commission. (Ord. 288, 1-24-1985)
3.02.02: MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT; TERMS:
The Lyon County Planning Commission shall be composed of seven (7) members who
shall be selected and determined as follows:
   A.   The Chairman of the Board of County Commissioners with the approval of
the Governing Body, shall appoint seven (7) members of the Planning Commission
who shall be residents of the County. The terms of each such appointed member
shall commence on the first Monday in January and shall be four (4) years or
until a successor is named; except, that the terms of two (2) of the members
first appointed shall be for four (4) years, the terms of two (2) members first
appointed shall be for three (3) years, and the terms of the three (3)
remaining members first appointed shall be two (2) years.
Members may be removed, after public hearing, by a majority vote of the Board
of County Commissioners for inefficiency, neglect of duty or malfeasance of
office. Vacancies occurring, other than through expiration of the term, shall
be filled by appointment for the unexpired term.
   B.   The appointed members of the Planning Commission shall hold no other
public office. (Ord. 606, 3-7-2019)
3.02.03: COMPENSATION AND EXPENSES:
The County may provide for compensation to the members of the County Planning
Commission up to the maximum amount allowed by Nevada Revised Statutes 278.040.
The County may also provide compensation for reasonable travel expenses and
subsistence allowances for the members in the same amounts as are allowed for
other officers and employees of the County. (Ord. 606, 3-7-2019)
CHAPTER 3
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT
SECTION:
3.03.01: Purpose
3.03.02: Definitions
3.03.03: Declaration Of An Emergency Or A Disaster
3.03.04: Use Of Emergency Powers And Continuity Of Government
3.03.05: Emergency Management Coordinator
3.03.06: Coordinator; Emergency Power
3.03.07: Advisory Council
3.03.08: Incorporation Of Certain Provisions Of Nevada Revised Statutes
3.03.09: Unlawful Acts; Penalties
3.03.10: Emergency Response Expenses Reimbursable
3.03.11: Adoption By Municipalities
3.03.12: National Incident Management System
3.03.01: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the safety and welfare of the
people and the protection of their property within this county in a disaster
situation through organized emergency operations; to provide for the
coordination of such operations with appropriate public authorities, private
persons, business associations and organizations; and to provide for the
delegation of the disaster assistance responsibilities of the board of county
commissioners to those county agencies having the resources for providing
disaster assistance. (Ord. 530, 10-16-2008)
3.03.02: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
BOARD: The Lyon County board of commissioners, and is to be the governing body
for all emergency management operations.
DISASTER: A flood, fire of extraordinary proportion, earthquake, storm,
epidemic, actual or threatened riot, serious domestic violence, insurrection,
general war or other major calamity which is so severe or widespread that it is
beyond the resources normally available to local government or private relief
agencies to alleviate the damage, loss, hardship or suffering caused by such a
calamity.
EMERGENCY: Any humanmade or natural event or circumstance causing or
threatening loss of life, injury to person or property, human suffering or
financial loss of such an extent that extraordinary measures must be taken to
protect the public health, safety and welfare.
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT: The preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency
functions, other than functions for which military forces are primarily
responsible, to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from
disasters caused by enemy attack, sabotage, or other hostile action, or by
fire, flood, earthquake or other natural causes. These functions include
firefighting, police services, medical and health services, searches, rescues,
engineering, air raid warning services, communications, radiological, chemical
and other special weapons of defense, evacuation of persons from stricken
areas, emergency welfare services (civilian war aid), emergency transportation,
existing or properly assigned functions of plant protection, temporary
restoration of public utility services, and other functions related to civilian
protection, together with all activities necessary or incidental to the
preparation for and carrying out of the foregoing functions.
EMERGENCY OPERATIONS: The planning, preparation for and carrying out of all
emergency functions necessary to prevent, minimize and recover from the effects
of a disaster.
EMERGENCY OPERATIONS PLAN OR THE PLAN: A plan adopted pursuant to this chapter
which contains the county's policies and procedures and provides guidance to
the chief executive, policymakers, county personnel and the community when
managing emergency operations, the planning process and programs.
EMERGENCY SERVICE WORKER: A.A county employee or official, whether full time,
part time or temporary, or
B.A person, registered with the county as an emergency worker, who performs
services during an emergency, a disaster or during emergency exercise or drills
subject to the order or control of, or pursuant to a request of a county
official.
LOCAL EMERGENCY PLANNING COMMITTEE OR LEPC: An organization consisting of
representatives from state and local government, fire, law enforcement,
emergency management, public health, environment, emergency medical,
transportation, media, community service organizations, manufacturers, retail
businesses, public utilities, and education, established to perform emergency
planning functions as required by federal, state, and local law.
NATIONAL INCIDENT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM: The national incident management system
(NIMS) is a comprehensive national approach to incident management, applicable
at all jurisdictional levels and across functional disciplines. NIMS provides a
consistent nationwide approach for federal, state, tribal entities, local
governments, and private and nongovernmental organizations to work effectively
and efficiently together to prepare for, respond to, and recover from domestic
incidents, regardless of cause, size, or complexity. (Ord. 530, 10-16-2008)
3.03.03: DECLARATION OF AN EMERGENCY OR A DISASTER:
The declaration of an emergency or a disaster must be made whenever it is
deemed necessary:
   A.   By the board, if a quorum is present;
   B.   By the county manager, if no quorum of the board is present in Lyon
County;
   C.   By the county manager's designee, if no quorum of the board is present
in Lyon County and the county manager is not present in Lyon County or is
unable to act.
A declaration of an emergency or a disaster may be suspended or revoked by the
person or body that declared it or by the board in any event. (Ord. 530, 10-16-
2008)
3.03.04: USE OF EMERGENCY POWERS AND CONTINUITY OF GOVERNMENT:
   A.   The county manager is empowered to execute the emergency operations
plan and resources management plan and control the overall accomplishment of
the purpose of this chapter at the direction of the board who performs
emergency duties necessary for the general health, welfare, and safety of Lyon
County. The emergency operations plan must designate who shall perform the
county manager's emergency management duties in the absence of the county
manager.
   B.   The county manager shall appoint an emergency management coordinator
(coordinator).
   C.   The county manager, or designee, may:
      1.   Direct other employees in order to implement the emergency
operations plan;
      2.   Obtain vital services, supplies and equipment needed to protect life
and property through requisition or contract with private parties or other
governmental entities and may bind the county for the value thereof without
being required to comply with the normal purchasing procedures if compliance
with those procedures would unreasonably hamper or impair the implementation of
the plan; or
      3.   Suspend the licensing requirement for persons whose services are
required for implementation of the emergency plans. (Ord. 530, 10-16-2008)
3.03.05: EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT COORDINATOR:
   A.   The emergency management coordinator shall:
      1.   Review and develop an emergency operations plan and maintain an
organization for emergency operations management utilizing for this purpose,
county, public and private resources;
      2.   Coordinate the implementation of the emergency operations plan and
establish an emergency operations center from which centralized direction and
control of the emergency operations organization may be exercised;
      3.   Exercise the emergency operations organization at drills and to
otherwise train and prepare the organization to effect the purpose of this
chapter;
      4.   Represent the emergency operations organization of this county in
all dealings with public or private agencies pertaining to emergency
operations; excepting, that the sheriff will provide such representation in all
matters dealing exclusively with law and order;
      5.   Plan, organize and conduct emergency and disaster training and
exercises;
      6.   Prepare an emergency operations plan for the county, in support of
and in consonance with federal and state emergency plans and guidance;
      7.   May employ technical, clerical, stenographic and other personnel as
may be required, and may make such expenditures therefor and for other expenses
of his/her office within the appropriation therefor, or from other funds made
available to him/her for the purpose of emergency operations as may be
necessary to carry out the purpose of this chapter;
      8.   Assist with negotiations and recommendations to the board for
adoption of such mutual aid agreements with adjoining cities, towns, and
counties as are determined essential to any part of emergency management and
emergency operations.
      9.   Other duties as the board or county manager may designate. (Ord.
530, 10-16-2008)
3.03.06: COORDINATOR; EMERGENCY POWER:
Upon declaration by the board or as otherwise provided in section
3.03.03 of this chapter of a disaster or emergency, the coordinator is further
empowered, under the direction of the board, to execute the emergency
operations plan, and coordinate the overall effort of the emergency operations
organization of this county for the accomplishment of the purpose of this
chapter; including the temporary procurement of equipment, services, shelter
and the procurement of supplies as provided under the emergency provisions of
Nevada Revised Statutes 332.055 and 338.011; excepting, that in a disaster
arising from civil disobedience, coordination of the emergency operations
organization will be exercised by the sheriff, assisted by the coordinator as
required. (Ord. 530, 10-16-2008)
3.03.07: ADVISORY COUNCIL:
The local emergency planning commission (LEPC) shall act as advisory council to
the emergency management coordinator.
   A.   The council must, as a specific function, provide technical and policy
guidance to the coordinator on emergency preparation, and public relations and
information. (Ord. 530, 10-16-2008)
3.03.08: INCORPORATION OF CERTAIN PROVISIONS OF NEVADA REVISED STATUTES:
All functions under this chapter and all other activities relating to emergency
management are hereby declared to be governmental functions. Pursuant to Nevada
Revised Statutes 414.110 (immunity and exemption), the county is not liable for
the death or injury to persons or for property damage as a result of any
emergency services worker complying with or reasonably attempting to comply
with this chapter, or any order or regulation promulgated pursuant to the
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 530, 10-16-2008)
3.03.09: UNLAWFUL ACTS; PENALTIES:
It is a misdemeanor for any person during a disaster or emergency to:
   A.   Wilfully obstruct, hinder or delay any member of the emergency
operations organization in the enforcement of any lawful rule or regulation
imposed upon him by virtue of this chapter;
   B.   Do any act forbidden by any lawful rule or regulation issued pursuant
to this chapter, if such act is of a nature as to imperil the lives or property
of inhabitants of this county, or to prevent, hinder or delay the protection
thereof, or to give or be likely to give assistance to the enemy.
   C.   Wear, carry or display, without authority, any means of identification
specified by the state office of emergency management or the county.
The penalty for violations of the provisions of this section shall be as
prescribed in section
1.04.01 of this code. (Ord. 530, 10-16-2008)
3.03.10: EMERGENCY RESPONSE EXPENSES REIMBURSABLE:
Those expenses of an emergency response necessary to protect the public from a
real or potential threat to health and safety incurred by a public agency
within Lyon County to confine, prevent, or mitigate the release, escape, or
burning of hazardous substances are a charge against any person whose
negligence causes the incident. Such expenses are a debt of the person liable
therefor, and shall be collectible in the same manner as in the case of an
obligation under contract, express or implied. The charge created against the
person by this section is also a charge against the person's employer if the
negligence causing the incident occurs in the course of the person's
employment. (Ord. 530, 10-16-2008)
3.03.11: ADOPTION BY MUNICIPALITIES:
The city of Fernley and the city of Yerington may adopt by reference the
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 530, 10-16-2008)
3.03.12: NATIONAL INCIDENT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM:
Lyon County hereby establishes the national incident management system (NIMS)
as the county standard for incident management. This system provides a
consistent approach for federal, state, and municipal governments to work
together more effectively and efficiently to prevent, prepare for, respond to
and recover from domestic incidents, regardless of cause, size or complexity.
NIMS will utilize standardized terminology, standardized organizational
structures, interoperable communications, consolidated action plans, unified
command structures, uniform personnel qualification standards, uniform
standards for planning, training, and exercising, comprehensive resource
management, and designated incident facilities during emergencies or disasters.
The NIMS incident command system (ICS) will be utilized by all Lyon County
emergency and disaster responders for incident management. (Ord. 530, 10-16-
2008)

3.05.01: BOARD ESTABLISHED; APPOINTMENT:

an advisory board to the Lyon County fair and recreation board, if such shall
be created, or to the board of Lyon County commissioners if a fair and
recreation board shall not be created. The Lyon County fair and rodeo board

1989)

The Lyon County fair and rodeo board:

authority to annually present the Lyon County fair and rodeo and to manage the

commissioners, so long as no transient lodging tax funds 1  are transmitted to
the Lyon County fair and rodeo board.
   B.   Shall continue to perform its traditional functions as authorized by
other Lyon County ordinances.
   C.   Is reauthorized expressly to continue to obtain funding for the Lyon
County fair and rodeo as it traditionally has done.
   D.   Shall advise the Lyon County fair and recreation board, if such shall
be created, or otherwise the board of Lyon County commissioners, as to how
transient lodging tax monies may be expended for the purposes herein provided.
(Ord. 335, 11-16-1989)

There is hereby established a Lyon County public land management advisory board
made up of seven (7) nonelected, Lyon County residents drawn from a diversity

   A.   The Lyon County planning commission shall act as the Lyon County public

public lands.
   E.   Will oversee creation of a final Lyon County plan for federally managed
public lands and present it to the county board of commissioners. (Ord. 545,
11-4-2010)
CHAPTER 7
HISTORICAL SITE ADVISORY BOARD
SECTION:
3.07.01: Title
3.07.02: Purpose
3.07.03: Lyon County Historical Site Advisory Board
3.07.04: Scope Of The Lyon County Historical Site Advisory Board
3.07.05: Issuance Of Certificate Of Appropriateness
3.07.06: Issuance Of Certificate Based Upon Economical Hardship
3.07.07: Appeal To The Board Of Commissioners
3.07.01: TITLE:
This Chapter shall be known as the LYON COUNTY HISTORICAL SITE ADVISORY BOARD
ORDINANCE. (Ord. 408, 12-1-1994, eff. 12-16-1994)
3.07.02: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this Chapter is to create a board to allow the residents of the
County to have a representative voice in the promotion of the education,
cultural, economic, general welfare and safety of the public through the
preservation and protection of structures, sites and areas of historic interest
within the County. (Ord. 408, 12-1-1994, eff. 12-16-1994)
3.07.03: LYON COUNTY HISTORICAL SITE ADVISORY BOARD:
The Lyon County Planning Commission shall serve as the Lyon County Historical
Site Advisory Board. (Ord. 408, 12-1-1994, eff. 12-16-1994)
3.07.04: SCOPE OF THE LYON COUNTY HISTORICAL SITE ADVISORY BOARD:
The sole scope of the Advisory Board is to ensure that any proposed
improvements to the exterior architectural features of a structure within the
Historical Zoning Overlay District are done in accordance with the style of the
original structure at the time the historical zoning overlay was put in place.
   A.   The following factors shall be considered in determining whether a
certificate of appropriateness should be issued for a proposed improvement to
the exterior architectural features:
      1.   Historic and architectural value and significance of the proposed
alteration; and
      2.   Position of the proposed new structures in relation to the street or
public way and whether it is subject to public view from a public place; and
      3.   The relationship of the proposed changes to the exterior
architectural features to well-recognized styles of early western architecture
of the late nineteenth and twentieth centuries.
   B.   A certificate of appropriateness may be refused for any structure,
erection, reconstruction, restoration, alteration, moving or razing of which,
in the opinion of the Advisory Board, would be detrimental to the interest of
the historic site.
   C.   "Exterior architectural features" means the architectural style,
general design and general arrangement of the exterior of a structure,
including the kind and texture of the building material, the type and style of
all windows, doors, light fixtures, signs, colors, and other apparent fixtures.
   D.   The Advisory Board shall neither consider nor have any authority over
alterations to the interior of any structure. (Ord. 408, 12-1-1994, eff. 12-16-
1994)
3.07.05: ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS:
   A.   If the Advisory Board determines that the proposed improvement or
alteration would not be detrimental to the interest of the historic site, then
a certificate of appropriateness must be issued.
   B.   If the Advisory Board determines that the proposed improvement or
alteration would be detrimental and a certificate of appropriateness is not to
be issued, then a report shall be issued to the Board stating the reasons for
denial.
   C.   A certificate of appropriateness is not required if:
      1.   The ordinary maintenance or repair of any exterior architectural
feature does not involve a change of design, material or the outward appearance
thereof; or
      2.   The construction, reconstruction, alteration, or demolition of any
such feature which the Community Development Department or similar authority
has certified is required to protect the public safety because of an unsafe or
dangerous condition; or
      3.   The construction, reconstruction, alteration, or demolition of any
such feature is to be completed under a permit issued by a building inspector
or similar authority prior to the effective date of the establishment of the
historical zoning overlay.
   D.   The Advisory Board may attach conditions to the certificate of
appropriateness that promote the purpose of this Chapter. (Ord. 408, 12-1-1994,
eff. 12-16-1994)
3.07.06: ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATE BASED UPON ECONOMICAL HARDSHIP:
The Advisory Board may issue a certificate of appropriateness despite a finding
that the improvements would be detrimental if the Advisory Board finds that
failure to issue the certificate would place a substantial financial hardship
upon the applicant because of conditions especially affecting the structure
involved. (Ord. 408, 12-1-1994, eff. 12-16-1994)
3.07.07: APPEAL TO THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS:
Any applicant may appeal any decision rendered by the Advisory Board to the
Board. Any appeal must be submitted in writing to the Board within thirty (30)
days after the determination of the Advisory Board or all rights to the appeal
are waived. (Ord. 408, 12-1-1994, eff. 12-16-1994)
CHAPTER 8
COMMUNICATIONS ADVISORY BOARD
SECTION:
3.08.01: Title
3.08.02: Definitions
3.08.03: Purpose
3.08.04: Obligations And Administration Of The Agreement
3.08.05: CAB Bylaws
3.08.06: Powers And Functions Of CAB
3.08.07: Limitations On CAB's Powers And Functions
3.08.08: Public Works And Road Department Communications
3.08.09: Compensation
3.08.01: TITLE:
This Chapter shall be known as the LYON COUNTY COMMUNICATIONS ADVISORY BOARD
ORDINANCE. (Ord. 417, 10-5-1995, eff. 10-20-1995)
3.08.02: DEFINITIONS:
CAB: Communications Advisory Board.
CDS: Communications Dispatch Center.
CLCFPD: Central Lyon County Fire Protection District.
CITY: The City of Yerington.
COUNTY: Lyon County.
MVFPD: Mason Valley Fire Protection District.
NLCFPD: North Lyon County Fire Protection District.
PARTICIPATING ENTITIES: Includes County, City, CLCFPD, NLCFPD, MVFPD and/or
SVFPD.
SVFPD: Smith Valley Fire Protection District. (Ord. 417, 10-5-1995, eff. 10-20-
1995)
3.08.03: PURPOSE:
The primary purpose and objective of this Advisory Board is to provide a more
efficient law enforcement, fire, emergency medical and emergency communications
dispatch system. This Advisory Board will provide a means for all County law
enforcement and fire districts to become involved in the design, operation,
development of policy and procedures and maintenance of the County's dispatch
system that each entity relies upon to perform its governmental duties. The
purpose is not to create a separate public agency. (Ord. 417, 10-5-1995, eff.
10-20-1995)
3.08.04: OBLIGATIONS AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE AGREEMENT:
   A.   Recommendations: City, CLCFPD, MVFPD, NLCFPD and SVFPD shall recommend
a member from within their respective districts to the County for appointment
to CAB.
   B.   Membership: CAB shall be comprised of the following seven (7) members:
      1.   One representative appointed by the County upon the recommendation
of the Lyon County Sheriff's office.
      2.   One representative appointed by the County upon the recommendation
of the Emergency Management Department.
      3.   One representative appointed by the County upon the recommendation
of the Yerington City Police Department and City.
      4.   One representative appointed by the County upon the recommendation
of the CLCFPD.
      5.   One representative appointed by the County upon the recommendation
of the MVFPD.
      6.   One representative appointed by the County upon the recommendation
of the NLCFPD.
      7.   One representative appointed by the County upon the recommendation
of the SVFPD. (Ord. 417, 10-5-1995, eff. 10-20-1995)
3.08.05: CAB BYLAWS:
CAB shall operate according to the following bylaws:
   A.   Four (4) members shall constitute a quorum.
   B.   The affirmative vote of a simple majority of Boardmembers as
constituted shall effect adoption of any motion, resolution, order or other
action by CAB. Written proxy votes will be accepted and included in all votes
if presented prior to the actual vote.
   C.   CAB members shall select a chairperson and vice chairperson from its
membership who shall each serve a one year term.
      1.   In the event a person selected cannot serve the full term, CAB
members may elect another member to either finish the unexpired term or to hold
the position for a full year.
      2.   No member shall serve in either position for more than two (2)
consecutive terms.
   D.   CAB members shall appoint a secretary who may or may not be a member of
CAB.
   E.   Meetings shall be held in accordance with Robert's Rules of Order to
the practical extent possible. CAB may adopt written rules that are not in
conflict with this Chapter. All such written rules shall be kept on file at a
place chosen by CAB.
   F.   All meetings shall be conducted in accordance with the Nevada Open
Meeting Laws. Regular meetings shall be conducted at a minimum of once every
three (3) months at a place chosen by CAB. The chairperson or vice chairperson
shall have the right to call for an unscheduled meeting. (Ord. 417, 10-5-1995,
eff. 10-20-1995)
3.08.06: POWERS AND FUNCTIONS OF CAB:
CAB is authorized to promulgate operational protocol that dispatch personnel
will follow concerning fire, emergency and emergency medical communications
processed through the CDS in the dispatch of personnel of the various
participating entities. CAB shall also perform, but is not limited to,
performing the following functions:
   A.   Budgets: The CDS Department supervisor shall create budget proposals
for CAB. CAB shall submit these budgets to the County for approval.
   B.   Equipment And Personnel Needs: CAB shall analyze the CDS and submit
reports to the County on the status of the CDS. The CDS supervisor shall submit
proposals for additional equipment or personnel to the County through CAB. The
CDS Department head shall create all bidding specifications with the advice and
consent of CAB upon receiving permission from the County to go out to bid. The
CDS Department head shall submit reports concerning the CDS to CAB on a
quarterly basis.
   C.   Grant And Assistance Programs: CAB shall have the authority to
coordinate applications for grants and assistance programs that would benefit
the CDS. (Ord. 417, 10-5-1995, eff. 10-20-1995)
3.08.07: LIMITATIONS ON CAB'S POWERS AND FUNCTIONS:
CAB shall not have any authority over the following:
   A.   Indebtedness: CAB cannot incur any debt on its own behalf or on behalf
of any of the participating entities. All contracts must be made in the name of
the County and can only be executed after approval of the Lyon County Board of
Commissioners.
   B.   Personnel: All personnel matters concerning County employees involved
in the CDS shall be handled by the County. CAB shall have the right, but not
the obligation, to submit recommendations to the CDS Department head, but all
final decisions shall be made at the sole discretion of the CDS Department head
and his/her County supervisor.
   C.   NCIC Criminal Justice Information Department Information: The Lyon
County Sheriff shall retain sole discretion over NCIC Criminal Justice
Department Information processed through the CDS. (Ord. 417, 10-5-1995, eff.
10-20-1995)
3.08.08: PUBLIC WORKS AND ROAD DEPARTMENT COMMUNICATIONS:
CAB shall consult with the Lyon County Public Works and Lyon County Road
Department whenever CAB actions would impact public works and road department
equipment. (Ord. 417, 10-5-1995, eff. 10-20-1995)
3.08.09: COMPENSATION:
All CAB members shall serve without compensation. (Ord. 417, 10-5-1995, eff.
10-20-1995)
CHAPTER 9
ANIMAL CONTROL ADVISORY BOARD
SECTION:
3.09.01: Advisory Board Established
3.09.02: Purpose
3.09.03: Powers And Duties
3.09.04: Compensation; Travel Expenses
3.09.05: Limitations
3.09.01: ADVISORY BOARD ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established a Lyon County animal control advisory board made up
of at least five (5) and not more than seven (7) nonelected Lyon County
residents drawn from a variety of backgrounds, and appointed by the county
board of commissioners. The county board of commissioners shall attempt to
select one resident from each of the Lyon County commissioner districts. Any
person appointed shall be a resident of Lyon County. (Ord. 446, 10-7-1999, eff.
10-22-1999)
3.09.02: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to create a board to allow the residents of the
county to have a representative voice in the promotion and discussion of animal
control issues. The animal control advisory board is advisory to the county
board of commissioners. (Ord. 440, 9-17-1998, eff. 10-2-1998)
3.09.03: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The animal control advisory board:
   A.   Shall advise and make recommendations to the county board of
commissioners and the director of animal services relating to the humane
treatment and control of animals.
   B.   Shall advise and make recommendations to the county board of
commissioners and the director of animal services regarding the implementation
of policies and ordinances relating to animal control.
   C.   Shall adopt bylaws for the governing body of the board and shall comply
with the Nevada open meeting law.
   D.   May establish temporary committees or standing subcommittees for
specific issues or problems. (Ord. 456, 2-15-2001, eff. 3-2-2001)
3.09.04: COMPENSATION; TRAVEL EXPENSES:
All members shall serve without compensation excepting reasonable travel
expenses and subsistence incurred in attending meetings. Reimbursement for
reasonable travel and other expenses shall be in accordance with Lyon County
policies and at the amounts set by the Lyon County board of commissioners.
(Ord. 440, 9-17-1998, eff. 10-2-1998)
3.09.05: LIMITATIONS:
The animal control advisory board may not enter into contracts on behalf of or
otherwise obligate Lyon County. (Ord. 440, 9-17-1998, eff. 10-2-1998)
CHAPTER 10
SURCHARGE FOR ENHANCEMENT OR IMPROVEMENT OF TELEPHONE SYSTEM USED FOR REPORTING
EMERGENCY
SECTION:
3.10.01: Authority And Purpose
3.10.02: Definitions
3.10.03: Establishment Of An Advisory Committee
3.10.04: Chairman, Election, And Duties
3.10.05: Rules And Regulations
3.10.06: Quorum
3.10.07: Meetings
3.10.08: Creation Of Special Revenue Fund; Use Of Money In Fund
3.10.09: Imposition Of Telephone Surcharge
3.10.10: Penalty For Failure To Remit Surcharges
3.10.01: AUTHORITY AND PURPOSE:
This chapter is enacted pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes 244A.7641 through
244A.7647 for the following purposes:
   A.   To establish an Advisory Committee to develop a five year Master Plan
for the enhancement or improvement of the telephone system for reporting
emergencies in Lyon County and to oversee any money allocated for that purpose.
   B.   To impose a surcharge for the enhancement or improvement of the
telephone system for reporting an emergency in Lyon County on:
      1.   Each access line or trunk line of each customer to the local
exchange of any telecommunications provider providing those lines in Lyon
County; and
      2.   The mobile telephone services provided to each customer of that
service whose place of primary use is in Lyon County. (Ord. 550, 5-19-2011)
3.10.02: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the words and terms defined in this section have the
meanings ascribed to them unless the context requires otherwise.
INCUMBENT LOCAL EXCHANGE CARRIER: Has the meaning ascribed to it in 47 USC 251
(h)(1), as that section existed on October 1, 1995, and includes a local
exchange carrier that is treated as an incumbent exchange carrier pursuant to
that section.
MOBILE TELEPHONE SERVICE: Cellular or other service to a telephone installed in
a vehicle or which is otherwise portable.
PLACE OF PRIMARY USE: Has the meaning ascribed to it in 4 USC 124(8), as that
existed on August 1, 2002.
PORTABLE EVENT RECORDING DEVICE: Has the meaning ascribed to in Nevada Revised
Statutes 289.830.
SUPPLIER: A person authorized by the Federal Communications Commission to
provide mobile telephone service.
TRUNK LINE: A line that provides a channel between a switchboard owned by a
customer of a telecommunications provider and the local exchange of the
telecommunications provider.
VEHICULAR RECORDING DEVICE: Means a device which is affixed to a marked vehicle
of a law enforcement agency, as defined in Nevada Revised Statutes 289.830, and
which records both audio and visual events. (Ord. 596, 12-21-2017, eff. 1-10-
2018)
3.10.03: ESTABLISHMENT OF AN ADVISORY COMMITTEE:
The Board of County Commissioners creates an Advisory Committee of a minimum of
five (5) members to develop a five year Master Plan to enhance or improve the
telephone system for reporting an emergency in Lyon County and to oversee any
money allocated for that purpose (the committee). The Master Plan must include
an estimate of the cost of the enhancement or improvement of the telephone
system and all proposed sources of money for funding the enhancement or
improvement.
   A.   Members will serve without compensation.
   B.   A minimum of five (5) members appointed to the committee must:
      1.   Be a resident of Lyon County;
      2.   Possess knowledge concerning telephone systems for reporting
emergencies; and
      3.   Not be an elected public officer.
   C.   As Lyon County has a population of less than one hundred thousand
(100,000), at least one member of the committee must be a representative of an
incumbent local exchange carrier which provides services to persons in Lyon
County.
   D.   Include the chief law enforcement officer or his or her designees from
each office of the County Sheriff, metropolitan Police Department, Police
Department of an incorporated city within the County and department, division
or Municipal Court of a city or town that employs Marshals within the County,
as applicable.
   E.   Members will be selected at large by the Board of County Commissioners
at its discretion.
   F.   The Board of County Commissioners must appoint for a term of two (2)
years, except for the initial term, and may reappoint any member to subsequent
terms of two (2) years. Any vacancy occurring during a member's term will be
filled by the Board of County Commissioners. A person appointed to fill a
vacancy occurring during a term must serve out the unexpired term of the member
replaced. Initially, the Board of County Commissioners must set the appointed
members' terms to provide for the terms of three (3) of the appointed members
to end on December 31, 2010, and for the terms of two (2) of the appointed
members to end on December 31, 2009. (Ord. 596, 12-21-2017, eff. 1-10-2018)
3.10.04: CHAIRMAN, ELECTION, AND DUTIES:
   A.   The committee must elect from its membership a Chairman and Vice
Chairman.
   B.   The Chairman will preside at meetings and be the signatory of any
correspondence necessitated by operation of the committee. (Ord. 550, 5-19-
2011)
3.10.05: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The committee may adopt rules and regulations regarding its meetings and
procedures. (Ord. 550, 5-19-2011)
3.10.06: QUORUM:
Three (3) members of the committee will constitute a quorum. The approval of a
majority of all members present to vote is necessary on any action the
committee desires to take. (Ord. 550, 5-19-2011)
3.10.07: MEETINGS:
The committee must hold a public meeting on a regular day not less than
quarterly unless a rule changing the meeting is adopted by the committee. At
least three (3) working days prior to any meeting, copies of the proposed
agenda must be available to the public in the County Clerk's Office and must,
additionally be mailed or electronically mailed to each member of the
committee. Notice of the meetings and the conduct of the meetings of the
committee, include taking of minutes and their transcript and retention, must
comply with the provisions of chapter 241 of Nevada Revised Statutes, Open
Meeting Law. (Ord. 550, 5-19-2011)
3.10.08: CREATION OF SPECIAL REVENUE FUND; USE OF MONEY IN FUND:
   A.   The Board of County Commissioners creates a Special Revenue Fund for
the deposit of any money collected pursuant to Nevada Revised Statutes
244A.7643. The money in the fund must be used only for the following purposes:
      1.   With respect to the telephone system for reporting an emergency:
         a.   Paying recurring and nonrecurring charges for telecommunication
services necessary for the operation of the enhanced telephone system.
         b.   Paying costs for personnel and training associated with the
routine maintenance and updating the database for the system.
         c.   Purchasing, leasing or renting equipment and software necessary
to operate the enhanced telephone system; and
         d.   Paying costs associated with any maintenance, upgrade and
replacement of equipment and software necessary for the operation of the
enhanced telephone system.
      2.   To improve the telephone system for reporting emergencies in the
County.
      3.   With respect to purchasing and maintaining portable event recording
devices and vehicular event recording devices, paying costs associated with the
acquisition, maintenance, storage of data, upgraded and replacement of
equipment and software necessary for the operation of portable event recording
devices and vehicular event recording devices or systems that consist of both
portable event recording devices and vehicular event recording devices.
   B.   If the balance of the fund created pursuant to subsection A1 of this
section which has not been committed for expenditure exceeds one million
dollars ($1,000,000.00) at the end of any fiscal year, the Board of County
Commissioners must reduce the amount of the surcharge imposed during the next
fiscal year by the amount necessary to ensure that the unencumbered balance in
the fund at the end of the next fiscal year does not exceed one million dollars
($1,000,000.00). (Ord. 596, 12-21-2017, eff. 1-10-2018)
3.10.09: IMPOSITION OF TELEPHONE SURCHARGE:
   A.   The Board of County Commissioners imposes a surcharge for the
enhancement of the telephone system for reporting an emergency in Lyon County
on:
      1.   Each access line or trunk line of each customer to the local
exchange of any telecommunications provider providing those lines in Lyon
County; and
      2.   The mobile telephone service provided to each customer of that
service whose place of primary use is in Lyon County.
   B.   The surcharge on access lines to the local exchange of
telecommunications provider will be one dollar ($1.00) per month per line.
   C.   The surcharge on trunk lines to the local exchange of a
telecommunications provider will be ten dollars ($10.00) per month per line.
   D.   The surcharge for each telephone number assigned to a customer by a
supplier of mobile telephone services will be one dollar ($1.00) per month per
line.
   E.   A telecommunications provider that provides access or trunk lines in
Lyon County and a supplier that provides mobile telephone service to customers
in Lyon County must collect the surcharge from its customers each month. Except
as otherwise provided in Nevada Revised Statutes 244A.7647, each
telecommunications provider and supplier must remit the surcharge it collects
to the Treasurer of the county in which the surcharge is imposed no later than
the fifteenth day of the month after the month it receives payment of the
surcharge from its customer. In accordance with Nevada Revised Statutes
244A.7647, a telecommunications provider or supplier which collects the
surcharge imposed pursuant to this section is entitled to retain an amount of
the surcharge collected which is equal to the cost to collect the surcharge.
   F.   Telecommunications providers and mobile telephone service suppliers
affected by this chapter must begin imposing the surcharge described in this
section within sixty (60) days after the Board of County Commissioners approves
the five year Master Plan for the enhancement or improvement of the telephone
system for reporting emergencies in the County commencing with a full monthly
billing cycle.
   G.   The County Manager may adopt procedures as necessary to effectuate the
provisions of this section. (Ord. 596, 12-21-2017, eff. 1-10-2018)
3.10.10: PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO REMIT SURCHARGES:
Any telecommunications provider or mobile telephone service supplier that fails
to remit surcharges due within ninety (90) days after the date on which the
telecommunications provider or supplier must otherwise remit the surcharges to
the County Treasurer will be subject to a penalty of five percent (5%) of the
cumulative amount of surcharges owed by the telecommunications provider or
supplier. (Ord. 550, 5-19-2011)
CHAPTER 11
COUNTY HEALTH BOARD AND COUNTY HEALTH OFFICER
SECTION:
3.11.01: Definitions
3.11.02: Composition Of The Board
3.11.03: Compensation
3.11.04: Duties
3.11.05: Powers
3.11.06: County Health Officer
3.11.07: Deputy County Health Officer; Appointment; Compensation; Duties
3.11.08: County Board Of Health; Supervision By Health Division
3.11.09: Meetings Of County Board Of Health
3.11.10: Severance Clause
3.11.01: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, unless stated otherwise herein, the following
definitions shall apply:
BOARD: The Lyon County health board.
BOARD MEMBER: A member of the Lyon County health board.
COUNTY COMMISSIONERS, COUNTY COMMISSION, OR COMMISSION: The board of county
commissioners for Lyon County, Nevada.
COUNTY HEALTH OFFICER: A person appointed by the board of county commissioners
as a county health officer on or before January 1 next following each general
election.
HEALTH DIVISION: The health division of the department of health and human
services for the state of Nevada.
