rule or regulation, the stricter shall prevail. (Ord. 329, 4-6-1989; amd. 1991
Code)
   B.   Existing Operations:
      1.   An infectious waste handler already operating a facility on the
effective date hereof shall be required to file an infectious waste management
plan within thirty (30) days.
      2.   All existing infectious wastes handlers shall be required to comply
with the terms of this chapter whenever any existing special use permit,
variance or other similar permit is renewed.
      3.   Existing infectious wastes handlers who presently are not required
to hold a special use permit or other such permit shall be required to comply
with the terms of this chapter within eight (8) years after its effective date.
(Ord. 329, 4-6-1989)
6.03.05: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section:
BUSINESS: An employer, self-employed individual, trust, firm, joint stock
company, corporation, partnership, association, city, district and the State of
Nevada or any department or agency thereof. For the purpose of this chapter a
business shall include both for profit and nonprofit business.
CONTROL: To mitigate, pretreat, remove or otherwise lessen the impact of an
emission, discharge or release of an infectious waste into the environment.
COUNTY: Lyon County, Nevada.
DISCHARGE: Includes, but is not limited to, any spilling, leaking, pumping,
pouring, emitting, emptying or dumping of an infectious waste into the
environment.
DISCLOSURE FORM: The written request for information prepared by the Lyon
County Department of Safety and Emergency Management and the Lyon County
Planning Department. The term includes the infectious waste permit application
form required by County.
EMIT: To discharge or release into the atmosphere, or through the atmosphere,
into the environment.
ENVIRONMENTAL AUDIT: The efforts undertaken to outline the handling of
infectious waste. An environmental audit is a precursor to and part of the
infectious wastes management plan required hereby.
FACILITY: Any building, structure, installation, equipment, pipe or pipeline or
any of the foregoing that are related by nature of contiguity, ownership, or
industrial process and used for the handling of infectious wastes.
HANDLE: To generate, treat, manufacture, produce, store, use, discharge,
release, transfer, dispose of, incinerate or emit in any fashion an infectious
waste.
HANDLER: An entity which generates, treats, manufactures, produces, stores,
uses, discharges, releases, transfers, transports, disposes of, incinerates or
emits in any fashion an infectious waste. An entity which otherwise would be a
"handler" who conducts any such activity pursuant to a pre-emptive State or
Federal law or regulation is not a "handler" for the purposes of this Chapter.
(Ord. 329, 4-6-89)
INFECTIOUS WASTE: Includes:
   A.   Equipment, instruments, utensils, blood and fomites of a disposable
nature from the patients or the rooms of patients suspected of having a
communicable disease;
   B.   Laboratory wastes such as pathological specimens (e.g. all tissues,
specimens of blood elements, excreta and secretions obtained from patients or
laboratory animals) and disposable fomites (any substance that may harbor or
transmit pathogenic organisms attendant thereto);
   C.   Surgical operating room pathologic specimens, blood and disposable
fomites attendant thereto and similar disposable materials from out-patient
areas and emergency rooms;
   D.   Dangerous drugs; and
   E.   Any other medical waste which may have been exposed to contagious or
infectious disease. (Ord. 331, 7-6-89)
LOAD: The amount of infectious waste transported by one truck, one towed
trailer, one railroad car or any other single vehicle to an infectious waste
area.
MONITOR: To perform a test, sample or otherwise check a discharge or handling
activity to ensure compliance with standards set pursuant to any provision of
this Chapter or any other law, rule or regulation regarding the handling of
infectious wastes.
OFFICER: Any representative of Lyon County whose official duties include
infectious waste control.
OFF-SITE: The substance is being handled at a site other than the location
where the substance was generated.
PERMIT: The infectious waste permit required pursuant to this Chapter.
RELEASE: Any spilling into, leaking into, pumping into, pouring into, emitting
into, emptying into, discharging into, injecting into, escape into, leaching
into, dumping into or onto or in any way disposing into the environment or any
abandonment of infectious wastes.
REMOVE:
   A.   The cleanup or removal of released infectious wastes or environmental
media contaminated by released infectious wastes;
   B.   Such actions as may be necessary to monitor, assess or evaluate the
release of the infectious wastes; or
   C.   The taking of other such actions as may be necessary to mitigate damage
to the public health and the environment.
STORAGE: Retention of infectious waste material by handler.
UNAUTHORIZED RELEASE: The release, discharge or emission of an infectious waste
that does not comply with this chapter and applicable Nevada or Federal law.
USER: Any business or person that, for business purposes, generates, produces,
manufactures, utilizes, treats, stores, transports or otherwise handles
infectious wastes subject to the permit requirements of this chapter. (Ord.
329, 4-6-1989)
6.03.06: OBLIGATIONS OF SAFETY AND CARE:
   A.   General Obligations: No person or business shall use or handle
infectious wastes in a manner which:
      1.   Violates any provisions of this chapter or any other local, Federal
or State Statute, code, rule or regulation relating to infectious wastes.
      2.   Harms or poses a significant risk of harm to the public health or
adverse impact to the environment.
   B.   Specific Obligations: Any person handling or intending to handle an
infectious waste shall obtain and keep current an infectious waste use permit.
A separate permit is required for each place or location where infectious
wastes will be handled. Ordinarily, such use permit will be issued pursuant to
this Code controlling planning and zoning 1 . In the event that the handler
does not have a fixed place or location where infectious wastes will be
handled, he is required to obtain a use permit for nonspecific location prior
to handling any waste pursuant to the County's health and safety police powers
rather than land use control authority. The use permit for nonspecific location
will be applied for, issued and controlled the same as a use permit for a
specific site. (Ord. 329, 4-6-1989)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 15 of this Code.
6.03.07: PROFESSIONAL ASSISTANCE FOR COUNTY DETERMINATIONS:
   A.   Whenever the approval or satisfaction of the County may be required by
this chapter for the design, monitoring, testing or other technical submittal
by an applicant or permit holder, the County may, in its discretion, at such
applicant's or permit holder's sole cost or expense, retain a suitably
qualified independent engineer, chemist, toxicologist or industrial hygienist
or other appropriate consultant, acceptable to the County, for the purpose of
evaluating and rendering a professional opinion regarding the adequacy of such
submittal to achieve the purposes of this chapter.
   B.   Prior to the County retaining any said independent expert, the County
shall consult with the applicant/permit holder regarding the expert to be
retained by County, the scope of the work to be done by said expert and a
reasonable estimate of the cost to be borne by the applicant/permittee. In the
event that a disagreement exists between the County staff and the applicant/
permittee regarding the expert to be utilized, the scope of the work to be done
by said expert or the cost to be assessed against applicant/permittee, the
issue shall be heard and decided by the County Commissioners. The County and
the applicant/permittee shall use their best efforts to cooperate and act
reasonably. The County shall be entitled to rely on such evaluation and/or
opinion of such consultant in making the relevant determinations provided for
in this chapter.
   C.   When County, in its discretion, reasonably determines that a
professional consultant shall be retained, an applicant or permit holder shall
forthwith deposit with the County such sum as may be necessary to pay for the
services of the expert. No new application shall be processed further until
such deposit is made. In the event that a consultant's services are required to
evaluate renewal of an existing infectious waste use permit, such permit shall
be suspended until the necessary deposit is made. (Ord. 329, 4-6-1989)
6.03.08: INFECTIOUS WASTE PERMIT:
   A.   Permit Required: As of the effective date hereof, a permit is required
for all new facilities where infectious wastes will be handled prior to the
construction of the facility.
   B.   Application for Permit; Procedures for Approval and Revocation:
      1.   An applicant for an infectious waste permit shall first pay to the
County a filing fee set by resolution of the Board of Lyon County
Commissioners. The filing fee shall be in a sum sufficient to reimburse the
County for all expenses which the County shall incur in processing the
application.
      2.   The application shall:
         a.   Be in a form prepared by the Lyon County Zoning Administrator and
the Lyon County Emergency Management Director and approved by the Board of Lyon
County Commissioners.
         b.   Not be accepted for filing until it is complete and all
investigations which may be required are complete.
      3.   After the application is accepted for filing by the Lyon County
Planning Department, County shall proceed as follows:
         a.   If the infectious waste permit is to be considered in conjunction
with an application for a special use permit or variance of land use or a
zoning change, the infectious waste permit pro- cess must be completed before
the special use permit/variance/ zoning change application is accepted for
filing; provided, however, if the applicant wishes to proceed simultaneously
with the infectious waste permit application and the land use application, the
County will accept both applications for filing if the applicant formally
waives, in writing, the provisions of NRS 278.315(2) or any other applicable
statute, rule or regulation limiting the period of time within which the County
may consider and process the land use application.
         b.   The application shall be placed on the agenda of the next
available meeting of the Lyon County Planning Commission for consideration and
adoption of a recommendation to the Board of Lyon County Commissioners.
If, in the discretion of the Planning Commission or at the request of the Board
of Lyon County Commissioners, it shall appear that the Lyon County Planning
Commission should hold a hearing in the area of the County which would be most
affected by the infectious waste permit, the Planning Commission is authorized
hereby to hold such a hearing.
         c.   The application, together with the recommendation of the Lyon
County Planning Commission, shall be forwarded to the Board of Lyon County
Commissioners for public hearing and decision.
         d.   The Board of Lyon County Commissioners may approve the infectious
waste permit application as requested, with modifications or conditions, or may
deny the application. Since it is the intention of Lyon County that infectious
wastes be regulated as "a pervasively regulated industry", denial of a permit
application may be based upon any reasonable finding of the County that
issuance of the permit would not be in the best interests of the County or any
of the residents thereof for reasons of health, safety, general welfare or any
other similar good and sufficient reason.
         e.   Any infectious waste permit issued pursuant to this Chapter shall
be subject to continuing review and may be terminated at any time if the permit
holder fails to comply with the terms of this Chapter and/or any special
conditions or modifications. In addition to continuing review, every infectious
waste permit shall be subject to automatic annual review to determine if the
permit should be continued, modified or revoked. No person or entity issued a
permit hereunder shall acquire any property right or other right to renewal or
continuation of the permit. Nonuse of a permit for six (6) months shall result
in automatic revocation.
If, in the opinion of the Lyon County Zoning Administrator, the office of the
District Attorney, the Board of Lyon County Commissioners or the Lyon County
Emergency Management Director, any infectious waste permit should be revoked,
those officers shall so notify the permit holder by legal notice, together with
notification of the date for a revocation hearing before the Board of Lyon
County Commissioners. The infectious waste permit shall be in a state of
suspension from the date of notification to the date of the revocation hearing,
and the permit holder shall not conduct any infectious waste operations during
such suspension. The revocation hearing shall be set for the first available
time and date and shall take precedence over other Board of Lyon County
Commissioners' agenda times, except for other public hearing previously
noticed.
At the conclusion of the public hearing on revocation, the Board of County
Commissioners may revoke the infectious waste permit, reinstate the infectious
waste permit with additional conditions or modifications or reinstate the
permit without additional conditions or modifications.
   C.   Investigative Costs: All applicants for infectious waste use permits
shall deposit, in advance, all costs of processing the application including
any travel costs or other expenses necessary in the County's sole discretion to
reasonably investigate the applicant or the proposed operation.
   D.   Nontransferability of Permit; Expiration: If a handler changes its
operations and begins handling a new infectious waste or if a new handler of
infectious wastes occupies a facility where another handler formerly operated,
then that handler is required to apply for a permit.
Every permit granted hereunder expires automatically with any significant
majority change of ownership or significant change in management of the
hazardous wastes handler entity. (Ord. 329, 4-6-89)
6.03.09: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   General Requirements: All applicants for infectious waste use permits
issued or renewed after the effective date hereof shall be required to provide
liability insurance or other financial surety adequate to insure the public
against the risks reasonably to be anticipated as a result of the handling of
infectious wastes. Lyon County shall be named expressly as an additional
insured on all such policies.
The amount and type of insurance to be required shall be determined by the
County after evaluation of the risks to be insured against. All liability
policies shall be for a minimum of one year with a one year "tail" to cover
later claim. The one-year policy and the "tail" shall be renewed annually.
   B.   Costs for Analysts or Consultants: In the event that the County finds
it necessary to retain an independent analyst to assist the County to determine
the level of insurance to be required, the applicant shall deposit, in advance,
the estimated cost of obtaining such analyst or consultant.
   C.   Qualifications of Insurance Companies: All insurance shall be written
by companies authorized by the Nevada Insurance Commissioner to write policies
of that type in the State of Nevada.
   D.   Types of Insurance Required: The insurance to be required may include,
but is not limited to:
      1.   General liability.
      2.   Sudden and accidental.
      3.   Nonsudden and accidental.
      4.   Environmental pollution.
      5.   Off-premises damages.
      6.   SIIS.
      7.   Additional industrial health insurance.
      8.   Closure expense insurance.
   E.   Termination or Cancellation of Insurance: Any infectious wastes use
permit issued or renewed pursuant to this Chapter shall become void upon the
lapse, termination or cancellation of any insurance policy required hereunder.
(Ord. 329, 4-6-89)
6.03.10: INFECTIOUS WASTE MANAGEMENT PLAN:
   A.   General Requirements: Lyon County requires that each handler establish
an infectious waste management plan (IWMP), which plan must be filed at the
time of application for permit. A responsible person at the facility shall
prepare a comprehensive document that outlines policies and procedures for the
management of infectious waste (including infectious wastes with multiple
hazards). This requirement shall be consistent with the standard of the Joint
Commission on Accreditation of Hospitals (JCAH) which specifies a system "to
safely manage hazardous materials and wastes". This plan shall include the
following elements:
      1.   Waste management options.
      2.   Designation.
      3.   Segregation.
      4.   Packaging.
      5.   Storage.
      6.   Handling and transport.
      7.   Treatment.
      8.   Disposal.
      9.   Staff training.
      10.   Contingency planning.
Various options are available for the development of an infectious waste
management system. Management options for an individual facility shall be
selected on the basis of what is most appropriate for that particular facility.
Factors such as location, size and budget shall be taken into consideration.
The selected options shall be incorporated into a documented infectious waste
management plan. Therefore, a specific person at the generating facility shall
be responsible for implementation of the plan. This person shall have the
responsibility as well as the authority to make sure that the provisions of the
management plan are being followed.
In addition to the overall infectious waste management plan, handlers shall
specify detailed instructions for research and clinical laboratories within the
facility where infectious waste is generated.
   B.   Selection of Waste Management Options:
      1.   In an infectious waste management system, there are a number of
areas in which alternative options are available (e.g., treatment techniques
for the various types of infectious waste, types of treatment equipment,
treatment sites, various waste handling practices, etc.). Selection of
available options at a facility shall be determined by factors such as the
nature of the infectious waste, the quantity of infectious waste generated, the
availability of equipment for treatment on-site and off-site, regulatory
constraints and cost considerations.
Since treatment methods vary with waste type, the waste shall be evaluated and
categorized with regard to its potential to cause disease. Such characteristics
as chemical content, density, water content, bulk, etc., influence waste
treatment decisions. Facilities may use a combination of treatment techniques
for the different components of the infectious waste stream, e.g., steam
sterilization for laboratory cultures and incineration for pathological waste.
      2.   The quantity of each category of infectious waste handled at the
facility may also influence the method of treatment. If a selected option is
not suitable for treatment of all wastes, then other options shall be included
in the infectious waste management plan.
      3.   Handlers shall comply with all Federal, State and local regulations
pertaining to the transport of infectious waste and ensure that the waste is
being handled and treated properly at any off-site treatment facility.
   C.   Designation of Infectious Waste: The first element of an infectious
waste management plan is to specify which wastes are to be managed as
infectious waste. Lyon County has designated seven (7) categories of wastes as
infectious; however, other potentially contaminated wastes shall be evaluated
on an individual basis by an authorized responsible person or committee. The
following categories of waste are designated as infectious waste:
Waste Category Examples*

known to be infected with blood-borne diseases should be managed as infectious
waste (for example, dialysis waste from known hepatitis B patients).

   D.   Infectious Waste Segregation: Infectious waste shall be separated from
the general waste stream to assure that these wastes receive appropriate
handling and treatment. Infectious waste shall be segregated from the general
waste stream at the point of generation (i.e., the point at which the material
becomes a waste).
Provision shall be made for infectious waste with multiple hazards. These
wastes shall be segregated from the general infectious waste stream when
additional or alternative treatment is required, or in cases where the wastes
are regulated under Federal or State rules.
Infectious waste shall be discarded directly into containers or plastic bags
which are clearly identifiable and distinguishable from the general waste
stream. Containers shall be marked with the universal biological hazard symbol.
Red or orange plastic bags shall be used to identify infectious waste.
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/dd62f16ea91c6fb0d01da5553d0f3c050135725a/
IMAGES/0-0-0-2329.gif]
 
The symbol is fluorescent orange or orange-red. The background may be any color
that provides sufficient contrast for the symbol to be clearly defined.
   E.   Packaging:
      1.   Lyon County requires:
         a.   Selection of packaging materials that are appropriate for the
type of waste:
            (1)   Plastic bags for many types of solid or semi-solid infectious
waste.
            (2)   Puncture-resistant containers for sharps.
            (3)   Bottles, flasks or tanks for liquids.
         b.   Use of packaging that maintains its integrity during storage and
transport.
         c.   Use of plastic bags that are impervious, tear resistant and
distinctive in color or markings.
         d.   Closing the top of each bag by folding or tying as appropriate
for the treatment or transport.
         e.   Placement of liquid wastes in capped or tightly stoppered bottles
or flasks.
         f.   No compaction of infectious waste or packaged infectious waste
before treatment.
      2.   Infectious waste shall be packaged in order to protect waste
handlers and the public from possible injury and disease that may result from
exposure to the waste. Infectious waste shall be contained from the point of
origin up to the point at which it is no longer infectious. Therefore, the
integrity of the packaging shall be preserved through handling, storage,
transportation and treatment.
      3.   The following factors shall be considered in selecting appropriate
packaging:
         a.   Waste type.
         b.   Handling and transport of the packaged waste (before treatment).
         c.   Treatment technique.
         d.   Special considerations for plastic bags.
         e.   Package identification.
   To provide adequate waste containment, packaging shall be appropriate for
the type of waste. For example, liquid infectious waste shall be placed in
capped or tightly stoppered bottles or flasks. Containment tanks shall be used
for large quantities of liquid waste. Solid or semi-solid wastes such as
pathological wastes, animal carcasses and laboratory wastes may be placed in
plastic bags.
      4.   Sharps shall be placed directly into impervious, rigid and puncture-
resistant containers to eliminate the hazard of physical injury. Clipping of
needles is not approved, unless the clipping device effectively contains needle
parts which might otherwise become airborne and pose a hazard.
      Authorized containers for sharps are glass, metal, rigid plastic, wood
and heavy cardboard; containers shall be compatible with selected treatment
processes. Sharps containers shall be marked with the universal biohazard
symbol and sealed before handling.
   F.   Storage:
      1.   Lyon County requires:
         a.   Minimizing storage time.
         b.   Proper packaging that ensure containment of infectious waste and
the exclusion of rodents and vermin.
         c.   Limited access to storage area.
         d.   Posting of universal biological hazard symbol on storage area
door, waste containers, freezers or refrigerators.
      2.   Infectious waste shall be treated as soon as possible after
generation. If treatment is not available because of insufficient capacity,
malfunction or unavailability of personnel, waste may be stored under
refrigeration for not more than three (3) days.
      3.   The packaging shall provide containment of the waste throughout the
waste management process. In addition, the packaging shall deter rodents and
vermin and other such vectors in disease transmission.
      4.   Storage temperature and duration must be controlled to prevent
microbial growth and odors typically associated with wastes containing decaying
organic matter.
      5.   The storage area shall be a specially designated area located at or
near the treatment site. The storage area shall have limited access that
restricts the entry of unauthorized personnel. It shall be kept free of rodents
and vermin. In addition,the universal biohazard lablel shall be posted where
appropriate (e.g., doors, waste containers, refrigerators and freezers).
   G.   Handling and Transport:
      1.   General Requirements:
         a.   Lyon County requires:
            (1) Avoidance of mechanical loading devices which may rupture
packaged wastes.
            (2) Frequent disinfection of carts used to transfer wastes within
the facility.
            (3) Placement of all infectious waste into rigid or semi-rigid
containers before transport off-site.
            (4) Transport of infectious waste in closed, leakproof trucks or
dumpsters.
         b.   If the waste is to be moved within the facility for treatment or
storage, packaging shall effectively contain the waste. If necessary, multiple
packaging shall be used to preserve the integrity of the bags and to ensure
containment of the waste. Placing single-bagged waste within a rigid or semi-
rigid container such as a bucket, box or carton is authorized. Plastic bags may
be used as liners for such containers. Another authorized practice is double-
bagging, that is, placing the sealed plastic bag within another bag which is
subsequently sealed. Containers of sharps and liquids may be placed within
other containers (e.g., boxes) for ease of handling. The containers shall be
covered with secure lids during transport and storage. Lids may be opened
during the treatment process.
      2.   Plastic Bags:
         a.   Whenever plastic bags of infectious waste are handled and
especially when they are transferred, care shall be exercised to prevent
tearing of the bags. Plastic bags containing infectious waste shall not be
transported through a chute or dumbwaiter. Mechanical devices shall not be used
for transport or loading of plastic bags containing these wastes. Authorized
practices for handling plastic bags include loading by hand, transporting the
loaded dumpster to minimize handling and placing the plastic bags within rigid
or semi-rigid containers before handling and transport.
         b.   Two (2) different criteria shall be used to judge the suitability
of a plastic bag: its thickness and its durability, as evaluated by the ASTM
dart test. Therefore, procurement shall be based on one or both of these
standards. The important consideration is the selection of tear-resistant
plastic bags that maintain their integrity (at least until the waste is
treated) and, thus, prevent dispersal of infectious agents into the
environment.
      3.   Transporting Off-Site: When infectious waste is transported off-site
for treatment, plastic bags, single or double, shall be placed within rigid or
semi-rigid containers to maintain the integrity of the packaging and prevent
spillage. Depending on the management system, these containers may be recycled
or disposed of. Recycled containers (such as heavy plastic barrels) which are
used repeatedly for transport and treatment of bagged waste shall be
disinfected after each use.
      4.   Compaction of Waste: Infectious waste shall not be compacted prior
to treatment because compacting may actually disperse the infectious waste by
destroying the integrity of the packaging. In addition, compaction may
interfere with the effectiveness of the treatment process.
      5.   Containers Appropriate for Type of Process: Containers to be
incinerated shall be combustible. Containers used in steam sterilization shall
allow steam penetration and evacuation of air. Packaging technique shall be
suitable for the application processes.
      6.   Package Identification: Packaged infectious waste shall be easily
identifiable. This shall be accomplished by the use of containers with the
distinctive red or orange color that indicates biohazardous material and the
use of the universal biohazard symbol on all infectious waste packages and
containers. The identification system shall include clear labelling to indicate
all hazards that are present in the waste.
      The use of appropriate hazard symbols shall be in accordance with
municipal, State and Federal regulations.
      7.   Requirements for Safe Transport: There are two (2) factors which
shall be satisfied to ensure safe transport of infectious waste both within the
facility and to the treatment facility:
         a.   Proper packaging is required to ensure containment of the waste.
         b.   Mechanical devices shall not be used to transfer or load
infectious waste to avoid rupturing of the packaging and dissemination of the
waste.
Carts are acceptable for moving packaged infectious waste within the facility.
Carts shall be disinfected frequently, and carts used to transport infectious
waste shall not be used for other materials prior to decontamination.
   H.   Treatment of Infectious Waste: For the purposes of this Chapter, Lyon
County defines "treatment" as any method, technique or process designed to
change the biological character or composition of waste.
   Lyon County requires:
      1.   Establishing standard operating procedures for each process used for
treating infectious waste.
      2.   Monitoring of all treatment processes to assure efficient and
effective treatment.
      3.   Use of biological indicators to monitor treatment (other indicators
may be used; provided, that their effectiveness has been successfully
demonstrated).
The purpose of treating infectious waste is to reduce the hazard associated
with the presence of infectious agents. Treatment shall reduce or eliminate
pathogens (present in the waste) so that waste no longer poses a hazard to
persons who may be exposed to it.
   I.   Disposal of Treated Waste: Infectious waste which has been effectively
treated is no longer biologically hazardous and may be mixed with and disposed
of as ordinary waste; provided, the waste does not pose other hazards that are
subject to Federal, State or local regulations.
   Needles and syringes shall be rendered nonusable before disposal; treated
sharps may be ground up, incinerated or compacted; for aesthetic reasons, body
parts shall not be recognizable when disposed of.
   J.   Staff Training: Training is required to maintain personnel awareness of
the potential hazards posed by infectious wastes and to reinforce waste
management policies and procedures that are detailed in the infectious waste
management plan.
   K.   Contingency Planning: As part of the infectious waste management plan,
all handlers shall prepare contingency plans to deal with spills and
unauthorized emission discharges and releases of infectious waste.
(Ord. 329, 4-6-89)
6.03.11: INFECTIOUS WASTE FACILITIES SITING:
   A.   Any generator of infectious waste may build and operate an infectious
waste treatment facility, including an appropriate infectious waste
incinerator, in conjunction with any hospital, laboratory, clinic or similar
facility; provided, any such infectious waste treatment facility shall have a
capacity not greater than that required to treat or incinerate the infectious
waste generated at that hospital, laboratory, clinic, etc.
   B.   Other than set forth above, any stationary facility for the treatment,
incineration or disposal of infectious waste, including treatment, incinerator
or disposal in tanks, is subject to the siting criteria set forth in NAC
444.8456.
   C.   A portable facility for the treatment, incineration or transfer of
infectious waste is subject to the siting requirements and considerations set
forth in NRS 278.020. (Ord. 329, 4-6-89)
6.03.12: DISCLAIMER OF LIABILITY:
The degree of protection required by this Chapter is considered reasonable for
regulatory purposes. The standards set forth herein are minimum standards, and
this Chapter does not imply that compliance will ensure that there will be no
unauthorized discharge of an infectious waste. This Chapter shall not create
liability on the part of the County or any officer or employee thereof for any
damages that result from reliance on this Chapter or any administrative
decision lawfully made hereunder. All infectious wastes handlers are advised to
determine to their own satisfaction the level of protection in addition to that
required by this Chapter necessary or desirable to ensure that there is no risk
or damage to public health or the environment. Mere compliance with this
Chapter does not release the handler from civil liability to others for damages
resulting from his use of infectious waste. (Ord. 329, 4-6-89)
6.03.13: ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES:
   A.   Any infectious waste handler who intentionally or negligently violates
any of the provisions of this Chapter may:
      1.   Be denied an infectious waste use permit by the County; or
      2.   Have an infectious waste use permit revoked.
      3.   Be ordered by an enforcement officer to cease operations forthwith
or have the infectious waste use permit suspended pending a formal hearing
before the Board of County Commissioners or a designated hearing officer.
      4.   Be subject to the following penalties:
         a.   Administrative Penalties: Upon a finding by the County that an
infectious waste handler has violated any provision of this Chapter, the County
may levy an administrative fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day for
each violation.
         b.   Civil Penalties: Any infectious waste handler who intentionally
or negligently violates any provision of this Chapter or fails to comply with
any order issued hereunder shall be liable for a civil penalty not to exceed
five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day for each violation which shall be
assessed and recovered in a civil action brought in the name of the County by
the District Attorney. In any civil action brought pursuant hereto, in which
the County prevails, the court shall determine and impose reasonable costs,
including all attorney fees permissible under Nevada law, incurred by the
County in the investigation and prosecution of the action.
         c.   Criminal Penalties: Any person or business which intentionally
violates any provision of the Chapter shall be subject to the criminal
penalties prescribed by Nevada statute for misdemeanor offenses.
   B.   Remedies under this Chapter are in addition to and do not supersede or
limit any and all other remedies, civil or criminal.
   C.   Acceptance by a permittee of a use permit granted pursuant to this
Chapter shall signify acceptance by the permittee of the penalty provisions of
this Chapter as if by contract or otherwise with the County. (Ord. 329, 4-6-89)
CHAPTER 4
BUSINESSES HANDLING HAZARDOUS AND TOXIC MATERIALS 1
SECTION:
6.04.01: Findings Of Fact; Purpose
6.04.02: Definitions
6.04.03: Specific Obligations
6.04.04: Emergency Notification
6.04.05: Siting Criteria
6.04.06: Compliance With Other Regulations
6.04.07: Inspections
6.04.08: Violations And Penalties
 
Notes
1 1. See chapters 1, 2 and 3 of this title for waste disposal regulations.
6.04.01: FINDINGS OF FACT; PURPOSE:
The U.S. government has adopted comprehensive requirements through the adoption
of laws and regulations requiring businesses to report to local officials and
fire officials certain information regarding extremely hazardous substances,
hazardous chemicals and toxic chemicals being handled by them.
Lyon County and various Fire Departments located within the County have limited
resources. The information required is necessary to Lyon County and the various
Fire Departments to allow them to properly plan for emergencies.
In order to ensure compliance, Lyon County, through the adoption of the
provisions of this chapter, intends to monitor and enforce compliance with the
existing Federal reporting requirements. (Ord. 330, 4-6-1989)
6.04.02: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings ascribed to them in this section:
BUSINESS: An employer, self-employed individual, trust, firm, joint stock
company, corporation, partnership, association, city, district and the State of
Nevada, or any department or agency thereof. For the purpose of this chapter, a
"business" shall include both for profit and nonprofit businesses.
COUNTY: Lyon County, Nevada.
DISCHARGE: Includes, but is not limited to, any spilling, leaking, pumping,
pouring, emitting, emptying or dumping of a hazardous material into the
environment.
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN: A written plan setting forth the following:
   A.   Identification of facilities and hazardous materials transportation
routes;
   B.   Emergency response procedures, on site and off site;
   C.   Designation of a facility coordinator(s) to implement the plan;
   D.   Emergency notification procedures;
   E.   Methods for determining the occurrence of a discharge and the probable
affected area and population;
   F.   Description of industry emergency equipment and facilities and the
identity of persons responsible for them;
   G.   Evacuation plans;
   H.   Description and schedules of a training program for emergency response
to chemical emergencies; and
   I.   Methods and schedules for exercising emergency response plans.
EXTREMELY HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES: Those substances in quantities above the
threshold planning quantities as listed by Federal Environmental Protection
Agency as extremely hazardous substances in the Federal register, including any
amendments or updates to said lists.
FACILITY: Any building, structure, installation, equipment, pipe or pipeline or
any of the foregoing that are related by nature of contiguity, ownership or
industrial process and used for the handling of hazardous materials.
HANDLE: To generate, treat, manufacture, produce, store, use, discharge,
release, transfer, dispose of, incinerate or emit in any fashion a hazardous
material.
HAZARDOUS MATERIAL: All substances meeting the criteria of "extremely hazardous
substance", "hazardous substances" or "toxic chemicals".
HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES: The following substances, when held in quantities
requiring notification under SARA Title III, sections 311 and 312.
   A.   Those substances and chemicals in the OSHA Hazard Communication
Standard;
   B.   Those substances which meet the performance- based classification
criteria for hazard determination under the OSHA Hazard Communication Standard;
and
   C.   Federal environmental list of hazardous substances as defined in the
Comprehensive Environmental Response, Conservation and Liability Act (CERCLA).
MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEETS: A. Chemical identity (by OSHA definition as
defined by OSHA in the Standard).
   B.   Physical and chemical characteristics.
   C.   Physical hazards.
   D.   Health hazards, including signs and symptoms of exposure and any
medical conditions generally recognized as being aggravated by exposure to the
chemical.
   E.   Primary route(s) of exposure.
   F.   The OSHA PEL, ACGIH TLV and any other exposure limit used or
recommended by the chemical manufacturer, importer or employer preparing the
MSDS.
   G.   Whether it is deemed under the Standard to be a carcinogen.
   H.   Any generally applicable precautions for safe handling and use known to
the person preparing the MSDS.
   I.   Any generally applicable control measures known to the person preparing
the MSDS.
   J.   Emergency and first aid procedures.
   K.   Date of preparation or latest revision.
   L.   The name, address, and telephone number of a responsible party who can
provide additional information on the chemical and appropriate emergency
procedures if necessary.
TOXIC CHEMICALS: Chemicals specified by Congress in the Emergency Planning and
Community Right-to-Know Act and held in amounts requiring notification under
SARA Title III, section 313. (Ord. 330, 4-6-89)
6.04.03: SPECIFIC OBLIGATIONS:
Any business handling extremely hazardous substances, hazardous substances and
toxic chemicals shall, during March of each year, provide, in writing, to the
Lyon County Safety Officer and all Fire Departments serving the area in which
the facility is located the following information:
   A.   Material safety data sheets for all extremely hazardous substances,
hazardous substances and toxic chemicals located at facilities within the
County.
   B.   An emergency response plan.
All information required shall be kept current by the responsible business. In
the event that there is no change in the required information, the person may
so indicate, in writing, in lieu of filing new material safety data sheets or
an emergency response plan. (Ord. 354, 5-2-1991)
6.04.04: EMERGENCY NOTIFICATION:
   A.   If a facility handles a hazardous material, it must immediately notify
Lyon County if there is a release of a listed hazardous material that exceeds
the reportable quantity for that substance as established by SARA title III,
section 304.
   B.   Emergency notification shall be given as soon as practicable, but in no
event longer than one hour after the release is discovered. Notice of a release
may be made by telephone, radio or in person and shall be made to the Lyon
County Sheriff's Office Dispatch Center and the Lyon County Safety Officer.
   C.   The emergency notification shall include:
      1.   The chemical name;
      2.   An indication of whether the substance is an extremely hazardous
substance;
      3.   An estimate of the quantity released into the environment;
      4.   The time and duration of the release;
      5.   The medium into which the release occurred;
      6.   Any known or anticipated acute or chronic health risks associated
with the emergency and, where appropriate, advice regarding medical attention
necessary for exposed individuals;
      7.   Proper precautions such as evacuation; and
      8.   The name and telephone number of a contact person.
In the event all of the above required information is not immediately
available, the responsible party shall make the immediate notification of the
available information, with the remainder of the information being provided
immediately when it becomes available. (Ord. 330, 4-6-1989)
6.04.05: SITING CRITERIA:
All handlers of hazardous materials shall comply with the applicable
requirements of the zoning and special use permit requirements 1 . (Ord. 330,
4-6-1989)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 15 of this Code.
6.04.06: COMPLIANCE WITH OTHER REGULATIONS:
The obligations of all businesses required under this chapter shall be in
addition to any other requirements established by law, ordinance or regulation
by any Federal, State or local entity. Compliance with this chapter shall not
relieve the responsible party or entity from any other requirements. (Ord. 330,
4-6-1989)
6.04.07: INSPECTIONS:
The Lyon County Emergency Management Director is hereby authorized to enter and
inspect all businesses for compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Said
inspection shall include the right to inspect and copy all records and
documents relating to receiving, shipping, storage and use of hazardous
materials in Lyon County. (Ord. 356, 5-16-1991)
6.04.08: VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES:
All violations of this chapter shall be punishable as for a misdemeanor under
State law. In addition, any violation shall be considered a substantial
violation of the business license 1 , special use permit 3 , or hazardous waste
permit 4 of the responsible business. (Ord. 330, 4-6-1989)
 
Notes
1 2. See title 5, chapter 1 of this Code.
3 3. See subsection
  15.230.01C of this Code.
4 4. See chapter 2 of this title.
CHAPTER 5
MEDICAL CARE ELIGIBILITY STANDARDS
SECTION:
6.05.01: Definitions
6.05.02: Director of County Welfare Department
6.05.03: Medical Care Eligibility Requirements and Restrictions
6.05.04: Extent of County Medical Care
6.05.05: Fraud
6.05.06: Rules and Regulations
6.05.07: Denial of Medical or Financial Assistance; Appeals
6.05.01: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this Section:
COMMISSIONERS: The Board of Lyon County Commissioners.
DIRECTOR: The Director of the Lyon County Welfare Department.
WELFARE DEPARTMENT: The Lyon County Department of Welfare. (Ord. 357, 5-16-91)
6.05.02: DIRECTOR OF COUNTY WELFARE DEPARTMENT:
A Director shall be appointed by the Commissioners who, under the direct
supervision of the Commissioners, shall discharge all those duties and
administer all such programs as the Commissioners may, from time to time,
delegate to the Director. Such duties and administrative responsibilities shall
be restricted to those which, under the various laws of the State pertaining to
welfare matters, are made the responsibility of the counties and which can be
lawfully delegated by the Board of County Commissioners to appointed or elected
officials of such counties. The Director shall serve at the will of the
Commissioners and at a salary to be fixed by them.
The Director is expressly authorized to exercise those powers and perform those
duties granted to the Commissioners under NRS 428.070 in the performance of his
duties delegated in this Section. (Ord. 357, 5-16-91)
6.05.03: MEDICAL CARE ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   General Requirements: A person is eligible for County medical care if:
      1.   He is in need of medical care;
      2.   Does not have sufficient funds, as determined in accordance with the
provisions of this Chapter, to pay for all or part of his medical care;
      3.   Is not eligible for a State or Federal medical care program or
private medical insurance.
   B.   Income Test: A person does not have sufficient funds if his average net
monthly income and number of persons dependent upon that income are as set
forth in the following schedule:
Number of Persons Dependent Upon Schedule of Monthly Net
Income of Patient or Responsible Net Income
Responsible Relative
1                                Less than $438.00
2                                Less than 588.00
3                                Less than 738.00
4                                Less than 888.00
5                                Less than 1,138.00
6                                Less than 1,288.00
 
   For each additional person over 6, there shall be added $150.00 to the above
limit of income.
   C.   Computation of Income: For the purpose of the foregoing table, the
following deductions for regular monthly payments shall be allowed on:
      1.   Existing medical bills.
      2.   Purchase of prosthetic devices prescribed by a physician.
      3.   Medical and hospital insurance premiums.
      4.   The cost of living away from home for any member of the family due
to illness, to be allowed on an individual basis and calculated upon the
difference between the cost so incurred and the cost which would have been
incurred if the person remained at home.
      5.   Alimony and child support; provided, that such payment is paid to a
person not included as one of the "persons dependent on income of patient or
responsible relative" in the above table.
      6.   Funeral expenses not to exceed one thousand five hundred dollars
($1,500.00) for any one funeral.
      7.   Necessary costs for child care required to maintain employment.
      8.   Necessary expenses of employment.
      9.   Involuntary deductions from income, such as income tax, social
security contributions and retirement fund payments.
      10.   For self-employed persons, deductions of expenses incurred in the
conduct of business as allowed by Federal income tax laws.
   D.   Other Eligibility Factors: If a person does not meet the income test in
subsection B of this Section, he may be eligible if it is determined by the
Director that he does not have sufficient funds to pay for all or part of his
medical care by reason of the following other factors:
      1.   Nature of the disability; effect of the disability, if any, on
future income production.
      2.   Estimated length of hospitalization.
      3.   Estimated elapsed time before employed person may return to work.
   E.   Effect of Property Ownership: Even if a person does meet other tests
for eligibility, he may be ineligible if he owns property; except, that he may:
      1.   Own a personally occupied residence having an assessed valuation not
in excess of the amount to be set forth in the rules and regulations to be
adopted pursuant to Section 6.05.06 of this Chapter.
      2.   Own personal property with a quick sale or cash value not in excess
of the amount to be set forth in the rules and regulations to be adopted
pursuant to Section 6.05.06 of this Chapter.
      3.   As herein provided, a lien in favor of the Welfare Department on
real property so owned by the person may be imposed as a condition to
certification of an applicant for medical care at County expense. (Ord. 357, 5-
16-91)
6.05.04: EXTENT OF COUNTY MEDICAL CARE:
Medical care shall be rendered to eligible persons to the extent and subject to
the conditions set forth in this Section.
   A.   Care Facilities: Medical care, as is necessary for the health and
safety of an eligible person, shall be provided at South Lyon Community
Hospital (formerly known as Lyon Health Center) and may be rendered at places
other than South Lyon Community Hospital only upon approval of the Welfare
Department.
   B.   Reimbursement to County: As a condition of such care, an eligible
person shall reimburse the County in accordance with the following rules:
      1.   The applicant or other responsible party will be required to
reimburse the Welfare Department for that portion of the medical expenses that
fall within his financial ability;
      2.   If a person who has received care acquires property or otherwise
ceases to be eligible, the cost of care shall be a charge against him to the
extent such cost exceeds his eligibility;
      3.   The County shall render to a person who has been provided care in a
County hospital a statement setting forth the charges upon which its claim for
reimbursement is based; and
      4.   No interest or carrying charge shall be charged in connection with
any debt incurred for County hospital care.
   C.   Liens:
      1.   Lien Imposed; Exceptions: If it is determined by the Welfare
Department to be in the best interest of the County, a lien against the
property of the eligible person or responsible relative may be required. Such a
lien shall not be enforced against the home of the eligible person or his
responsible relative:
         a.   During his lifetime or that of his spouse.
         b.   During the lifetime of any dependent adult child who resides in
the home and who is incapable of self-support because of mental or physical
disability.
      2.   Release of Lien: Any lien taken by the County for County hospital
care shall be released immediately when the amount owing the County for that
care is paid.
      3.   Transfer of Lien: If a person against whose home a lien has been
imposed for County hospital care desires to acquire a different home, the
County may release its lien against the original home and transfer it to the
new home if its security will not thereby be impaired.
      4.   Home Improvements; Additions to Lien: If the person desires to
borrow money for the purpose of making improvements to his home, using his home
as security, the County may subordinate its lien to the mortgage or other
security interest given for the loan if its security will not thereby be
impaired.
   D.   Responsible Relatives: The cost of care rendered to a person is a
charge against the responsible relative of that person in accordance with the
following rules:
      1.   A responsible relative is a spouse, parent, adult children and adult
brothers and sisters of that person to whom aid is rendered; and
      2.   The cost of such care shall not be a charge against a responsible
relative who is a recipient of public assistance or is eligible for a Federal
or State medical care program.
   E.   Installment Payments: If the Director deems it appropriate, a person
against whom the cost of care is a charge may pay in installments in such
amounts and at such intervals as approved by the Director; except, that the
term of such installment arrangement shall not exceed three (3) years. (Ord.
357, 5-16-91)
6.05.05: FRAUD:
In cases where it appears the applicant or responsible relative has conveyed
away substantial property prior to application or any time thereafter, the
Welfare Department shall determine as soon as possible whether such transfer
was for a fair and adequate consideration and whether or not the transfer in
effect makes the person a public charge. In such a case, the County may then
proceed against responsible relatives or other parties involved to recover the
expenses incurred by the County. (Ord. 357, 5-16-91)
6.05.06: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The Welfare Department shall have the duty and the right to establish such
other rules and regulations or to amend existing rules and regulations as it
may, from time to time, find necessary in order to give the provisions of this
Chapter full force and effect. Such new rules and regulations shall have the
force and effect of law when their adoption is ordered by the Commissioners and
placed on file with the Clerk thereof. (Ord. 357, 5-16-91)
6.05.07: DENIAL OF MEDICAL OR FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE; APPEALS:
   A.   Notice of Denial: A person who is denied medical or financial
assistance and his representative must be notified, in writing, within fifteen
(15) days from the date of denial by personal service or certified mail setting
forth the factual basis for the denial and the applicable regulation.
   B.   Appeals:
      1.   A person may appeal the denial within thirty (30) days of the date
written notice was served or mailed, to the commissioners, and shall have the
right to be represented in such appeal by his counsel or agents.
      2.   A person aggrieved by the final decision of the commissioners may,
within thirty (30) days after the date on which the written notice of the
decision is served or mailed, petition the district court to review the
decision. The court shall review the decision on the record of the case before
the commissioners, a copy of which must be certified as correct by the chairman
of the commissioners and filed with the court as part of its answer to the
petition. The procedure set forth in Nevada Revised Statutes 428.093 shall
govern the review by the district court of the petition of the aggrieved party.
(Ord. 357, 5-16-1991)
TITLE 7
POLICE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
ANIMALS AND ANIMAL SERVICES
SECTION:
7.01.01: Definitions
7.01.02: Jurisdiction
7.01.03: Animal Services Officer
7.01.04: Dogs; Licensing Requirements; Tags, Permits And Fees
7.01.05: Prohibited Acts And Conditions
7.01.06: Impoundment Of Dogs On Private Property
7.01.07: Rabies Control
7.01.08: Businesses That Sell Or Board Dogs For Profit Or Act As A Breeder
7.01.09: Disposition Of Revenue
7.01.10: Penalty
7.01.01: DEFINITIONS:
ADEQUATE FEED: The provision at suitable intervals for the species, of a
quantity of wholesome foodstuff for the species, physical condition and age,
sufficient to maintain an adequate level of nutrition in the animal, such
foodstuff to be served in a clean receptacle, dish or container.
ADEQUATE SHELTER: A physical structure or place suitable for maintaining the
health and life of an animal.
ADEQUATE WATER: An adequate supply of clean, fresh, potable water provided at
suitable intervals for the species, physical condition and age of the animal
provided at least once every twelve (12) hours.
ANIMAL SERVICES OFFICER: The person or persons hired by Lyon County for the
purpose of enforcement of the provisions of this chapter and state laws
relating to animals and animal control.
AT LARGE: Any place off the premises of the owner or person having custody and
control of a dog and not accompanied by and under the control of the owner or
any other responsible person by physical restraint or signal command or voice
command.
BIG GAME ANIMAL: Any species of prong horned antelope, bear, deer, mountain
goat, mountain lion, bighorn sheep or elk which runs free in the wild.
BOARD: The board of county commissioners for Lyon County.
BREEDER: A dealer, operator, or other person who is responsible for the
operation of a commercial establishment engaged in the business of breeding
dogs or cats for sale or trade. The term does not include a person who breeds
dogs or cats as a hobby.
COUNTY: Lyon County, a political subdivision of the state of Nevada.
DEALER: A person who, for compensation or profit, buys, sells, breeds, trades
or imports cats or dogs for resale.
ESTRAY HORSE: Any horse running at large upon public or private lands in the
county whose owner is unknown in the section where the animal is found.
KENNEL:
Breeder's Kennel: Any enclosure, premises, building, structure, lot or area
where more than three (3) dogs of a recognized registered breed over six (6)
months of age are kept, harbored or maintained as follows:
   A.   For breeding;
   B.   For showing in recognized dog shows, field or obedience trials;
   C.   For working or hunting; or
   D.   For improving the variety or breed in temperament or conformation with
a view to exhibition in shows or trials or for use as working dogs in hunting.
Commercial Kennel: Any enclosure, premises, building, structure, lot or area
where more than three (3) dogs over six (6) months of age are kept, harbored or
maintained for commercial purposes.
LICENSED VETERINARIAN: A doctor of veterinary medicine currently licensed in
Nevada to practice veterinary medicine.
OPERATOR: A person responsible for the operation of:
   A.   A cattery 1 , kennel or commercial establishment engaged in the
business of selling animals; or
   B.   An animal shelter 2 .
OWNER: Any person owning, keeping or harboring a dog or any other animal
regulated by this chapter.
POUND: Any facility designated by the board for receiving and holding dogs or
any other animal regulated by this chapter.
RABIES CONTROL AUTHORITY: The person(s) designated by the board to administer
the rabies control provisions of this chapter.
SERVICE ANIMAL: An animal which has been or is being trained to provide a
specialized service to a person with a disability.
VICIOUS OR DANGEROUS TENDENCIES: An animal possesses vicious or dangerous
tendencies if the animal has bitten, attempted to bite, injured or attempted to
injure any person or other animal.
WILD HORSE: Any horse, mare or colt which is unbranded and unclaimed and lives
on public land. (Ord. 475, 3-18-2004, eff. 4-9-2004; amd. Ord. 563, 1-7-2013)
 
Notes
1 1. As defined in NRS 574.
2 2. As defined in NRS 574.
7.01.02: JURISDICTION:
The terms of this chapter shall apply in all unincorporated areas within Lyon
County. (Ord. 475, 3-18-2004, eff. 4-9-2004)
7.01.03: ANIMAL SERVICES OFFICER:
   A.   Authority: The animal services officer is empowered to:
      1.   Enforce all provisions of this chapter, including the power to issue
misdemeanor citations for violations of this chapter and related matters.
      2.   Take into custody and safely keep any animal(s) found to be in
violation of the provisions of this chapter.
      3.   Remove from any property any animal(s) when necessary for the
protection of the animal(s) or the general public.
   B.   Interference With Animal Services Officer: No person shall interfere
with or resist any animal services officer while engaged in the performance of
their duties pertaining to the enforcement of this chapter.
   C.   Consult With State Veterinarian: In the performance of his/her duties,
the animal services officer and his/her authorized representative will consult
with the state veterinarian or their representatives concerning the type and
method of use of all drugs to be utilized. (Ord. 475, 3-18-2004, eff. 4-9-2004)
7.01.04: DOGS; LICENSING REQUIREMENTS; TAGS, PERMITS AND FEES:
   A.   License Requirements: All dogs over the age of six (6) months in Lyon
County and owned by a resident of Lyon County shall be licensed, except for
dogs being used for the purpose of herding livestock or the protection of
livestock against predators on farm or ranch property designated as greenbelt
by the assessor, and dogs that are being temporarily housed in kennels or
animal shelters or in animal hospitals operated by a licensed veterinarian.
      1.   Dog Licenses:
         a.   License And Tag: Upon presentation of a certificate of rabies
vaccination and the payment of the license fee, the Lyon County animal services
division or a designated representative shall issue to the owner a license
receipt and metallic tag for each dog licensed. The metallic tags shall be worn
by the licensed dog on a visible collar. Show dogs while being shown and
working dogs while in the field are exempt from wearing the tag.
No penalty shall be imposed if:
            (1)   The license is obtained within thirty (30) days of expiration
of current license.
            (2)   The license is obtained within thirty (30) days after moving
into the county.
            (3)   The license is obtained within thirty (30) days after a
change of ownership.
If the license is not purchased within such time period, the owner shall pay,
in addition to the regular license fee, a penalty of one hundred percent
(100%).
         b.   License Fees: The fees for dog licenses and tags, other than dogs
housed in a kennel, shall be set by resolution of the board of Lyon County
commissioners. The fees shall be for each full year (12 months). At no time can
the expiration date of the license sold extend past the date that the rabies
expired.
   B.   Animal Services Tags, Permits And Fees:
      1.   Every person, firm or corporation owning, operating or maintaining a
commercial kennel or any business involving the keeping of any animal including
the keeping of animals for the purpose of breeding, for the purpose of medical
treatment, for the purpose of care for hire, for sale or for the purpose of
grooming shall first obtain a license from Lyon County to operate said business
or commercial kennel, as provided for in this title and title 5 of this code,
but the granting of said license shall be subject to the approval, denial, or
revocation by the animal services supervisor. Such business license shall at
all times be subject to the planning and zoning regulations of Lyon County.
Such licenses must be renewed annually and exempt that person from having to
obtain other licenses required in this chapter.
      2.   No person shall keep more than three (3) canine animals over six (6)
months of age at any place, or on any premises, or in any one residence without
first obtaining a permit from the animal services supervisor. Such permit fee
shall be set by the board of commissioners, and is in addition to the license
fee required, per year per dog kept over three (3) in number. License fees for
service dogs and dogs owned by persons classified as senior citizens shall be
waived. Such permit shall at all times be subject to the planning and zoning
regulations of Lyon County.
      3.   The animal services supervisor in approving, denying or revoking any
license and permit required in subsections B1 and B2 of this section shall
consider the following:
         a.   The animal services supervisor shall determine if the person
requesting a license or permit can keep or maintain any animal or animals so as
to not create a public nuisance.
         b.   The animal services supervisor shall determine if the person
requesting a license or permit can keep or maintain the animal or animals in
compliance with all the requirements of this chapter and all other ordinances
of Lyon County, and the laws of the state of Nevada.
Every person must hold a license for every dog he or she owns, keeps, harbors
or possesses. The owner of any dog over the age of six (6) months shall, within
thirty (30) days after obtaining the dog or first bringing said dog into Lyon
County, obtain and continuously maintain for said dog a current and valid
animal services tag issued by the Lyon County animal services department.
   C.   Impoundment And Redemption Provisions 1 :
      1.   Authority To Impound: The animal services officer or his authorized
representatives and every peace officer, while on duty, are authorized to take
up, seize and impound:
         a.   Subject to the provisions of this chapter, all dogs found
trespassing on private property or running at large on any street, alley,
court, park, school playground, right of way or private street open for use to
the general public.
         b.   All dogs in the county which are endangering private or public
property, public safety, themselves or other animals.
      2.   Notice Of Impoundment; Disposition Of Unclaimed Dogs:
         a.   Where the identity of the owner of an impounded dog is
discovered, such owner shall be given notice of the impoundment. Seven (7) days
after written notice is mailed, or actual notice is given, the impounded dog
may be destroyed in a humane manner under the direction of the animal services
officer; provided however, any such dog authorized for destruction may be
released for adoption in accordance with applicable law.
         b.   In the event the identity of the owner of an impounded dog cannot
be ascertained and notice given, then such dog may be disposed of pursuant to
this subsection C five (5) days after impoundment.
      3.   Reclaiming Impounded Dogs:
         a.   The owner or person entitled to the custody or possession of any
impounded dog may, at any time before the disposition thereof, reclaim or
redeem such animal by complying with the provisions of this chapter and
regulations hereunder and by paying to the animal services officer all charges
imposed for the impounding of the dog and any license fees due as set forth by
the fee schedule.
      4.   Regulations For Costs; Disposition:
         a.   Lyon County is authorized to set forth reasonable regulations for
charging owners or persons having the care, custody or possession of dogs
impounded under this chapter for all costs and maintenance incurred by the
county. (Ord. 475, 3-18-2004, eff. 4-9-2004)
