      6.   Penalties For Overuse: Property owners or their agents with water
rights who use water in an amount greater than the provided or allocated
amounts must:
         a.   Pay an assessment that is equal to double the amount charged per
one thousand (1,000) gallons over the base water rate; and
         b.   Reduce consumption; or
         c.   Provide additional water rights to Lyon County. (Ord. 504, 1-18-
2007, amd. Ord. 512, 8-2-2007; Ord. 622, 12-16-2021)
9.03.06: MAIN EXTENSIONS AND/OR CAPACITY ENHANCEMENTS:
   A.   Application For Main Extension And/Or Capacity Enhancement: The
following rules are established for making main extensions and/or capacity
enhancement:
      1.   Application: Any owner of one or more lots or parcels, or subdivider
of a tract of land, desiring the extension of one or more water mains to serve
such property, shall make a written application to LCUD on a form provided by
LCUD.
      2.   Investigation: Upon receipt of the application, LCUD shall make an
investigation of the proposed extension and/or enhancement.
      3.   Reimbursements: The board of commissioners may consider
reimbursement agreements as presented by the director or county manager.
      4.   LCUD Lines: All extensions must be approved and accepted by LCUD and
be offered for dedication to the county by the applicant. There may be a
situation where the main extension may be privately owned.
      5.   Dead End Lines: No dead end lines shall be permitted, except at the
discretion of the utilities director.
   B.   Costs: All costs and expenses incident to the installation and
connection of any water service or other work for which a permit has been
issued shall be borne by the applicant, and shall be in addition to all fees
established by the board. The owner shall indemnify LCUD for any loss or damage
that may be directly or indirectly related to the work. All work shall be made
by or be authorized by LCUD.
   C.   Reserved.
   D.   Reimbursement Agreement: If the applicant must extend the water main
through another's property or along the frontages of another's property or
along the frontages of various intermediate property owners, and if said
properties are not currently served by the county's water system, then said
intermediate and benefiting property owners shall be responsible when
development commences or connection is made for a pro rata share of the costs
of the water line extension.
   When the applicant is required to extend a water line, he shall "front end"
the entire cost of the water line design and construction and shall be
responsible for the actual construction of said water line. Any owners of
properties to be served by the extended water line will thereafter be
responsible for reimbursing the first property owner through LCUD for a pro
rata share of the costs of the water line at the time said subsequent owners
begin to plat, parcel, develop or build upon their parcels. LCUD may reimburse
the applicant for materials associated with oversizing at LCUD's request. Only
the difference in cost between the two (2) different sizes will be considered.
   The pro rata shares for the applicant and all subsequent owners benefited by
the extended water line shall be determined prior to the county entering into
the reimbursement agreement. Extensions and/or capacity upgrades financed by
the applicant shall be prorated to the linear footage along the extension. Flag
lots and large parcels with narrow frontage may be calculated by a percentage
of the parcel square footage in relation to the main line installation cost
percentage.
   The county shall collect a fifteen percent (15%) administrative fee from the
applicant who front ended the water line construction upon reimbursement by
deducting the fifteen percent (15%) administrative fee from the subsequent
owners' pro rata share prior to reimbursement to the applicant by the county.
The reimbursement agreement shall become null and void ten (10) years from the
date of board of county commissioners' approval.
   The applicant shall submit three (3) bids prior to construction from
qualified contractors attached to the application for reimbursement, unless due
to extraordinary circumstances three (3) bids are not available due to
specialized construction. The bids shall be itemized and include costs for all
items to be installed. Failure to provide the itemized bids will exempt the
installation from reimbursement. Construction costs eligible for reimbursement
are limited to engineering, contractor's bid, construction staking by an
engineer or surveyor, permit, inspection and testing fees. Final costs must be
approved by LCUD and may require certification from a Nevada licensed civil
engineer. The applicant's administration costs are not eligible for
reimbursement.
   Single-family homes on property zoned single-family existing at the time of
application for a reimbursement agreement shall be exempt from the provisions
of the agreement. When an existing single-family home is on a parcel which has
adequate area to be divided per the current zoning or master plan designation
of the parcel, the area which could be divided for new development will be
required to be included in the reimbursement agreement. In no event shall any
owners of the property to be served by such extended water lines be permitted
to connect thereto without first paying to the county the pro rata share of the
costs described above as well as all other fees required by the county.
   Any facilities installed pursuant to this section are the property of the
LCUD upon inspection and acceptance by the county and LCUD. A one year warranty
agreement period is in effect for the contractor to be responsible for repairs.
(Ord. 504, 1-18-2007)
9.03.07: GENERAL USE REGULATIONS:
   A.   Number Of Services Per Premises: The applicant may apply for as many
services as may be reasonably required for the premises provided that the
pipeline system for each service is independent of the others and that they not
be interconnected. LCUD must approve all service connections.
   B.   Water Waste: It is unlawful for anyone connected to the public water
system to waste water. For the purpose of this section, "waste" means any
excessive usage which causes water to run into or along any street, alley,
storm drainage system, or into or upon another's property; provided nothing in
this section shall be construed as to apply to the accidental breaking of any
hose, water pipe, or other irrigation. If such breaks are not repaired or the
water turned off within the specified time once notice is given, LCUD may
discontinue water service, and it is unlawful for any person to again turn on
such water until proper repairs have been made.
   If personal notice is unable to be given, the water may be immediately shut
off by the LCUD and a notice shall be placed on the most accessible door
stating the reason for shutoff. If service is disconnected due to failure to
stop the waste that may cause damage or during moderate or strict conservation,
a service fee will be charged for every occurrence after the first shutoff.
Other penalties may apply as prescribed in subsection 9.03.16E of this chapter.
   Exception: Car washing by civic or philanthropic groups may receive written
approval from the utilities director or his/her designee when it is determined
that said usage will not be detrimental to the public water supply.
   C.   Responsibility For Equipment On Customer Premises: All facilities
installed by LCUD on private property for the purpose of rendering water
service shall remain the property of LCUD and may be maintained, repaired or
replaced by the LCUD without consent or interference of the owner or occupant
of the property. The property owner shall use reasonable care in the protection
of the facilities. No payment shall be made for placing or maintaining said
facilities on private property. Easements and rights of way are to be kept free
of encroachment of any kind, and LCUD shall have access to such areas, and any
obstructions or encroachments in these areas shall be removed at the expense of
the customer and/or owner. All meters and meter boxes must be clearly marked
and accessible and are to be kept free of encroachment of any kind. Any
obstructions, encroachments and/or inaccessibility conditions will be removed
at the customer's and/or owner's expense, and shall become a charge on the
customer's bill. LCUD has no responsibility to return the site to anything but
its natural, unlandscaped condition.
   D.   Damage To Water System Facilities: The customer shall be liable for any
damage to the service facilities when such damage is from causes originating on
the premises by an act of the customer or his tenants, agents, employees,
contractors, licensees or permittees, including the breaking or destruction of
locks or tags by the customer or others on or near a meter, and any damage to a
meter that may result from hot water or steam from a boiler or heater on the
customer's premises. LCUD shall be reimbursed by the customer for any such
damage promptly on presentation of a bill. Damage to water system would also
include, but not be limited to, damage to meter boxes, fire hydrants, water
valves and boxes, removal of meter location stakes, service lines and
distribution system.
   E.   Ground Wire Attachments: All individuals or business organizations are
forbidden to attach any ground wire or wires to any plumbing which is or may be
connected to a service connection or main belonging to LCUD. LCUD will hold the
customer liable for any damage to its property occasioned by such attachments.
   F.   Control Valve On The Customer's Property: The customer shall provide a
valve on his side of the service connection to control the flow of water to the
piping on his premises. The customer shall not use the meter valve or curb stop
valve to turn water on or off for his convenience.
   G.   Relief Valves And Regulating Valves: As a protection to the customer's
or owner's plumbing system, a suitable pressure relief valve and pressure
regulating valve must be installed and maintained at the customer's or owner's
expense. When check valves or other protective devices are used, the relief
valve and an expansion tank shall be installed between the check valves and the
water heater.
   H.   Service Size: Where increased meter and service sizes are required, the
owner is responsible for the installation and associated cost of any needed
infrastructure. Only contractors approved by LCUD are allowed to install
waterworks infrastructure. Any costs incurred by LCUD will be charged to the
owner on a time and materials basis.
   I.   Discontinued Service: The service of water to any premises may be
immediately discontinued by LCUD if any defect is found in the check valve or
other protective devices, or if it is found that dangerous unprotected cross
connections, or jumper connections exist. Services will not be restored until
such defects have been corrected and inspected by LCUD. LCUD shall not be
responsible for damages or losses as a result of the water being disconnected.
   J.   Interruptions In Service: LCUD shall not be liable for damage or losses
which may result from an interruption in service from a cause beyond the
control of LCUD or during emergency shutdowns.
   K.   Ingress And Egress: Representatives from LCUD shall have the right of
ingress and egress to the customer's premises at reasonable hours for any
purpose reasonably connected with the furnishing of water service.
   L.   Nonexistent Services: Where service lines do not exist from the main to
the property line, the applicant is responsible for service line installation
and costs under the ordinances, rules and regulations of LCUD.
   M.   Pools And Tanks: When an abnormally large quantity of water is desired
for filling a swimming pool or for other purposes, arrangements must be made
with LCUD prior to taking such water. Permission to take water in unusual
quantities will be given only if it can be safely delivered through LCUD's
facilities and if other consumers are not inconvenienced thereby.
   N.   Responsibility For Equipment: The customer shall, at his own risk and
expense, furnish, install and keep in good and safe condition all equipment
that may be required for receiving, controlling, applying and utilizing water,
and LCUD shall not be responsible for any loss or damage caused by the improper
installation of such equipment, or the negligence or wrongful act of the
customer or of any of his tenants, agents, employees, contractors, licensees or
permittees in installing, maintaining, operating or interfering with such
equipment. LCUD shall not be responsible for damage or losses to property
caused by faucets, pipes, valves and other equipment that are open or leaking
when water is turned on at the meter, either originally or when turned on after
a temporary discontinuance of service. Costs of repairs, replacements or
disruption of services shall be borne by the customer.
   O.   Use Of Siphons: No siphon of any nature shall be operated from any
service connected to LCUD's system.
   P.   Uniform Plumbing Code And Standard Details: The following uniform
plumbing code provisions are made a part of this chapter. Deviations from the
UPC must be approved by LCUD.
      1.   This chapter hereby adopts the 2003 uniform plumbing code and its
appendices including: A, B, C, E, H, I (omitting the standards contained within
"I" of 8-95, 11-87), K, (omit K-7 and K-8), and L, (omit L4.0 to L6.3).
      2.   This chapter hereby adopts the "Standard Specifications For Public
Works Construction" and "Lyon County Standard Details" most current versions.
(Ord. 504, 1-18-2007)
9.03.08: METERS:
   A.   Meter Installation: Meters will be installed on all services. This
chapter establishes the minimum meter size to be three-fourths inch (3/4").
Flat rate services will not be allowed.
   All meter installation charges are based upon materials and labor costs.
Only duly authorized LCUD employees or contractors preapproved by the LCUD will
be authorized to install service connections and/or meters. Meters will be
installed at the property line and shall be owned by LCUD. The seal or lock of
any meter sealed by LCUD shall not be altered or broken except by one of its
authorized employees or agents.
   B.   Change In Location Of Meters: Meters moved or raised for the
convenience of the customer will be relocated at the customer's expense and
must be approved by LCUD. Meters moved to protect LCUD's property will be moved
at LCUD's expense.
   C.   Meter Tests; Deposit: If a customer desires to have the meter serving
his premises tested, he shall first make a deposit in the amount established by
the board. Should the meter register faster than AWWA standards, latest
revision, the deposit will be refunded, but should the meter register less than
AWWA meter test standards, latest revision, LCUD will retain the deposit.
   D.   Adjustment For Meter Errors; Fast Meters: If a meter tested at the
request of a customer is found to be faster than AWWA standards, the charges in
excess of AWWA standards for a period not to exceed six (6) months shall be
refunded to the customer.
   E.   Adjustment For Meter Errors; Slow Meters: If a meter tested is found to
be slower than AWWA standards, LCUD may bill the customer for the amount of the
undercharge based upon corrected meter readings for the period, not exceeding
six (6) months that the meter was in use.
   F.   Nonregistering Meters: If a meter is found to be not registering, the
charges for service shall be at the minimum monthly rate or based on the
estimated consumption, whichever is greater. Such estimates shall be made from
previous consumption for a comparable period or by such other method as is
determined by LCUD. (Ord. 504, 1-18-2007)
9.03.09: BILLING:
   A.   Billing Period: The regular billing period will be at the discretion of
LCUD.
   B.   Meter Reading: Meters shall be read as nearly as possible on the same
day of each billing period. (Ord. 504, 1-18-2007)
   C.   Opening And Closing Bills: Opening and closing bills for less than the
normal billing period will be prorated for the number of days in the month for
which service is provided based on the meter size plus any water used in excess
of five thousand (5,000) gallons' base use amount. (Ord. 568, 7-3-2014)
   D.   Billing Time: Bills for the base rate and for consumption over the
minimum are billed in arrears.
   E.   Penalties: All charges shall become due and payable upon presentation.
Payments not received by the due date listed on the bill shall become
delinquent on the next business day after the due date. All charges which
become delinquent shall be subject to a penalty of ten percent (10%) for the
first month delinquent. Customers' payments shall be applied to their oldest
balances due, including penalties, first.
   F.   Delinquent Charges Collected On Tax Rolls:
      1.   The purpose of this subsection is to adopt an ordinance authorized
by Nevada Revised Statutes 244.36605 to have delinquent charges for water and/
or sewer service placed on the tax roll in the same manner, by the same
persons, and at the same time as, together with and not separately from, Lyon
County's general taxes.
      2.   The utilities department shall cause a description of each parcel of
real property with respect to which a water service charge is delinquent on May
1 and the amount of the delinquent charge to be prepared and submitted to the
county clerk/treasurer no later than June 1. The description of each parcel and
the amount of the delinquent charge must be submitted in a form approved by the
county clerk/treasurer.
      3.   The amount of the charge which is delinquent constitutes a lien
against the lot or parcel of land against which the charge has been imposed as
of the time when the lien of taxes attaches.
      4.   The county clerk/treasurer shall include the amount of the charges
on bills for taxes levied against the respective lots and parcels of land.
      5.   Thereafter the amount of the charges must be collected at the same
time and in the same manner and by the same persons as, together with and not
separately from, the general taxes for the county.
      6.   All laws applicable to the levy, collection and enforcement of
general taxes of the county, including, but not limited to, those pertaining to
the matters of delinquency, correction, cancellation, refund, redemption and
sale, are applicable to delinquent charges for water and/or sewer.
      7.   The county clerk/treasurer may issue separate bills for those
charges and separate receipts for collection on account of those charges.
   G.   Protests To Rates And Charges: If any owner shall be dissatisfied with
any water charge imposed, he may file a written protest with the utilities
director setting forth his/her objections provided such protest is filed within
fifteen (15) working days of receipt of the bill being protested.
   Upon receipt of any such protest, the director shall, within fifteen (15)
working days, make a determination in writing as to the correctness of the
bill. Should the director determine that the bill was incorrect, he/she may
cause the corrections to be made.
   If the owner is not satisfied with the utilities director's decision, the
owner may appeal that decision to the county manager in writing within five (5)
working days. The county manager shall, within fifteen (15) working days, make
a determination in writing.
   If the protester is dissatisfied with the county manager's decision, he/she
may appeal to the board, provided such written appeal is filed within ten (10)
days of receipt of the county manager's decision.
   The board, upon receipt of a protest, shall fix a time and place for a
hearing of said protest which shall not be later than thirty (30) calendar days
after receipt of same and cause the protesters to be notified thereof.
   Upon the hearing, the board may adjust the water charge if it is satisfied
with the reasons and basis of the protest. Action taken on any protest shall be
entered in the minutes of the board.
   The protester shall have fifteen (15) calendar days after determination of
the protest by the board within which to pay his/her water charge before any
penalty or interest shall be attached or imposed, notwithstanding any other
provision of this chapter concerning the imposition of penalty and interest
charges.
   H.   Represents Lien On Property: Until paid, all rates, tolls and charges
provided in this chapter constitute a perpetual lien on and against the
property served and may be foreclosed upon as provided by law.
   I.   Billing Of Separate Meters Not Combined: Separate bills will be
rendered for each meter installation except where LCUD has, for its own
convenience, installed two (2) or more meters in place of one meter. Where such
installations are made, the meter readings may be combined for billing
purposes.
   J.   Owner's Guarantee: Before water is turned on by LCUD for any purpose,
the property owner must sign the application form as provided by LCUD in which
he guarantees payment of future water bills for the service required. The
property owner signing the owner application for utility service form will be
held liable for the appropriate fee for water service until LCUD is notified in
writing to remove the meter or transfer the account to another property owner.
The owner may assign an agent that the bill will be mailed to, however the
owner will ultimately be responsible for all payments.
   At LCUD's discretion, service may be established verbally, but must be
followed up with an application form completed by the owner or agent within
ninety (90) days of request for service.
   K.   Water Used Without Application Being Made: An owner taking possession
of premises and using water from an active service connection without having
made application to LCUD for water service shall be held liable for the water
delivered from the date of the last recorded meter reading, and if the meter is
found inoperative, the quantity consumed will be estimated. If proper
application for water service is not made within a period of time specified by
LCUD, and if accumulated bills for service are not paid immediately, the
service may be discontinued by LCUD without further notice.
   L.   Damages Through Leaking Pipes And Fixtures: Owner or owner's agent must
be present at the property at the time scheduled for LCUD to turn on the water
service. LCUD will in no case be liable for damages caused by water leaking or
running from open or faulty fixtures, or from broken or damaged pipes or any
other appurtenances within or outside of the building structure. (Ord. 504, 1-
18-2007)
   M.   Policy For Appeal For Relief From Excessive Water Charges: When
customers, through no fault of their own, have incurred excessively high water
bills due to freezing or breaking of water lines or other unavoidable
circumstances, and the detection and correction of such a break could not have
reasonably been accomplished in time to avoid the excessive water usage, the
following policy shall apply. Leaving water running unattended does not qualify
for relief.
   An LCUD water customer who has an uncontrollable loss of water that results
in an excess of one hundred twenty five dollars ($125.00) above the previous
year's bill for the same period, may apply to LCUD for relief under this
policy. The utilities director will review the matter and determine if the high
overage was a result of an undetectable condition and was not a result of
negligence or inattention of the property owner. Upon such a determination,
LCUD will credit the overage charge in excess of one hundred twenty five
dollars ($125.00). This adjustment will only be allowed one time per parcel
within a twenty four (24) month period. The owner may be required to replace
plumbing in order to qualify for future relief. The utilities director may use
other means necessary in determining average water usage. Relief will only be
considered for one billing period. (Ord. 568, 7-3-2014)
   N.   Checks And Electronic Funds Transfers Not Honored By Bank: Checks and
electronic funds transfers presented in payment of bills that are returned by a
bank shall be treated as though no payment had been made, and an administrative
charge will be levied by LCUD, plus any additional charges received from the
bank. The customer must reimburse LCUD for any returned check/electronic funds
transfer fees charged by a bank to LCUD.
   O.   Collection By Suit:
      1.   Suit: As an alternative to any of the other procedures herein
provided, all unpaid rates and charges and penalties herein provided may be
collected by suit. As an additional procedure, LCUD shall have all rights as
provided by law.
      2.   Costs: Defendant shall pay all costs of suit in any judgment
rendered in favor of LCUD, including a reasonable attorney fee.
   P.   Collection With Other Utility Charges:
      1.   With Utility Charges Of LCUD: Where the person charged is a user of
another utility owned and operated by LCUD, the charges may be collected
together with and not separately from the charges for the other utility service
rendered by it. They may be billed upon the same bill and collected as one item
at the discretion of LCUD.
      2.   Discontinuance Of Service Upon Delinquency: Upon delinquency, the
other utility service may be discontinued until full payment of the dual
charges and penalties and associated fees are paid in full. At the discretion
of LCUD the delinquent charges may be added to the property tax rolls.
   Q.   Service Rates:
      1.   Rates: For all users within LCUD, rates established by the board
shall apply.
         a. Monthly Charges: For all monthly water consumption of five thousand
(5,000) gallons or less, the minimum charge as established by the board shall
apply. For all consumption in excess of five thousand (5,000) gallons in any
month, a charge according to the unit cost established by the board shall
apply.
         b. Fire Protection: Public and private fire protection systems shall
be charged the following monthly rates:
            (1) Public fire protection rates shall be billed to the responsible
fire protection agencies at the rate determined in the contract between LCUD
and the fire protection agency.
            (2) Private fire protection systems shall be billed monthly to the
property owner or association of property owners at the rate established by the
board.
      2.   Multi-Unit Residential Accounts: The base charge for multi-unit
residential accounts using common meters shall be determined by the base charge
based on meter size. The excess charge for multi-unit residential accounts
using common meters shall apply to usage exceeding five thousand (5,000)
gallons per month.
      3.   Bulk Water For Construction: Where water is used for construction
and obtained from a fire hydrant or other location approved by LCUD, the volume
used will be billed on a per one thousand (1,000) gallon rate established by
the board plus a rental fee and any additional time or material costs
associated with the hydrant meter setup.
      4.   Call Out Service Charges: A customer requesting LCUD assistance with
customer related water issues, i.e., interior water leak, problem with
irrigation system, water shutoff at meter (because customer cannot locate their
own shutoff valve, etc.), may be billed a service call charge, at the
discretion of the utilities director. (Ord. 504, 1-18-2007)
      5.   Source Water Impact Fee: A service charge may be imposed for
stormwater planning, capital improvements, maintenance and repair of stormwater
collection and detention systems in order to protect groundwater quality within
the LCUD water service area. (Ord. 568, 7-3-2014)
9.03.10: DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE:
   A.   For Nonpayment Of Bills When Not Collected On Tax Rolls: A customer's
service may be discontinued for nonpayment of a bill for service furnished if
the account becomes delinquent, provided LCUD has given the customer at least
two (2) days' prior written notice of such intention.
   B.   Liability For Bills: Failure to receive a water bill does not relieve
consumer or owner of liability. Any amount due shall be deemed a debt to LCUD,
and any person, firm, or corporation failing, neglecting or refusing to pay
said indebtedness shall be liable to an action in the name of LCUD in any court
of competent jurisdiction for the amount thereof.
   C.   Resumption Of Service Charge: Where service has been discontinued for
violation of these rules or for nonpayment of bills, the cost of discontinuing
and resuming service shall be at the expense of the customer or owner.
      1.   Made During Regular Business Hours: LCUD will endeavor to resume
service during regular business hours on the day of the request, if conditions
permit; otherwise, LCUD will endeavor to resume service on the next regular
business day following the day the request is made.
      2.   Made At Other Than Regular Business Hours: When a customer has
requested that the service be resumed at a time outside of regular business
hours, LCUD will reasonably endeavor to resume service if practicable under the
circumstances but will be under no obligation to do so, unless an emergency
exists. A charge based on costs, including overtime rates, shall be billed to
the customer for services rendered outside of regular business hours.
      3.   Presence Of Owner Or Authorized Representative: During requested
resumption of service, the owner or their authorized representative is required
to be on site. (Ord. 504, 1-18-2007)
   D.   Unsafe Apparatus: Water service may be refused or immediately
discontinued to any premises where apparatus or appliances are in use which
might endanger or disrupt the service to other customers in any way. Where
service has been disconnected due to an unsafe apparatus, all costs associated
with investigating, discontinuing and resuming service shall be at the expense
of the customer. (Ord. 568, 7-3-2014)
   E.   Cross Connections: Water service may be refused or discontinued to any
premises where a cross connection exists that is in violation of this chapter
or state, federal or local laws.
   F.   Fraud Or Abuse: Service may be immediately discontinued if necessary to
protect LCUD against fraud or abuse.
   G.   For Noncompliance With Rules: LCUD may discontinue service to any
customer for violation of these rules after it has given the customer at least
five (5) days' written notice of such intention. In case of emergency,
unauthorized use, water waste, or where safety of water supply is endangered,
service may be discontinued or curtailed immediately without notice, in
addition to any other penalties provided by law and these regulations.
   H.   Abatement: During the period of discontinuance of service, habitation
of such premises by human beings shall constitute a public nuisance, whereupon
the county manager shall cause proceedings to be brought for the abatement of
the occupancy of said premises by human beings. In such event, a reasonable
attorney fee shall become due as a penalty for nonpayment.
   I.   Customer's Request For Discontinuance Of Service: A customer may have
service discontinued by giving not less than two (2) working days' advance
notice, in writing, to LCUD. Water base rates shall only be ceased for
"seasonal offs" lasting more than one billing period. Base fees for partial
months in seasonal off status will not be prorated. When the water is turned
back on, either the owner or agent must be present or the owner must provide
LCUD with written authorization to resume service without an owner
representative being present. LCUD will not be responsible for damage caused
from leaking or damaged plumbing.
   J.   Charges For Discontinuing And Resuming Service: Charges shall be made
for discontinuing and resuming service, as determined by the board.
      1.   When a discontinuance or resumption of service is made at other than
regular business hours, the charge for that service shall be actual cost to
LCUD, or at the rate established by the board.
      2.   If the use of equipment is necessary in discontinuing or resuming a
service, the customer shall be billed at an hourly rate on a time and materials
basis, in addition to the charge for the discontinuance or resumption of
service.
      3.   Service shall be considered to be disconnected when an employee of
LCUD has been dispatched for that purpose, and the rates, as established by the
board, will apply.
      4.   If an unauthorized connection is made to a public water system, the
owner or applicant will be charged a fee on a time and materials basis
associated with disconnection. Jumpers will be confiscated by LCUD and the
owner or person making the connection may be prosecuted under Nevada Revised
Statutes 704.800.
   K.   Reserved. (Ord. 504, 1-18-2007)
9.03.11: PUBLIC FIRE PROTECTION:
   A.   Use Of Fire Hydrants: Fire hydrants are for use by LCUD or by organized
fire protection agencies pursuant to contract with LCUD. Other parties desiring
to use fire hydrants for any purpose must first obtain written permission from
LCUD prior to use and shall operate the hydrant in accordance with instructions
issued by LCUD. Unauthorized use of hydrants will be prosecuted according to
law.
   B.   Hydrant Rental: A charge, to be determined by contract between LCUD and
organized fire protection agencies, will be imposed for hydrant maintenance and
water used for public fire protection.
   C.   Moving Of Fire Hydrants: When a fire hydrant has been installed in the
location specified by the proper authority, LCUD has fulfilled its obligation.
If a property owner or other party desires a change in the size, type or
location of the hydrant, he shall bear all costs of such changes, without
refund. Any change in the location of a fire hydrant must be approved by LCUD
and the appropriate fire protection district. (Ord. 504, 1-18-2007)
9.03.12: PRIVATE FIRE PROTECTION SERVICE:
   A.   Payment Of Cost: The applicant for private fire protection service
shall pay the total actual cost of installation of the service from the
distribution main to the customer's premises to meet the requirements of LCUD
and the appropriate fire protection district. Requirements of LCUD include, but
are not limited to, detector check meter, meter box, backflow device, hotbox,
vault, valve and valve box, and construction materials acceptable to LCUD.
   B.   No Connection To Other System: There shall be no connection between the
fire protection system and any other water distribution system on the premises.
   C.   Use: There shall be no water used through the fire protection service
except to extinguish fires and for testing the firefighting equipment.
   D.   Rates: The monthly rates for private fire protection shall be
established by the board.
   E.   Water Used For Firefighting Not To Be Charged For: In those instances
wherein private fire protection is provided from a metered domestic water or
fire service line, the volume of water used for firefighting will be estimated
and that estimated volume shall be deducted from the water bill for that
billing period.
   F.   Water For Fire Storage Tanks: Occasionally water may be obtained from a
private fire service for filling a tank connected with the fire service, but
only if written permission is secured from LCUD in advance and an approved
means of measurement and backflow protection are available. The regular water
rates will be applied.
   G.   Violation Of Agreement: If water is used from a private fire service in
violation of the agreement or these regulations, LCUD may, at its option,
discontinue and remove the service at owner's expense and charge a fee for the
volume used.
   H.   Water Pressure And Supply: LCUD assumes no responsibility for loss or
damage due to lack of water or pressure, either high or low, and merely agrees
to furnish such quantities and pressures as are available in its general
distribution system. The fire service is subject to shutdowns and variations
required by the operation of the distribution system.
   I.   Rules: The following rules shall apply to fire service connection:
      1.   Additional Service: LCUD shall have the right to take a domestic,
commercial or industrial service connection from the fire service connection at
the curb to supply the same premises as those to which the fire service
connection belongs. LCUD shall charge all fees associated with each service
connection.
      2.   Backflow Prevention: LCUD reserves the right to require installation
of an approved backflow prevention assembly. (Ord. 504, 1-18-2007)
9.03.13: TEMPORARY SERVICE:
   A.   Duration Of Service: Temporary service connections shall be
disconnected and terminated within six (6) months after installation unless an
extension of time is granted in writing by LCUD.
   B.   Deposit: The applicant may be required to deposit, in advance, the
estimated cost of installing and removing the facilities required to furnish
said service.
   C.   Installation And Operation: All facilities for temporary service to the
customer connection shall be inspected by LCUD and shall be operated in
accordance with its instructions.
   D.   Responsibility For Meters And Installations: The customer shall use all
possible care to prevent damage to the meter or to any other loaned facilities
of LCUD which are involved in furnishing the temporary service from the time
they are installed until they are removed. If the meter or other facilities are
damaged, the cost of making repairs shall be paid by the customer. If water is
supplied to the property through an existing water meter, no permission will be
granted to use water from a fire hydrant. If application has been made for
water connection services, the customer must arrange to make water connection
in a timely manner to avoid use of the fire hydrant.
   E.   Supply From Fire Hydrant: An applicant for temporary use of water from
a fire hydrant must secure a permit, as provided in subsection 9.03.11A of this
chapter, therefor from LCUD and pay a deposit equal to the replacement value of
the meter assembly, the regular rental fee charged for the use of a meter to be
installed on said hydrant; provide a hydrant wrench necessary to operate such
hydrant, and pay for the water used in accordance with the meter readings, at
the rates established by the board. Applicant must call in meter readings to
LCUD billing staff on a monthly basis or be charged a service fee based on a
time and materials basis for LCUD to obtain the meter reading.
   F.   Unauthorized Use Of Hydrants: Tampering with any fire hydrant for the
unauthorized use of water therefrom, or for any other purpose, is a
misdemeanor, punishable by law. (Ord. 504, 1-18-2007)
9.03.14: PUBLIC AND PRIVATE WATER SYSTEM CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall construct, extend, or connect to any
public water system without first obtaining a written permit from LCUD and
paying all fees and connection charges and furnishing bonds as required. The
provision of this section requiring permits shall not be construed to apply to
contractors constructing water systems and appurtenances under contracts
awarded and entered into by LCUD.
   B.   Plans, Profiles And Specifications Required: The application for a
permit for public water system construction shall be accompanied by complete
plans, profiles and specifications, complying with all applicable ordinances,
rules and regulations of LCUD, prepared by a professional engineer registered
in the state of Nevada, showing all details of the proposed work based on an
accurate survey of the ground. The application, together with the plans,
profiles and specifications, shall be examined by LCUD and LCUD shall approve
them as filed or require them to be modified as deemed necessary for proper
installation.
   C.   Easements Or Rights Of Way: In the event that an easement is required
for the extension of the public water system or the making of connections, the
applicant shall procure a proper easement or grant of right of way sufficient
in law to allow the construction and operation of such extension, facility or
connection. Easements or rights of way are reserved for the servicing of
utilities, and no structure or building shall be placed within or over
easements or rights of way, nor shall these areas be occupied or used in any
manner as to restrict or deny access for repairs or maintenance, and all costs
of removing or replacing land surfaces, landscaping or other occupancies shall
be charged to the property owner.
   D.   Persons Authorized To Perform Work: Only properly licensed contractors
shall be authorized to perform the work of public water system construction
within LCUD. LCUD will not accept dedication of any public water system, or
portions thereof, unless the construction has been performed by the holder of a
class A contractor's license issued by the Nevada state contractors board. All
terms and conditions of the permit issued by LCUD to the applicant shall be
binding on the contractor.
   E.   Compliance With Local Regulations: Any person constructing a water
system within a street shall comply with all state, county, or city laws,
ordinances, rules, and regulations pertaining to the cutting of pavement,
opening, barricading, lighting and protecting of trenches, backfilling and
repaving thereof, and shall obtain all permits and pay all fees required by the
department having jurisdiction, prior to starting any work.
   F.   Protection Of Excavation: The applicant shall maintain such barriers,
lights and signs as are necessary to give warning to the public at all times
that a water system is under construction and of each dangerous condition to be
encountered as a result thereof. He shall also likewise protect the public in
the use of the sidewalk against any such conditions in connection with the
construction of the water system. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other
property disturbed in the course of the work shall be reinstalled in a manner
satisfactory to LCUD or any other entity having jurisdiction.
   G.   Design And Construction Standard: Minimum standards for the design and
construction of water systems within LCUD shall be in accordance with the
standard specifications for Lyon County water, sewer, as adopted by the board,
copies of which are on file in the LCUD office and in accordance with NAC445A
and as approved by NDEP - bureau of safe drinking water.
   Reproducible "record" drawings, stamped and prepared by a professional
engineer registered in the state of Nevada, showing the actual location of all
mains, service connections, hydrants, valves and appurtenances, shall be filed
with LCUD before final acceptance of the work. LCUD may accept and/or require
specific electronic versions of record drawings.
   H.   Completion Of Water System Required: Before any acceptance of any water
infrastructure by LCUD, the infrastructure shall be tested and shall be
complete and in full compliance with all requirements of LCUD and the state of
Nevada. (Ord. 504, 1-18-2007)
9.03.15: BACKFLOW AND CROSS CONNECTION REGULATIONS:
   A.   General Policy:
      1.   Purpose: The purpose of this section is:
         a.   To protect any public potable water supply of LCUD from the
possibility of contamination or pollution by isolating within the customer's
internal distribution system or the customer's private water system such
contaminants or pollutants which could backflow into the public water systems;
and
         b.   To promote the elimination or control of existing cross
connections, actual or potential, between the consumer's potable water system
and nonpotable water system, plumbing fixtures and industrial piping systems;
and
         c.   To provide for the maintenance of a continuing cross connection
control program that will systematically and effectively prevent the
contamination or pollution of all potable water systems within the jurisdiction
of LCUD. This program shall also meet the requirements of the safe drinking
water act amendments of 1986, public law 99-339, Nevada administrative code
sections 445A.67185 through 67255, uniform plumbing code, meet all of the
laboratory and field performance specifications of the Foundation for Cross-
Connection Control and Hydraulic Research of the University of Southern
California (hereinafter referred to as foundation), and the American Water
Works Association manual M14 with AWWA C506-84 Standards for Reduced Pressure
Principle and Double Check Valve Backflow Prevention Devices, including any
existing or future amendments.
      2.   Responsibility: The utilities director, or his designee, shall be
responsible for the protection of the public potable water system from
contamination or pollution due to the backflow of contaminants or pollutants
through the water service connection. If, in the judgment of said utilities
director, an approved backflow prevention assembly is required at the
customer's water service connection, or within the customer's private water
system, the utilities director or his designated agent shall give notice in
writing to said customer to install such an approved assembly(ies) at specific
locations on the customer's premises. Immediately upon receipt of the notice,
the customer shall install such assembly at the customer's sole expense.
Failure or refusal on the part of the consumer to make such installation and to
have such tested yearly or as required by LCUD by a certified CA/NV section
American Water Works Association (AWWA) tester and/or tester/agent approved by
LCUD's backflow administrator and maintained in good working order shall
constitute grounds for discontinuing water service to the premises until such
requirements have been satisfactorily met.
      3.   Nonliability Of LCUD: LCUD shall not be responsible for any loss or
damage directly or indirectly resulting from or caused by the proper, improper,
or negligent installation, operation, use, repair, or maintenance of, or
interfering with, any protective device by any customer of LCUD or any other
person.
      4.   Shared Responsibility: Customers must share in the responsibility
for the protection of the potable water system. Customers must maintain their
water piping system so that pollutants do not backflow into LCUD's water mains.
It is also the customer's responsibility to report any possible hazard that may
affect LCUD's water mains. Reports should be made to the utilities director as
soon as a hazard is detected.
   B.   Backflow Definitions:
   APPROVED: Accepted by LCUD utilities director as meeting an applicable
specification contained in this chapter, or as suitable for the proposed use.
   AUXILIARY WATER SUPPLY: Any water supply on or available to the premises
other than LCUD's approved public water supply and which is within LCUD's water
service area shall constitute an auxiliary water supply.
   APPROVED BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICES: An assembly or means to prevent
backflow that has been manufactured, tested and approved in conformance with
the foundation.
   BACKFLOW: The reversal of normal flow of water caused by either back
pressure or back siphoning.
   CONTAMINATION: An impairment of the quality of the potable water by
materials to a degree which creates an actual or potential hazard to the public
health.
   CROSS CONNECTION: Any physical connection or arrangement of piping or
fixtures between two (2) otherwise separate piping systems, one of which
contains potable water and the other nonpotable water or industrial fluids of
questionable safety, through which, or because of which backflow may occur into
the potable water system.
   HAZARD, DEGREE OF: The term is derived from an evaluation of the potential
risk to public health and the adverse effect of the hazard upon the potable
water system.
    Hazard, Health: Any condition, device, or practice in the water supply
system and its operation which could create or may create a danger to the
health and well being of the water consumer.
    Hazard, Pollution: An actual or potential threat to the physical properties
of the water system or the consumer's potable water system, which constitutes a
nuisance or is aesthetically objectionable or could cause damage to the system
or its appurtenances, but which is not dangerous to human health. (Ord. 504, 1-
18-2007) !DEFEND!
   C.   Requirements:
      1.   Policy:
         a.   No water service connection to any premises shall be installed or
maintained by LCUD unless the water supply is protected as required by state
laws and regulations and section 9.07.04 of this title. Service of water to any
premises shall be discontinued by LCUD if a backflow prevention assembly has
been removed, bypassed, or if an unprotected cross connection exists on the
premises. Service will not be restored until such conditions or defects are
corrected. (Ord. 568, 7-3-2014)
         b.   The customer's system shall be open for inspection at all
reasonable times to authorized representatives of LCUD to determine whether
cross connections or other structural or sanitary hazards exist. When such a
hazard becomes known, the utilities director may deny or discontinue service to
the premises by providing for a physical break in the service line until the
customer has corrected the condition(s) in conformance with state law and local
ordinances relating to plumbing and water supplies and any regulations adopted
pursuant thereto.
         c.   An approved backflow preventer shall be installed on each service
line to a customer's water system at or near the property line or immediately
inside the building being served; but, in all cases, before the first branch
line leading off the service line, wherever the following conditions exist:
            (1) In the case of premises having an auxiliary water supply that
is not acceptable as an additional source, the public water system shall be
protected by installing an approved backflow preventer in the service line
appropriate to the degree of hazard.
            (2) In the case of premises on which any industrial fluids or any
other objectionable substance is handled in such a fashion as to create an
actual or potential hazard to the public water system, the public system shall
be protected against backflow from the premises by installing an approved
backflow preventer in the service line appropriate to the degree of hazard.
            (3) In the case of premises having: a) an internal cross connection
that cannot be permanently corrected or controlled, or b) intricate plumbing
and piping arrangements or where entry to all portions of the premises is not
readily accessible for inspection purposes, making it impracticable or
impossible to ascertain whether or not dangerous cross connections exist, the
public water system shall be protected by installing an approved backflow
preventer in the service line at the owner's expense.
            (4) Any customer wishing to fill water trucks or other equipment
shall fill out an LCUD application for service and have that equipment
inspected and approved by a representative of LCUD. An approved air gap must be
installed before filling from the potable water supply. Violation of this
section shall result in discontinuance of service and a charge on a time and
materials basis for any corrective action needed.
      2.   Type Of Backflow Preventer: The type of backflow preventer required
shall depend upon the degree of hazard which exists as follows:
         a.   Where there is an auxiliary water system, a minimum of a reduced
pressure principle assembly will be required.
         b.   Where there is any pollution hazard, the public water system
shall be protected with a minimum of an approved double check valve assembly.
         c.   Where there is any health hazard, the public water system shall
be protected by an approved air gap or an approved reduced pressure principle
assembly. Hospitals, sewage treatment plants and structures with chemical
additives in fire sprinkler systems are examples of these type premises.
         d.   Where access is denied or is impossible or impractical to make a
cross connection survey, the public water supply shall be protected with an
approved air gap or an approved reduced pressure principle assembly.
      3.   Approval Required: Any backflow preventer required herein shall be a
model and size approved by the utilities director. Any below grade applications
must be approved by LCUD prior to installation.
      4.   Inspections:
         a.   It shall be the joint duty of LCUD and the customer at any
premises where backflow prevention assemblies are installed to have certified
inspections and operational tests made upon installation and at least once a
year thereafter, or as determined necessary by the LCUD. In those instances
where utilities director deems the hazard to be great enough, more frequent
tests may be required. All cross connection surveys and tests shall be
performed by CA/NV AWWA certified technicians preapproved by LCUD. The customer
shall bear the cost of the inspection, repairs and testing. Records of testing
and repairs shall be kept by LCUD when said work is completed.
         b.   All industrial, commercial, residential, multi-residential and
all other properties with backflow devices installed and requiring testing
according to this chapter shall provide access upon request to any authorized
representative of LCUD to perform such testing or provide acceptable test
results to LCUD from a CA/NV AWWA certified backflow tester, preapproved by
LCUD's utilities director, of the customer's choice.
      5.   Charges For Backflow Testing: Charges for backflow testing/repairs
performed by LCUD shall be a minimum rate, or actual cost, labor and materials,
as established by the board.
      6.   Exclusions: All presently installed backflow prevention assemblies
which do not meet the requirements of this section, but which were approved
devices for the purposes described herein at the time of installation and which
have been properly maintained, shall, except for the inspection and maintenance
requirements, be excluded from the requirements of these rules so long as the
utilities director is satisfied that they will protect the public water system.
Whenever such device is moved, removed, or requires more than minimum
maintenance or when LCUD finds that the maintenance constitutes a hazard to
health, the unit shall be replaced by an approved backflow prevention assembly
meeting the requirements of this section. Any plumbing improvements requiring a
building permit will require that the rules of this chapter be observed. (Ord.
504, 1-18-2007)
9.03.16: WATER CONSERVATION REQUIRED:
When in the opinion of the board of commissioners circumstances require water
conservation by LCUD customers, the board of commissioners may impose one or
more of the following conditions after consideration of those circumstances at
a regular public hearing after notice to the customers as provided for in
Nevada law or at an emergency meeting conducted by the board.
Routine conservation does not require special board action and is observed
annually from June 1 through October 1 of each year.
   A.   Routine Conservation:
      1.   Restrict watering to odd and even days depending on service address.
There is no restriction to hand watering or washing cars using hoses with self-
closing nozzles.
         a.   Watering is not allowed between the hours of ten o'clock (10:00)
A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M.
         b.   No outside watering on the thirty first day of a month.
         c.   No outside watering when it is windy.
      2.   Exempted from this section are the following:
         a.   Nevada licensed commercial gardeners or caretakers who are on the
premises at the time watering is taking place;
         b.   Vegetable gardens, flowerbeds, trees within two (2) months of
planting;
         c.   New lawns including sod, for twenty one (21) days from planting
or installation date, that have been planted prior to June 15 or after August
15;
         d.   Complexes that file for and receive approval of an irrigation
plan.
         e.   Residential customers adjusting and repairing their irrigation
system during the nonwatering times for a not to exceed time frame of one hour.
         f.   Special exemptions from this section may be granted by the
utilities director or his/her designee on a case by case basis based on a
determination that the special request shall not be detrimental to the public
water system or supply. A customer requesting an exemption must submit a
written request to LCUD.
      3.   No excess water running down impervious surfaces or on to other
property that may cause damage or as described in subsection 9.03.07B of this
chapter.
   B.   Moderate Conservation:
      1.   All items under subsection A, "Routine Conservation", of this
section.
      2.   Restrict landscape irrigation to more restrictive schedule such as
no watering on Mondays or watering only twice a week.
      3.   Limit use of water from fire hydrants to actual firefighting use.
      4.   Prohibit wash down of driveways, sidewalks, parking lots and other
impervious surfaces.
   C.   Strict Conservation:
      1.   All items under subsection B, "Moderate Conservation", of this
section.
      2.   No landscape or lawn irrigation under any circumstances.
      3.   No new lawn or landscape installation.
      4.   No wash down of automobiles, trucks, vans or other motorized
equipment except at commercial washing facilities that recycle wash water.
      5.   Impose an excess consumption charge of three hundred percent (300%)
of the existing rate per one thousand (1,000) gallons for water use in excess
of one hundred fifty percent (150%) of the base amount. The director may make
arrangements on a case by case basis but must report the arrangements to the
board through the county manager.
   D.   Circumstances Under Which Moderate Or Strict Conservation May Be
Required: The board of commissioners, upon its findings that one or more of the
following emergency conditions are present, may impose moderate or strict
conservation measures:
      1.   Water scarcity condition exists or is likely to exist.
      2.   Failure of water production, storage or distribution system(s).
      3.   Demand for service in excess of LCUD's authorized water rights.
      4.   Order of any agency of the federal, state or local government having
jurisdiction in such matters.
      5.   Any other condition that may require such action.
   E.   Penalties: As a condition of service, any person who violates any of
the provisions of subsection 9.03.07B of this chapter, subsections A, B and C
of this section, will be assessed as follows:
      1.   For the first offense, issuance of a verbal warning;
      2.   For the second offense, issuance of a written warning both posted
and mailed;
      3.   For the third through seventh offense, a fee assessment established
by the board;
      4.   For the eighth offense and subsequent offenses, the installation of
a flow restriction device and a service fee on a time and materials basis to
cover the installation cost.
   Fee assessments shall be added to the owner's or agent's monthly utility
bill. Owners or agents shall be notified of the fee assessment through
certified mail within seven (7) days of the observed violation. Protests shall
be handled as provided for in subsections 9.03.01K through M and 9.03.09G of
this chapter. (Ord. 504, 1-18-2007)

9.05.01: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   Short Title: This chapter may be cited as LYON COUNTY UTILITIES SEWER
ORDINANCE.
   B.   Enabling Statutes: This chapter is adopted pursuant to Nevada Revised
Statutes.
   C.   Enterprise: The county will furnish a system, plant, works and
undertaking used for and useful in the collection, treatment and disposal of
domestic wastewater and industrial waste for the various LCUD service areas,
including all parts of the enterprise, all appurtenances thereto, and lands,
easements, rights in land, contract rights and franchises.
   D.   Separability: If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of
this chapter or the application thereof to any person or circumstances is for
any reason held to be unconstitutional or invalid, such decision shall not
affect the validity of the remaining portions of this chapter or the
application of such provision to other persons or circumstances. The board
hereby declares that it would have passed this chapter or any section,
subsection, sentence, clause or phrase hereof irrespective of the fact that any
one or more sections, subsections, sentences, clauses or phrases be declared to
be unconstitutional.
   E.   Posting: The adoption of this chapter shall be entered in the minutes
of the board and certified copies hereof shall be posted in accordance with the
state of Nevada open meeting law, Nevada Revised Statutes 241, section 020,
pertaining to posting requirements.
   F.   Relief Of Application: When any person, by reason of special
circumstances, is of the opinion that any provision of this chapter is unjust
or inequitable as applied to his premises, he may make written application to
the board stating the special circumstances, citing the provision complained
of, and requesting suspension or modification of that provision as applied to
his premises.
If such application be approved, the board may, by resolution, suspend or
modify the provision complained of, as applied to such premises, to be
effective as of the date of the application and continuing during the period of
the special circumstances. This decision shall not violate Nevada department of
environmental protection, federal or state regulations.
   G.   Relief Of Own Motion: The board may, on its own motion, find that by
reason of special circumstances any provision of this regulation and chapter
should be suspended or modified as applied to a particular premises during the
period of such special circumstances or any part thereof.
   H.   Violations And Penalties:
      1.   Violations: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation
to erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, improve, remove, convert,
demolish, equip, use, or maintain any plumbing or permit the same to be done in
violation of this chapter.
      2.   Penalties: Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision
of this chapter shall be penalized in accordance with the provisions of the
applicable county ordinance or resolutions or applicable laws. Each separate
day or any portion thereof during which any violation of this chapter occurs or
continues shall be deemed to constitute a separate offense.
   I.   Ruling Final: All rulings of the board shall be final. All rulings of
the county manager shall be final unless appealed in writing to the board
within ten (10) working days. When appealed, the board's ruling shall be final.
(Ord. 507, 1-18-2007)
9.05.02: DEFINITIONS:
ADDITIONAL DEFINITIONS: For the purpose of this chapter, additional terms not
specifically defined herein shall have the meaning indicated in chapter 1 of
the most recently adopted edition of the plumbing code entitled "uniform
plumbing code" (UPC), compiled by the International Association of Plumbing and
Mechanical Officials, copies of which are on file with the LCUD.
AGENT: A person or firm, corporation, partnership or association duly
authorized with supporting documentation to complete requirements and
performances of this chapter.
APPLICANT: The person making permit application for a sewer or plumbing
installation and shall be the record owner of premises to be served by the
sewer for which a permit is requested or his authorized agent.
APPLICATION: A written request for sewer service as distinguished from an
inquiry as to the availability or charges for such services.
BILLING PERIOD: The regular billing period will be monthly, or at the
discretion of the board.
BOARD: The Lyon County board of commissioners.
BUILDING: A structure built, erected, and framed of component structural parts
designed for the housing, shelter, enclosure, or support of persons, animals,
or property of any kind.
BUILDING SEWER: That privately maintained part of the horizontal piping of a
drainage system which extends three feet (3') outside the foundation from the
end of the building drain and which receives the discharge of the building
drain and conveys it to a public sewer, private sewer delivery system, or other
point of disposal.
COMBINED SEWER: A sewer which conveys both sewage and storm water or other
drainage.
COMMERCIAL UNIT: Any building, structure, or facility or a portion thereof,
devoted to the purposes of trade or commerce, such as a store or office
building.
COMMUNAL SEWER: A sewer serving any multi-unit property and is considered a
private sewer system and not properly controlled by or under the jurisdiction
of the county.
CONTRACTOR (AGENT): An individual, firm, corporation, partnership or
association duly licensed by the state of Nevada to perform the type of work to
be done under the permit.
COUNTY: The county of Lyon, Nevada.
COUNTY ENGINEER: The engineer appointed and acting for the LCUD and shall be a
registered civil engineer in the state of Nevada.
COUNTY MANAGER: The manager of Lyon County.
CUSTOMER: In the case of single-family or multiple-family residences, the
customer shall be the owner of the property served, but the billing for service
may be sent to the owner in care of his agent or renter. For commercial
services, the person in whose name service is rendered, as evidenced by the
signature on the application or contract for that service, or in the absence of
a signed instrument, by the receipt and payment of bills regularly issued in
his name regardless of the identity of the actual user of the service.
DATE OF PRESENTATION: The date upon which a bill or notice is postmarked or
hand delivered to the customer of the county.
DEVELOPER: Any person engaged in or proposing development of property.
DEVELOPMENT: A parcel of property being improved and requiring installation of
sewer collection lines to and possibly on the property being improved.
ENGINEER: An engineer licensed and registered in the state of Nevada. A civil
engineer is required for design of all public utility main lines.
GARBAGE: Solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food
products.
INSPECTOR: That person so designated by the LCUD to perform inspections, tests,
fixture unit counts and related work in determining compliance with Lyon County
construction specifications, standards and ordinances.
LAW: Any statute, rule, ordinance, bylaw or regulation established by federal,
state, county or municipal authorities.
LEGAL ENTITLEMENT: Any person holding legal title to property within Lyon
County or his or her authorized agent.
LIVING UNIT: Any residence, apartment, or other structure to be occupied for
purposes of habitation by a single person or family and requiring wastewater
disposal services.
LOCAL PURVEYOR: The local entity that provides utility service to the public
within a specified area of service. This chapter is applicable only to local
purveyor as individually accepted by their respective board.
LYON COUNTY UTILITIES DEPARTMENT (LCUD): The Lyon County utilities department
and related service area. May be used in conjunction with "local purveyor" for
areas outside the LCUD service area, providing the local purveyor chooses to
obtain board acceptance.
MAIN EXTENSION/CAPACITY ENHANCEMENT: The extension or replacement of sewer
collection mains and necessary facilities in accordance with the provisions of
this chapter applicable to main extensions and/or capacity enhancements.
METERED SERVICE: A service for which charges are computed on the basis of
measured quantities of water, wastewater or liquid wastes.
OUTSIDE SEWER: A sanitary sewer beyond the limits of the LCUD service area not
subject to the control or jurisdiction of the LCUD.
PERMANENT SERVICE: A service which, in the opinion of the LCUD, is of a
permanent and established character. The use of the sewer may be continuous,
intermittent or seasonal in nature.
PERMIT: Written authorization received from the entity having jurisdiction over
the area. Permit required pursuant to this or any other regulation of Lyon
County and the LCUD for the installation of any utility related infrastructure,
or development requiring a permit from any state, county, city or presiding
entity.
PERSON: A natural person, his heirs, executor, administrators, or assigns and
shall also include a firm, corporation, municipal or quasi-municipal
corporation, or governmental agency. Singular includes plural, male includes
female.
PLUMBING FIXTURE: Any sink, tub, shower, water closet or other facility as
defined by UPC connected by a building drain to the building sewer.
PREMISES: All that real property of a single integrated operation under one
name which operation may involve one or more buildings, locations or services,
provided: a) such buildings, locations, or services are to a single unit of
property; or b) such buildings, locations or services are on two (2) or more
units of property immediately adjoining, except for intervening public
highways, streets, alleys, or waterways.
PRIVATE SEWER: A sewer which is privately maintained and receives the discharge
from one or more building drains and conveys it to a public sewer, private
sewer disposal system, or other point of disposal.
PUBLIC RIGHT OF WAY: Any public deeded, dedicated and accepted highway, road,
street, avenue, alley, way, public easement or right of way for public access.
PUBLIC SEWER: A common sewer main line and related infrastructure directly
controlled by public authority.
PUBLICLY OWNED TREATMENT WORKS (POTW): Any arrangement of devices and
structures used for treating wastewater. The treatment plant and related works
shall be designed and operated in compliance with pertinent state of Nevada
and/or federal statutes, rules, regulations and permits.
SANITARY SEWER: A sewer which carries wastewater and to which storm, surface
and ground waters are intentionally excluded.
SERVICE CLASSIFICATIONS:
   A.   Commercial Unit: Office buildings, private clubs, motels, hotels, dry
cleaners, supermarkets, or portions thereof, laundry, or other facilities
(excepting toilet facilities) requiring wastewater disposal services. All
commercial buildings, or portions thereof, shall include, but not be limited
to, department stores, restaurants, clubs and schools.
   B.   Industrial Service: Service to customers engaged in a process which
creates or changes raw or unfinished materials into another form or product.
(Including, but not limited to, factories, mills, machine shops, mines, pumping
plants, creameries, canning and packing plants, or processing activities.)
   C.   Residential Service: Service to a customer from a residential activity
in a single-family dwelling or building, mobile home, in an individual flat,
condominium, or apartment in a multiple-family dwelling, or building or portion
thereof occupied as the home, residence or sleeping place of one or more
persons.
SERVICE CONNECTION: The point of connection of the customer's piping with the
LCUD or local purveyor's public sewer facilities. Customer owned "Y" on sewer
laterals connecting to the main line, or the point of connection of customer
piping to a public owned manhole.
SERVICE SIZE FOR BILLING PURPOSE: The service size for commercial billing
purposes is based on the calculated demand using the fixture unit calculation
found in the uniform plumbing code. Certain site conditions may necessitate the
installation of a different size meter or a submeter. Billing will be based on
the calculated flows for that connection. Lyon County must approve all metering
design and size.
SEWER: A pipe or conduit approved by LCUD for the conveyance of wastewater.
SEWERAGE: See definition of Treatment Works/Sewerage.
STORM SEWER: A sewer which carries storm, surface, ground, and clear water.
STORM WATER: Water, rainfall or other precipitation which drains from roofs,
other surfaces, catch basins or other pipelines or structures during or
following a storm.
TREATMENT PLANT: See definition of Publicly Owned Treatment Works (POTW).
TREATMENT WORKS/SEWERAGE: All facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and
disposing of wastewater. The treatment works and all facilities shall be in
accordance with design and construction practices of pertinent state of Nevada
statutes, rules, regulations and permits and federal regulations where
applicable.
UTILITIES DIRECTOR: The person appointed to perform the duties of utilities
director.
WASTE: The solid, liquid, or vapor components of wastewater that may be
discharged into the sewer system.
WASTEWATER: The spent water of a community. From the standpoint of source, it
may be a combination of the liquid and water carried wastes from residences,
commercial buildings, industrial plants, and institutions, together with any
ground water, surface water, and storm water that may be present. (Ord. 507, 1-
18-2007)
9.05.03: GENERAL RULES:
   A.   Rules And Regulations: The following rules and regulations respecting
sewer construction, disposal of wastewater, and connection to the treatment
works of LCUD, are hereby adopted, and all work in respect thereto shall be
performed as herein required.
   B.   Purpose: This chapter is intended to provide rules and regulations for
the use and construction of sanitary sewer facilities hereafter installed,
altered or repaired within the LCUD.
   C.   Violation Unlawful: Following the effective date hereof it shall be
unlawful for any person to connect to, construct or install or provide any
other means of wastewater disposal from any building in the LCUD except by
connection to a public sewer where available within four hundred feet (400').
Connection shall be as provided in this chapter.
   D.   Protection From Damage: No person shall maliciously, wilfully, or
negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any
structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the LCUD treatment
works. Any person violating this provision shall be subject to the penalties
provided by law, and shall be responsible for the cost of repair.
   E.   Violation: Any person found to be violating any provision of this
chapter or any other ordinance, rule or regulation of the LCUD, except
subsection F of this section, shall be served by the inspector or other
authorized person with written notice stating the nature of the violation and
providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. Said
time limit shall be ten (10) working days. The offender shall, within the
period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. All
persons shall be held strictly responsible for any and all acts of agents or
employees done under the provisions of this chapter or any other ordinance,
rule or regulation of the LCUD and state and federal rules or regulations. Upon
being notified by the inspector of any defect arising in any sewer or of any
violation of this chapter, the person or persons having charge of said work
shall immediately correct the same.
      1.   Amounts: Violations of these regulations shall be subject to civil
monetary penalties established: a) by applicable Nevada law, b) by applicable
rules and regulations of the Nevada department of environmental protection and
the LCUD and c) by such penalty schedules as may from time to time be adopted
by the LCUD and appended to these regulations.
      2.   Continuing Violations: For purposes of the computation of penalties,
each day of a continuing violation of these regulations shall be deemed to be a
separate violation.
   F.   Public Nuisance: Continued habitation of any building or continued
operation of any industrial facility in violation of the provisions of this
chapter or any other ordinance, rule or regulation of the LCUD is hereby
declared to be a public nuisance. The LCUD may cause proceedings to be brought
for the abatement of the occupancy of the building or industrial facility
during the period of such violation.
   G.   Disconnection: As an alternative method of enforcing the provisions of
this chapter or any other ordinance, rule or regulation of the LCUD, the LCUD
shall have the power to disconnect the user from the sewer mains or water mains
or both. Upon disconnection, the LCUD shall estimate the cost of disconnection
from and reconnection to the system and such user shall deposit the cost, as
estimated, of disconnection and reconnection before such user is reconnected to
the system. LCUD shall refund any part of the deposit remaining after payment
of all costs of disconnection and reconnection.
   H.   Abatement: During the period of such disconnection, habitation of such
premises by human beings shall constitute a public nuisance, whereupon the LCUD
shall cause proceedings to be brought for the abatement of the occupancy of
said premises by human beings during the period of such disconnection. In such
event, and as a condition of reconnection, there is to be paid to the LCUD a
reasonable attorney fee and cost of suit arising in said action.
   I.   Means Of Enforcement Only: The LCUD hereby declares that the foregoing
procedures are established as a means of enforcement of the terms and
conditions of its ordinances, rules and regulations, and not as a penalty.
   J.   Lateral Sewer: That portion of utility line connecting between the main
and the customer property line adjacent to the right of way. A sewer lateral is
that portion of the private sewer line that is within the right of way, but
maintained by the property owner. Sewer laterals are privately owned and
maintained. Any work to be done on the lateral requires a permit and a
contractor licensed to do the work within the right of way.
   K.   Permits And Fees: No public sewer, private sewer delivery system or
other sewerage facility connected or to be connected to the treatment works of
the LCUD shall be installed, altered or repaired within the LCUD service area
until a permit for the work has been obtained and all fees paid in accordance
with the requirements of this chapter.
   L.   Responsibility For Loss Or Damage: LCUD will not be responsible for any
loss or damage caused by any negligence or wrongful act of a person or his
authorized representative in installing, maintaining, operating or using any or
all appliances, facilities or equipment for which sewer service is supplied.
The person will be held responsible for damage to LCUD's facilities and other
property resulting from the use or operation of appliances and facilities on
customer's premises, including damage caused by steam, hot water, chemicals,
electrical connections, private sewer connections, grease sewer overflow or
backups, etc.
Contractors, owners' agents, or other persons responsible for damage to LCUD
property shall be required to pay for repair, replacement, or other
compensation resulting from such damages.
The LCUD assumes no responsibility for loss or damage due to sewage backup or
overflow. The LCUD merely agrees to furnish such capacity in its general
collection system as required by Nevada rules and regulations. The LCUD will
endeavor to give reasonable notice to customers before curtailment of services;
however, the LCUD shall not be liable for shutdown or variations to the system
that occur without prior notice by the LCUD.
