   M.   Uniform Plumbing Code: The following uniform plumbing code provisions
are made part of this chapter as they pertain to areas of responsibility of
LCUD:
This chapter hereby adopts the 2003 uniform plumbing code and its appendices
including: A, B, C, E, H, I (omitting the standards contained within "I" of 8-
95, 11-87, 20-2000), K, (omit K-7 and K-8), and L, (omit L4.0 to L6.3). This
chapter hereby adopts the "Standard Specifications For Public Works
Construction" and "Lyon County Standard Details" most current versions. (Ord.
507, 1-18-2007)
9.05.04: SEWER DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Creation: A sewer department is hereby created comprised of the board,
county manager, and the utilities director.
   B.   County Manager: The county manager shall have full charge and control
of the maintenance, operation and construction of the sewer works and system.
   C.   Utilities Director: The position of utilities director of LCUD is
hereby created. He/she shall have charge of the utilities of the LCUD. This
shall include all maintenance, operation and construction of the sewer works,
and billing for and collecting of service and connection charges. He/she shall
perform such other duties as shall be determined by the county manager.
   D.   Inspections: The LCUD shall perform inspections on all sewer system
construction within the LCUD service area to assure compliance with LCUD
standards and specifications. All existing residential, commercial and
industrial establishments are subject to inspection for proper operation of
grease traps, pretreatment devices, etc. Inspection of existing devices shall
be scheduled with the property owner or property manager. If the property owner
or property manager refuses access, subsection G of this section shall apply.
   E.   Performance Of Duties: The foregoing duties of the utilities director
may be performed by the county manager or by a designated employee(s), as the
county manager may direct, so long as a registered professional engineer
performs those decisions or actions that require professional engineering
judgment.
   F.   Consolidations: Any of the foregoing offices may be consolidated, one
with the other, or with other offices of the LCUD.
   G.   Consequences Of Denial Of Entry Or Access: Where an owner or user,
after having received reasonable notice from the LCUD, refuses to permit
properly identified LCUD personnel to enter or have access to premises or
facilities in accordance with subsection D of this section, the LCUD may
forthwith give written notice of its intent to terminate water and/or sewer
service to such user. Such notice shall be given in accordance with section
9.05.13, "Billing And Collection", and subsection
9.05.14B, "Discontinuance Of Service By LCUD", of this chapter. Termination
based on these sections shall be treated as a termination for refusal of access
under subsection D of this section.
   H.   Violation: Any person found to be violating any provision of this
chapter or any ordinance, rule or regulation of the LCUD, shall be served by
the LCUD authorized personnel with written notice stating the nature of the
violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction
thereof. Said time limit shall be ten (10) business days. The offender shall,
within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all
violations. All persons shall be held strictly responsible for any and all acts
of their agents or employees under the provisions of this chapter or any other
ordinance, rule or regulation of the LCUD. Upon being notified by the LCUD of
any violation of this chapter, the person or persons having charge of said work
shall immediately correct the same.
      1.   Amounts: Violations of these regulations shall be subject to civil
monetary penalties established by: a) applicable Nevada statutes or
administrative code, b) NDEP and the LCUD and c) by such penalty schedules as
may from time to time be adopted by the LCUD and appended to these regulations.
      2.   Continuing Violations: For purposes of the computation of penalties,
each day of a continuing violation of these regulations shall be deemed to be a
separate violation. (Ord. 507, 1-18-2007)
9.05.05: USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED; PROHIBITIONS; CONNECTION:
   A.   Disposal Of Wastes: It shall be unlawful for any person to place,
deposit, or permit to be deposited upon public or private property within the
LCUD service area, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the county, any
human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste.
   B.   Treatment Of Wastes Required: It shall be unlawful to discharge into
any stream or watercourse any sawdust, pulp, oils, rubbish, filth, industrial
waste, poisonous or deleterious substances which affect the health of persons,
fish or livestock, or render such waters unpalatable or distasteful, or other
polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter and Lyon County's industrial
wastewater requirements found in chapter 6 of this title.
   C.   Unlawful Disposal: Except as herein provided, it shall be unlawful to
construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, cesspool, seepage pit or other
facility intended or used for the disposal of wastewater. Septic tanks will
only be allowed in areas where sewer service is not available.
   D.   Occupancy Prohibited: No building, industrial facility or other
structure shall be occupied or issued a certificate of occupancy, until the
owner of the premises has complied with all rules and regulations of the LCUD.
   E.   Sewer Required: The owner of any residential building or structure
occupied by humans, situated within the LCUD service area, is hereby required
at his expense to connect said building directly with the public sewer of the
LCUD where available within four hundred feet (400'), in accordance with the
provisions of this chapter.
      1.   Manner Of Connection And Service: Prior to any connection to the
public sewer, an approved permit for such connection shall be obtained and all
fees paid for such connection.
         a.   A condition for obtaining a permit shall be the approval of plans
and information required for the proposed development. Conformance with
"Standard Specifications For Public Works Construction", current "Standard
Details For The Lyon County Utilities Water And Sewer System", and the current
"Lyon County Ordinance And Development Standards".
         b.   Every building or industrial facility must be separately
connected to the public sewer main with a private building sewer line. One or
more existing buildings located on a single lot or parcel belonging to the same
owner may be served with the same private sewer line during the period of said
ownership. Upon the subsequent subdivision, parceling or dividing of said
parcel or ownership thereof, the portion not directly connected to a public
sewer shall sever and properly cap the connection to the jointly used private
sewer line, install a private building sewer line and lateral and connect
directly to the public sewer. Any proposed new buildings to be used as "mother-
in-law" type quarters located on a single lot or parcel belonging to the same
owner desiring to have the buildings share a single lateral, private main, or
building lateral, shall obtain approval of the LCUD prior to obtaining a permit
to construct.
         c.   In all buildings in which the plumbing system is too low for
gravity flow to the public sewer, domestic wastewater carried by the building
drain shall be lifted by pump or other means approved by the LCUD and
discharged to the public sewer at the expense of the owner. Private sewer
pumping systems shall be designed by an engineer at no cost to the county, LCUD
or local purveyor. Private pumps and equipment are to be located on private
property, not in the public right of way or any public utility easements.
Private pumping systems and related infrastructure are to be privately
maintained.
         d.   Building private sewer lines with the lateral connection below
the manhole rim of the immediate upstream manhole of the public sewer shall
provide at the owner's expense such protective devices in the private sewer
building line as may be necessary to protect owner against flooding. The LCUD
shall not be responsible for any damages from flood or damages caused by flow
to owner's buildings or property regardless of whether such facilities are
located below the hydraulic grade line of the public sewer.
      2.   Protection Of Excavation: All excavations for sewer installations
shall be adequately guarded with barricades or lights to protect the public
from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, easements and other property
disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory
to the LCUD and the county or other person or agency having jurisdiction.
      3.   Approval Of Private Building Sewer Line And Lateral: Prior to any
service, a representative of the LCUD shall inspect and approve the connection
to the public sewer system. Prior to covering the private sewer building line
or lateral, the inspector shall determine compliance with approved plans and
LCUD specifications before approval and authorizing any service. Noncompliance
with plans or specifications shall be corrected prior to issuance of
certification of occupancy or service by the LCUD.
      4.   Permit Required: No unauthorized person shall excavate, make any
connection with or opening into, use, or disturb any public sewer or
appurtenance or perform any work on any building sewer without first obtaining
authorization from LCUD or the local purveyor, and when required a Lyon County
building permit, road department permit, or Nevada department of transportation
permit. (Ord. 507, 1-18-2007)
9.05.06: APPLICATION AND BILLING FOR REGULAR SEWER SERVICE:
   A.   Application: A property owner or his agent shall make application for
regular water service on a form provided by LCUD:
      1.   Purpose: The application is merely a written request for service on
a form provided by LCUD and does not bind the applicant to take service;
neither does it bind LCUD to serve.
Sewer service will not be provided until all provisions related to state,
federal and local regulations and standards have been met.
   B.   Forms Of Application: A property owner or his agent shall make an
application for regular sewer service on the form provided.
   C.   Undertaking Of Applicant: Such application will signify the customer's
willingness and intention to comply with this chapter and other ordinances or
regulations relating to the regular sewer service and to make payment for sewer
service required.
   D.   Individual Liability For Joint Service: Two (2) or more persons who
join in one application for service shall be jointly and severally liable for
payment of bills and shall be billed by means of a single periodic bill.
   E.   Change In Customer's Equipment Or Operations: Before a customer makes
any material change in size, or operation resulting in significant increase in
volumes or wastewater characteristics, or extent of the equipment or operations
for which the LCUD's service is utilized, customer shall immediately file with
the LCUD a new application for additional service.
   F.   Special Cases: The LCUD will require a written contract or permit with
special guarantee from applicants whose unusual characteristics of load would
require excessive or special investment in facilities or whose requirements for
service are of a special nature. Pretreatment may be required and must be
approved by LCUD and NDEP and may require a separate industrial discharge
permit.
   G.   Payment For Previous Service: An application will not be honored unless
payment in full has been made for sewer and other services previously rendered
to the applicant by the LCUD.
   H.   Connection To System Required Within Three Hundred Sixty Five Days Of
Application: Any application that has been accepted by the LCUD may be
considered vacated if the applicant fails to commence construction and
connection to the LCUD's sewer system within three hundred sixty five (365)
days of such acceptance. The fees collected for such application shall be
returned to the applicant upon written request, and a new application and
payment of fees in effect at time of approval of application will be required
before service will be provided. No fees will be refunded after connection.
   I.   Changes In Use Or Uses Of Served Property: Any changes in the use or
uses of properties served by regular sewer service which may affect the service
classification under which it is served or the number of fixture units served
must have the prior approval of the LCUD. Examples of such changes would be
adding plumbing fixtures not previously approved in applying for service,
modifying a residence to accommodate more single-family units than were
approved or such other changes that would similarly change the character of the
building. Such changes in use shall be subject to then current standards and
the fee resolution in effect at time of application approval. Payment of such
fees shall be made upon application. If such change is made without
application, it shall be subject to the corrective measures and current fees.
   J.   Connection Charges: Connection fees shall be collected at the time of
issuing the permit for a sewer connection. Connection fees shall be charged at
the rate in effect on the day of application. Connections not made or
construction not started within three hundred sixty five (365) days will be
subject to reapplication and the current rates in effect at the time of
reapplication. Previously paid connection fees shall be credited to the new
connection fee rate.
      1.   Unit Charges: Sewer connection fees are based on fixture unit counts
for commercial use and one EDU for residential use. Each unit of multi- family
or multiple dwellings on a single parcel shall constitute a separate unit.
      2.   Remodeling Connection Charges: If remodeling necessitates upsizing
of the water meter, sewer connection fees shall be charged equal to the fee for
the upgraded meter size as described in subsection J.1. of this section minus:
a) the total in sewer connection fees paid to the LCUD previously or b) sewer
connection fees for the difference between the old fixture unit count and the
new fixture unit count on commercial service, whichever results in the lower
net additional connection charges.
      3.   Plan Check Fee: Any person requiring approval of plans by the LCUD,
or desiring plan checking, shall pay to the LCUD a plan checking fee as
established by the LCUD and board accepted by resolution. Each plan revision
requiring rechecking shall necessitate the charge of an additional plan check
fee per the Lyon County fee resolution. Plan checking is performed for water
and sewer concurrently.
   K.   Subdivisions:
      1.   Plan Check Fee: Any person requiring approval of plans by the LCUD,
or desiring plan checking shall pay to the LCUD the following fee or fees. Plan
checking fees shall be invoiced at a rate to reimburse direct costs, labor and
materials as determined by LCUD as contained in the current fee resolution.
If any portion of the plans after being checked, are required to be redrawn or
rechecked, the applicant shall pay the additional cost of checking based upon
the actual expense of the rechecking labor and materials, as determined by the
LCUD. Plans will not be released until all fees have been paid.
Encroachment permit applications are available in the office of the LCUD and
are to be filled out by the engineer submitting the plan. Plan checking is
performed for water and sewer concurrently.
      2.   Plan Checking Application: A record owner or his agent may make
application for plan checking service on the form established by the LCUD for
the purpose intended.
      3.   County Or Other Permits: The applicant is responsible to apply for
and obtain any required county road cut, NDOT encroachment or other required
permits.
      4.   Notice To Customer: Notice to a customer will normally be in writing
and will be delivered or mailed to the customer's last known address. In
emergencies, or when circumstances warrant, the LCUD where feasible, will
endeavor to promptly notify the customer affected and may make such
notification orally, either in person or by telephone.
      5.   Notice From Customers: A customer may make notification in writing
to the LCUD at its utilities office or through e-mail. If a customer uses e-
mail for notification, the customer must keep a printed copy showing LCUD
received the notice. (Ord. 507, 1-18-2007; amd. Ord. 622, 12-16-2021)
9.05.07: APPLICATION FOR SERVICE WHEN MAIN EXTENSION OR CAPACITY ENHANCEMENT IS
REQUIRED:
   A.   Application: Any owner of one or more lots or parcels, or subdivider of
a tract of land, desiring the extension of one or more mains to serve such
property, and/or for any capacity enhancement of existing facilities shall
submit an application with six (6) complete sets of plans to the Lyon County
planning department, two (2) sets of plans to the LCUD, a copy of the
application, and any needed studies will be sent to LCUD, such application to
contain the legal description of the property to be served and tract number,
flow models, location of the proposed connection and any additional information
which may be required by LCUD, or Lyon County. Costs shall be borne by the
applicant for surveys or engineering services, including engineering or
potholing to determine location of existing utilities, or the costs of
extensions and/or capacity enhancement. Refer to Lyon County development
standards, "Standard Details And Specifications For Public Works Construction".
Design with plan and profile by a civil engineer registered in Nevada are
required for all main line development. Installation must be by a Nevada and
Lyon County licensed contractor.
   B.   Investigation: Upon receipt of an application for a main extension, the
LCUD engineer shall make an investigation and review of the proposed extension
and/or capacity enhancement.
   C.   Ruling: The director shall thereupon consider the application for main
extension and the report thereon and after such consideration reject or approve
it.
   D.   LCUD Lines: All sewer main extensions and/or capacity enhancement shall
be in accordance with the Lyon County utilities sewer ordinance, "Standard
Specifications For Public Works Construction" and "Lyon County Standard
Details". Main lines shall be and remain the property of the LCUD or the local
purveyor for the area.
   E.   LCUD Extension: The LCUD will inspect all main extensions and/or
capacity enhancement installations.
   F.   Determination: The cost of such extension shall be borne by the
applicant, subject to the reimbursement agreement provided in subsection G of
this section, unless the board determines it is in the best interest of the
LCUD to advance such costs.
   G.   Reimbursement Agreement: If the applicant must extend the sewer line
system through another's property or along the frontages of another's property
or along the frontages of various intermediate property owners, and if said
properties are not currently served by the county's sewer system, then said
intermediate and benefiting property owners shall be responsible when
development commences or connection is made for a pro rata share of the costs
of the sewer line extension.
When the applicant is required to extend a sewer line, he shall "front end" the
entire cost of the sewer line construction and shall be responsible for the
actual construction of said sewer line. Any owners of properties to be served
by the extended sewer line will thereafter be responsible for reimbursing the
first property owner for a pro rata share of the costs of the sewer line system
at the time said subsequent owners begin to plat, parcel, develop or build upon
their parcels.
The pro rata shares for the applicant and all subsequent owners benefited by
the extended sewer line shall be determined prior to the county entering into
the reimbursement agreement. Extensions and/or capacity upgrade financed by the
applicant shall be prorated to the linear footage along the extension. Flag
lots and large parcels with narrow frontage may be calculated by a percentage
of the parcel square footage in relation to the main line installation cost
percentage.
The county shall collect a fifteen percent (15%) administrative fee from the
applicant who front ended the sewer line construction upon reimbursement by
deducting the fifteen percent (15%) administrative fee from the subsequent
owners' pro rata share prior to reimbursement to the applicant by the county.
The reimbursement agreement shall become null and void ten (10) years from the
date of board of county commissioners' approval.
The applicant shall submit three (3) bids prior to construction from qualified
contractors attached to the application for reimbursement, unless due to
extraordinary circumstances three (3) bids are not available due to specialized
construction. The bids shall be itemized and include costs for all items to be
installed (i.e., pipe, manholes, etc.). Failure to provide the itemized bids
will exempt the installation from reimbursement. Construction costs eligible
for reimbursement are limited to engineering, contractor's bid, construction
staking by an engineer or surveyor, permit, inspection and testing fees. The
applicant's administration costs are not eligible for reimbursement.
Single-family homes on property zoned single-family existing at the time of
application for a reimbursement agreement shall be exempt from the provisions
of the agreement. When an existing single-family home is on a parcel which has
adequate area to be divided per the current zoning or master plan designation
of the parcel, the area which could be divided for new development will be
required to be included in the reimbursement agreement. In no event shall any
owners of the property to be served by such extended sewer lines be permitted
to connect thereto without first paying to the applicant or the county the pro
rata share of the costs described above as well as all other fees required by
the county.
Any facilities installed pursuant to this section are the property of the LCUD
upon inspection and acceptance of the county and LCUD. A one year warranty
agreement period is in effect for the contractor to be responsible for repairs.
      1.   Participation By LCUD: Should LCUD require an oversized sewer line,
LCUD will reimburse the applicant for the costs for materials only of the
additional sewer line size as long as said line is greater than ten inches
(10") in diameter. The applicant shall be responsible for the cost of the size
of mains up to and including ten inches (10") or larger if needed for the
project, whichever is greater.
When the LCUD agrees to pay for an increase in sewer line size, at least three
(3) bids, signed and prepared by a contractor, shall be required which show the
comparable cost of the incremental increase. LCUD shall select the proposal
most beneficial to it. The LCUD reserves the right to reject the bids if the
cost differentials exceed prices paid by the LCUD on similar installations. In
no event shall LCUD pay more than the lowest proposal presented. Prior to
construction, the applicant shall submit three (3) bids from qualified
contractors attached to the application for participation, unless due to
extraordinary circumstances three (3) bids are not available due to specialized
construction.
For LCUD to reimburse an applicant for any utility upgrades, approval must be
obtained, an agreement signed and the lowest of three (3) bids approved. LCUD
is not obligated or required to participate in any costs, any reimbursement is
at the discretion of LCUD, and is for out of the ordinary situations only. In
no event shall LCUD pay more than the lowest proposal presented. Bids shall be
itemized and include cost differentials for all items to be included in the
reimbursement. Failure to provide the itemized bids will exempt the
installation from reimbursement.
   H.   Extension By Customer: In special cases where extension of the LCUD's
mains to a point adjacent to customer's premises is not feasible, in the
opinion of the LCUD, customer may obtain necessary easements and upon approval
of LCUD, lay service pipe, at his own expense, from point of use to point where
tap can be made directly to the LCUD's then existing main. This method of
installation will require encroachment permit approval and a possible annual
fee for private lines within the right of way. Easements from adjacent property
owners may be required. This method will be used only in emergencies or as a
last result. This method will only be used on a temporary basis if private
lines are running parallel to the road, or within the public rights of way or
public utility easement. Any damage because of the private line shall be the
responsibility of the line owner, Lyon County shall be held harmless, with no
costs incurred to the county.
   I.   Point Of Connection: LCUD shall be obligated to provide service at the
point of connection to its collection main lines only, and customer shall
assume all responsibility and cost for maintenance, operation and replacement
of his private sewer line and the flow therein.
   J.   Additional Facilities Required: If additional facilities, including,
but not limited to, a sewer pump, should be required in customer's private
sewer line to provide adequate customer service, beyond that normally provided
by the LCUD at point of connection of customer's private sewer line to the
LCUD's main, customer shall provide, operate, maintain and replace such
facilities, all at his own expense.
   K.   No Obligation By LCUD: The LCUD shall at no time in the future be
required to lay additional public sewers beyond the original point of delivery
to provide service to said customer or others supplied through said customer's
private sewer. (Ord. 507, 1-18-2007)
9.05.08: PUBLIC SEWER EXTENSIONS:
   A.   Extensions: The record owner, or duly authorized agent acting on behalf
of the owner, shall submit a written application to LCUD requesting a main line
extension. This application shall contain the legal property description,
assessor's parcel number, map and plan showing proposed extension and
connection, easements or rights of way to be granted or procured. Prior to LCUD
approval of the project for permit, submittal of proposed plans, profiles, flow
models and specifications, prepared and stamped by an engineer registered in
the state of Nevada shall be received. Refer to Lyon County development
standards and current codes for permit requirements. Acceptance of application
is no guarantee of approval by LCUD and does not obligate LCUD to participate
in any costs or installation. LCUD's participation in main line extensions or
upsizing projects must be approved by the Lyon County board of county
commissioners.
LCUD may make but must approve extensions along streets, alleys, lanes, roads,
common areas, and easements cut by established grades, and/or make alterations
in its existing facilities in accordance with these rules and regulations,
provided such extensions are located within the service area of LCUD.
      1.   Extensions of collection lines and appurtenances to provide service
to an applicant will be made at applicant's expense. Subsection G of this
section may apply if LCUD and board of county commissioners' approval is
obtained.
      2.   The cost for LCUD to extend and install utility appurtenances will
be based on actual cost of the project.
      3.   Reserved.
      4.   Reserved.
      5.   All main extensions will become the property of the LCUD. LCUD must
approve inspections and verify compliance with all rules, regulations and
specifications required by the LCUD. A one year maintenance period is in effect
for the contractor to be responsible for repairs. After that time the main
extension will be accepted, owned, operated and maintained by the LCUD at its
own expense.
      6.   Acceptance criteria of sewer lines installed by approved licensed
contractors shall include, but not be limited to:
         a.   Submittal of a three (3) mil Mylar, hard copy and electronic
version acceptable to LCUD, stamped record drawing plan and profile upon
completion of the main line extension;
         b.   Completion of all required testing to the satisfaction of the
LCUD;
         c.   Completion of all appropriate legal documentation incidental to
the transfer of ownership of utility infrastructure and easements to the LCUD.
      7.   All expenses incurred relating to the line extension and/or capacity
enhancement shall be borne by the applicant.
      8.   LCUD approval and acceptance of lines shall be based on compliance
with all Lyon County, federal, and state ordinances, rules, regulations and
policies.
      9.   No extension contract, or any rights thereunder, granted under this
provision may be assigned without written notification to the LCUD by the
registered holder of the contract. (Ord. 507, 1-18-2007)
9.05.09: BUILDING SEWERS, PRIVATE SEWER LINES, LATERALS, AND CONNECTIONS:
   A.   Permit Required: No unauthorized person shall excavate, make any
connection with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer,
building drain or building sewer; and appurtenances thereto or perform any work
on any lateral or building sewer without first obtaining a written permit from
the LCUD. Any new construction, addition, remodel or demolition requiring
issuance of a Lyon County building permit shall require written approval and
final acceptance by an LCUD inspector.
   B.   Construction Requirements: Construction of building sewers and private
sewer lines shall be in accordance with the requirements hereof and other
current Lyon County standards. Conflicts in current codes will be resolved by
using the most stringent code, or at the discretion of LCUD.
   C.   Minimum Size And Slope: The minimum size of a building sewer shall be
four inches (4") in diameter unless discharging from a pressure system. The
building sewer, private sewer delivery system or all other portions of the
sewerage shall be four inches (4"), six inches (6"), or eight inches (8") in
diameter, as determined by the engineer of record, and approved by LCUD.
   D.   Separate Sewers: No two (2) adjacent buildings fronting on the same
street shall be permitted to join in the use of the same private building sewer
line or lateral. Every building or industrial facility must be separately
connected to a public sewer if such public sewer exists in the street upon
which the property abuts or in an easement which will serve said property.
However, upon approval of LCUD, one or more buildings located on a lot or
parcel of land belonging to the same record owner may be served with the same
private sewer main line during the period of said ownership. Upon the
subsequent subdivision of said lot and sale of a portion thereof, the portion
not directly connected to public sewer shall have a new private lateral and
building line installed and connect directly to the public sewer main. It shall
be unlawful for the record owner thereof to continue to use or maintain such
indirect connection. Joint use sewers shall only be approved in the case of a
multi-family complex, or commercial complex that has a private main line for
collection. Any private main lines are privately maintained. Ownership shall be
as stated above, unless easements and agreements are created between commercial
or multi-family owners, approved by LCUD. Customer must record the agreement
with the county recorder's office. A main line is classified as six inches (6")
and above, and shall connect with the county main with a manhole.
   E.   Old Building Sewers: Old building sewers may be used in connection with
new buildings only when they have been video inspected and tested and are found
to meet all requirements of the LCUD and engineer of record. The inspector must
approve their use. Any sewer not used shall be properly capped at the
connection to the main. The capping must be inspected by LCUD or the local
purveyor. If street work is required for the capping, the owner will be
required to get an encroachment permit.
   F.   Cleanouts: Cleanouts shall be provided and privately maintained in the
private building sewer at a location three feet (3') outside the foundation
wall of the building. Cleanouts shall be constructed as per Lyon County
standard details, the adopted uniform plumbing code and where the building
sewer crosses a property line. All cleanouts shall be maintained watertight,
with plug enclosure and covered with a concrete box with a steel lid marked
"sewer" and set to finished surface grade.
   G.   Sewer Too Low, Individual Sewage Pump Stations (ISPS): In all buildings
or properties in which the plumbing systems are too low to permit gravity flow
to the public sewer, domestic wastewater carried by the building sewer shall be
lifted by artificial means and discharged to the public sewer at the expense of
the owner. Design of the system shall be by the owner's project engineer and
approved by LCUD. Installation shall be approved by the inspector. Location of
the pump and related equipment is to be on private property, not in the right
of way, or public utility easement. A backwater device shall be installed and
maintained by the customer in building sewers serving fixtures at a lower
elevation than the overflow rim of the upstream manhole of the sewer to which
it discharges. The LCUD reserves the right to have sewer pump stations
inspected and tested when deemed by the utilities director to be a potential
hazard to public health or the environment. The LCUD shall determine the
inspection and testing frequency. Maintenance will be done at the owner's
expense. All ISPSs must be approved by LCUD and all backwater devices must be
accessible for maintenance and repair.
   H.   Abandonment Of Private Sewer Disposal (Septic) System: The LCUD will
not authorize a customer to extend and connect customer's private sewer
disposal system (septic system) to the LCUD's main.
Abandonment of any failed or unused septic system shall be done in accordance
with the uniform plumbing code, state health and Lyon County requirements.
Under no circumstance will an abandoned private sewer disposal system be
allowed to stay in service with any connection to the county sewer system. Any
parcel connecting to the county sewer shall properly abandon the existing
septic system.
The costs incurred for the abandonment and connection to the sewer shall be the
responsibility of the record owner and the connection shall be at the location
specified or approved by the LCUD.
All water and sewer testing is required to comply with federal, state and local
regulations, laws or ordinances and shall be at the expense of the applicant.
   I.   Backflow Prevention Devices: The LCUD may refuse or discontinue service
to any premises where a cross connection to a source of water supply exists.
   J.   Maintenance: The LCUD will not be responsible for the installation and
maintenance of the sewer or waste lines beyond the point of connection of the
private sewer lateral to the public sewer (see subsection K of this section).
It shall be the owner's and/or customer's responsibility to verify that
fixtures and piping conform to the requirements of all state, county or
municipal ordinances, laws, codes and regulations and be properly maintained.
   K.   Connection To Public Sewer:
      1.   Connection Point Provided: The connection of the building sewer and
private sewer delivery system into the public sewer shall be made at a point
where the lateral and building sewer meets the county sewer main line. The wye
branch, lateral and building line are the customer's responsibility for
maintenance and repair.
      2.   Location: The location of all sewer connection points shall be
approved by the LCUD.
      3.   Installation Standards: The connection to public sewer shall be
installed in accordance with all rules, regulations and standards of LCUD.
      4.   Connection Point: All building sewers, laterals and private mains
are the responsibility of the property owner to the connection at the main
sewer including the wye, tee or saddle.
      5.   Backwater Valve Required: Where any fixture in a structure is lower
than the overflow rim of the upstream manhole or end of line cleanout, an
approved backwater valve must be installed on the building sewer service line.
   L.   Protection Of Excavation: All excavations for sewer installations shall
be adequately guarded with barricades and/or lights so as to protect the public
from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other property disturbed in the
course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the LCUD and
the county or any other entity or person having jurisdiction.
   M.   Maintenance Of Building Sewer: Building sewers to point of connection
to public sewer (wye connection on main) shall be maintained by the record
owner served by that building sewer per subsection K of this section.
      1.   It is unlawful for any record owner of a house, building or property
connected to a public sewer to maintain the private sewer delivery system or
building sewer in a condition that is incapable of passing a test as specified
in subsection M3 of this section.
      2.   All private sewer delivery systems and building sewers, including
lines serving residential, multiple residential and commercial properties
connected to a public sewer shall be cleaned and tested as specified in
subsection M3 of this section prior to completion of the following events:
         a.   Complete remodel or over fifty percent (50%) addition to a house,
building or property served.
         b.   Installation of additional buildings or property to be served.
         c.   Change of use of a house, building or property served from
residential to business or commercial, or from nonrestaurant commercial to
restaurant commercial.
         d.   Repair or replacement of all or part of the building sewer or
private sewer delivery system.
         e.   Determination by the utilities director that the cleaning and
testing is required for the protection of the public health, safety or welfare.
         f.   Laterals installed at the time of the main line installation
shall be tested and video inspected.
         g.   Video inspection may be required after completion of hardscape or
other surface improvements.
      3.   Air testing of existing private sewer delivery systems and building
sewers shall be completed as follows:
         a.   Install cleanouts to grade within three feet (3') outside of the
foundation wall and at property line, including box with metal lid marked
"sewer".
         b.   Testing from LCUD manholes is permissible if the sewer line ties
directly into the manhole. If the sewer line exceeds seventy five feet (75') in
length, use of the property line cleanout for testing is required. When testing
from an LCUD manhole, conformance with the approved safety methods is required.
         c.   Insert air test plug at foundation cleanout.
         d.   Insert an inflatable plug at the property line cleanout.
         e.   Pressurize the line to 3.5 pounds per square inch (psi). The line
shall be allowed a maximum loss in pressure of 0.5 psi in five (5) minutes. If
the loss exceeds 0.5 psi, the test may be attempted one additional time. A
second loss of pressure constitutes failure of the line.
         f.   Lines which fail the air pressure test shall be repaired or
replaced at the record owner's expense. The line shall be air pressure tested
following the repair or replacement.
         g.   Private sewer delivery systems and building sewers shall be left
operationally clean after air testing.
         h.   If access to private sewer delivery systems or building sewers at
the LCUD main is not available, testing will be between property line and
foundation cleanouts. Cleaning and video inspection must be performed on the
entire line from foundation cleanout to public sewer.
         i.   LCUD must witness all pressure tests.
      4.   The record owner of any house, building or property shall conduct
all cleaning and testing required at his sole expense and shall notify the LCUD
for inspection. Testing conducted without such notice shall not satisfy the
requirements of this section.
      5.   The utilities director shall have the authority to waive the
cleaning and testing requirements.
      6.   In the event that cleaning, testing, repair or replacement is
required at a time when weather conditions or excavation restrictions prohibit
such repairs, the utilities director may defer completion of the requirements
until such date as agreed upon between the record owner and the LCUD. If the
test is deferred, the record owner shall post a performance bond or cash
deposit with the LCUD in an amount equal to one hundred fifty percent (150%) of
the engineer's estimate of the cost of replacing the building sewer or private
sewer delivery system. In such an event, the testing requirements shall be
completed within a six (6) month period.
      7.   If any items in subsection M2 of this section applies, if the
property is being sold and weather conditions or excavation restrictions
prohibit testing, the record owner shall deposit escrow funds in the amount
equal to one hundred fifty percent (150%) of the engineer's estimate of the
cost of replacing the private sewer delivery system. Funds held in escrow will
not be released without written notice by the LCUD to the title company holding
such funds. If the testing requirements are not completed by the time set by
this section, the funds held in escrow shall be released to the LCUD. The funds
shall be used by the LCUD for physical disconnection, testing, repair or
replacement of the private sewer delivery system. Should such costs exceed the
amount held in escrow, the difference shall be billed to the new owner of
record.
      8.   In the event a private sewer delivery system or building sewer does
not meet the standards set forth in subsections M3 and N of this section, the
record owner shall complete corrective work and testing shall be performed
within thirty (30) days from the date of the original test.
      9.   A state of Nevada licensed contractor shall be responsible for the
performance of all work connected with the cleaning and testing of private
sewer delivery systems. If the record owner chooses to perform the cleaning and
testing, he may do so by obtaining authorization from the LCUD. Contractors and
owners must post a certificate of insurance with the LCUD showing property
damage and public liability in an amount satisfactory to the LCUD.
      10.   Testing of private sewer delivery systems for common interest
developments shall be completed as follows:
         a.   All homeowners' and property owners' associations for common
interest developments are responsible for the cleaning and maintenance for the
building lines and laterals.
         b.   Each parcel or development applying for a permit shall include on
the site and utility plan the location of all existing and proposed private
sewer lines and appurtenant facilities, designating those sewer facilities
belonging to the association, sizes and lengths of pipes, location of cleanouts
and types of pipe. Said plans shall also show the location of proposed new
cleanouts, where necessary, in order to gain access to the private sewer
delivery systems and facilities. Prior to final approval of inspections a three
(3) mil Mylar drawing showing the above items shall be provided to LCUD.
         c.   Homeowners' and property owners' associations for common interest
developments may undertake a six (6) year program of testing and cleaning
private delivery systems, and may coordinate with LCUD for assistance in
keeping records and plans showing pertinent locations of on site facilities.
Each homeowners' or property owners' association choosing to undertake and
participate in the six (6) year maintenance program shall submit to the LCUD a
schedule of that year's proposed testing and cleaning program with a timetable
as to when actual work will take place. LCUD reserves the right to vary the
testing schedule in order to coordinate with the availability of LCUD
inspectors.
   N.   Testing: Testing shall be conducted in accordance with the most
recently adopted edition of the uniform plumbing code and the LCUD
requirements. In the case of conflicting requirements, the LCUD requirement
shall prevail.
   O.   Modification Of Time Frame: Modifications of the time frames in
subsection M of this section shall be at the discretion of the utilities
director. (Ord. 507, 1-18-2007)
9.05.10: PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SEWER SYSTEM CONSTRUCTION:
   A.   Permit Required: No person shall construct, extend or connect to any
public sewer without first obtaining a written permit from Lyon County and
obtaining approval from the LCUD, paying all fees and furnishing any required
bonds. The provision of this section requiring permits shall not be construed
to apply to contractors constructing sewers and appurtenances under contracts
awarded and entered into by the LCUD except as provided in this chapter.
Inspections, tests, approvals, and one year maintenance agreements are required
on all LCUD owned main line installations, regardless of the party processing
the contract or awarding the bid for contractors.
   B.   Plans, Profiles And Specifications Required: The application for a
permit for public sewer construction shall be accompanied by complete plans,
profiles and specifications, complying with all applicable ordinances, rules
and regulations of Lyon County and the LCUD, prepared by a registered Nevada
civil engineer, showing all details of the proposed work based on an accurate
survey of the ground. The application, together with the plans, profiles, flow
models and specifications, shall be examined by the LCUD who shall approve them
as filed or require them to be modified as necessary to meet all regulations
for proper installation. Refer to Lyon County development standards.
   C.   Easements Or Rights Of Way: In the event that an easement is required
for the extension of the public sewer or the making of connections, the
applicant shall procure, have recorded and have accepted by LCUD a proper
easement or grant of right of way sufficient in law to allow the laying and
maintenance of such extension or connection. Easements or rights of way are
reserved for the servicing of utilities, and no structure or building shall be
placed within or over easements or rights of way, nor shall these areas be
occupied or used in any manner as to restrict or deny access for repairs to
maintenance, and all costs of removing or replacing land surfaces, landscaping
or other occupancies shall be charged to the property record owner.
In order to preserve the health, safety and welfare of the residents within the
LCUD service area, and in order to comply with the environmental protection
agency's safe drinking water act/surface water treatment rule and the clean
water act and the intents and specifications thereof, the LCUD requires and
shall be allowed open and continuous access by its personnel over, across,
through, and under all easement locations for normal and emergency operation of
the LCUD infrastructure.
Types of obstructions restricted within easement areas include, but are not
limited to:
      1.   Residential site improvements, such as landscaping, lawn,
flowerbeds, gardens, irrigation systems, outbuildings, secondary residences,
fences, walls, gazebos, paving, and other site improvements and ancillary
improvements associated therewith.
      2.   Primary residence, multi-family, commercial, industrial, public,
special use buildings and lands and such ancillary improvements associated
therewith, such as decks, carports, pools, gazebos, spas, parking and paved
accesses, carports and garages, fences and detached outbuildings.
      3.   Refer to Lyon County development standards for development criteria.
A sewer easement shall have a minimum width of twenty feet (20'). Any
development encroaching into an easement may be removed by the entity doing
maintenance on the sewer line. There is no requirement for replacement of items
or structures removed.
      4.   Easements shall allow for a ten foot (10') minimum horizontal
separation that shall be maintained between water lines and sewer, storm drain
and reclaimed water lines. Measurement shall be from outside edge of pipes.
Minimum horizontal separation from all other utilities shall be five feet (5').
All natural and constructed obstructions in aforementioned rights of way shall
be subject to the provisions set forth herein.
All new construction, remodeling, restoration and further development on any
parcel shall incorporate the provisions as set forth herein.
   D.   Mitigation Of Encroachments Onto Easements And Rights Of Way: Lyon
County and the LCUD may accommodate, by means of direct negotiations leading to
the execution of an encroachment agreement (that may include a yearly fee for
county owned right of way encroachment), extenuating circumstances where
conditions of clear necessity or historical occupation or use are present.
Encroachment agreements approved and executed shall be recorded. Absent
explicit language to the contrary, by entering into any encroachment agreement,
the LCUD does not surrender a claim to title nor control of operations;
furthermore, absent explicit language in the encroachment agreement to the
contrary, the LCUD shall not incur any additional cost by reason of existing or
constructed privately owned improvements. The county, LCUD, county retained
contractors or other professionals on a bid contract shall be held harmless,
with no cost to the county or LCUD for any damage to encroachments during
maintenance on utility lines and infrastructure within the easement. The above
hold harmless clause does not include any blatant acts of carelessness or
activities outside normal legal parameters.
   E.   Persons Authorized To Perform Work: Only properly licensed contractors
shall be authorized to perform the work of public sewer construction within
Lyon County. The LCUD will not accept dedication of any public sewer
construction, or portions thereof, unless the construction has been performed
by the holder of a class A contractor's license issued by the Nevada state
contractors board and a current Lyon County business license. The licensed
contractor shall sign for and pick up the permit, or authorization issued by
the county or LCUD. All terms and conditions of the permit issued by the county
and/or LCUD to the applicant shall be binding on the contractor. The
requirements of this section shall apply to building sewers and private sewer
lines, laterals and mains installed concurrently with public sewer
construction. Owners, developers or others without proper licensing may not be
issued the permit for right of way, or public utility construction.
No person, other than employees of the LCUD, persons contracting to do work for
the LCUD, or maintenance workers of the LCUD, shall construct or cause to be
constructed, or alter or cause to be altered, any public sewer, lateral sewer,
house connection or industrial connection sewer over six inches (6") in
diameter, sewage pumping plant, pollution control plant, or other sewerage
facility within the LCUD service area where existing or proposed wastewater
flows will discharge directly or indirectly to facilities of the county without
first obtaining approval of sewerage construction plans from LCUD and obtaining
a construction permit.
   F.   Grade Stakes: Grade and line stakes shall be set by a registered civil
engineer or a licensed surveyor prior to the start of work on any public sewer
construction. The contractor shall be responsible for accurately transferring
grades to grade bars and sewer invert.
   G.   Compliance With Local Regulations: Any person constructing a sewer
within a street shall comply with all state, county or city laws, ordinances,
rules and regulations pertaining to the cutting of pavement, opening,
barricading, lighting and protecting of trenches, backfilling and repaving
thereof, and shall obtain all permits and pay all fees required by the
department having jurisdiction prior to the issuance of a permit by the LCUD.
   H.   Design And Construction Standards: Minimum standards for the design and
construction of sewers within the LCUD service area shall be in accordance with
Lyon County and LCUD's development standards, standard details, "Standard
Specifications For Public Works Construction", and ordinances, rules and
policies heretofore or hereafter as amended by Lyon County and the LCUD, copies
of which are on file in the LCUD office. The LCUD may permit engineered
modifications or may require higher standards where unusual conditions are
encountered. Modifications to the engineered plans require the engineer of
design to approve and submit revisions for the modifications. LCUD or Lyon
County and the design engineer will determine when a project will require
resubmittal. The LCUD inspector may "shut down" a job in process with a written
stop work notice, if he deems more information is required on the approved
improvement plans, therefore requiring a resubmittal for more information, or
the correct information to be shown on the plans.
   I.   Connection To A Trunk Sewer Main Line:
      1.   Any person desiring to connect a sewer six inches (6") or smaller in
diameter directly to a trunk sewer of the LCUD shall make written application
to the LCUD. The applicant shall furnish such information as required by the
LCUD to substantiate that the proposed work or use will comply with the
provisions of this chapter.
      2.   A trunk sewer connection permit will not be issued for any sewer
which will convey industrial wastewaters unless the discharger has first
obtained a permit for industrial wastewater discharge.
      3.   Direct attachment of a sewer six inches (6") or smaller in diameter
to a trunk sewer will be permitted only if the LCUD determines that a suitable
local sewer is not available, that adequate trunk sewer capacity exists, that
the connection will function properly, and that the connection will not
adversely affect existing or anticipated facilities or operations of the LCUD
system. Sewers six inches (6") or smaller in diameter to be attached directly
to a trunk sewer shall be constructed in a manner and at the location specified
by the LCUD. Inspection of the connections to a trunk sewer shall be made by
personnel of the LCUD. No sewer exceeding six inches (6") in diameter shall be
connected directly to a trunk sewer without the prior approval of plans for
sewerage construction, by the LCUD.
   J.   Completion Of Sewer Required: Before any acceptance of any sewer line
by the LCUD and prior to the admission of any wastewater into the system, the
sewer line shall be video inspected, tested and shall be in full compliance
with all requirements of the most recently adopted edition of the uniform
plumbing code, "Lyon County Standard Details", "Standard Specifications For
Public Works Construction" and/or LCUD requirements to construct water and
sewer and private communal utility systems, LCUD requirements to construct
water and sewer service lines, the specifications for sewer construction, and
to the satisfaction of the LCUD staff. All permit requirements must be met, and
all required inspections approved. There is a one year warranty period where
the developer/contractor is responsible for repairs or defects. (Ord. 507, 1-
18-2007)
9.05.11: REQUIREMENTS FOR USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS:
   A.   Drainage Into Sanitary Sewers Prohibited: No leaders from roofs, no
surface drains for rainwater, or no underdrains for foundations or paved
surfaces shall be connected to any sanitary sewer. No surface or storm water,
seepage, cooling water, ground water or unpolluted industrial process waters
shall be permitted to enter any sanitary sewer by any device or method
whatsoever.
   B.   Combined Sewers: No combined sewer or storm sewer shall be connected to
the POTW.
   C.   Required Use Of Grease Interceptors: All waste discharged from
commercial establishments which may generate grease shall install and maintain
a grease interceptor. Sizing specifications for interceptors are outlined in
the uniform plumbing code. The design, operation and sizing of all grease
interceptors must be approved by the LCUD. Grease traps are not allowed.
      1.   Capacity: Grease interceptors and sand/oil separators shall be
constructed to prevent any bypass of matter prohibited in the wastewater
system. Grease interceptors and sand/oil separators shall be a minimum capacity
of seven hundred fifty (750) gallons or as specified in the uniform plumbing
code and a sampling manhole will be installed. All systems must be designed by
a registered civil engineer with the state of Nevada.
Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when and where necessary
for the removal of grease, oil, sand or other waste components not present in
normal residential wastewater. No such device shall be required for residential
service. Grease interceptors shall be cleaned regularly to ensure proper
operation and shall comply with the industrial wastewater discharge and
pretreatment regulations.
      2.   Service Log: The owner or operator of the establishment or business
conducted on the premises where the grease trap or interceptor and/or sand/oil
separators are located shall maintain a log describing the date and type of all
service and maintenance performed in connection with the grease trap or
interceptor and/or sand/oil separator, the identity of the person who performed
the service or maintenance, the amount of residue removed from the grease
interceptor and/or sand/oil separator on each date, the method of disposal of
the residue, and copies of the receipts for service. The log entries shall be
maintained for six (6) years, along with photocopies of receipts for service,
and shall be made available for inspection and copying at the request of an
LCUD representative. The schedule for service and maintenance of a grease
interceptor and/or sand/oil separator shall be subject to approval by the LCUD.
Any change of ownership, remodel, and/or use of a property or facility, may
require the installation or upgrade of a grease interceptor.
      3.   Prohibitions: The introduction of emulsifiers, bacteria, enzymes or
any other product into the grease interceptor which would cause oil and grease
to pass through the interceptor is prohibited.
      4.   Inspections: The LCUD engineer shall determine frequency of
inspections. Should inspections become necessary at a frequency of less than
four (4) months, then the LCUD shall charge the cost, labor and materials for
the more frequent inspections.
      5.   Violations And Citations: At the discretion of the LCUD engineer,
after a notice to the property owner stating the violation, a citation may be
issued, and service may be discontinued if the situation is not in compliance
with local, state, and federal regulations. LCUD may require replacement or
upsizing of facilities to meet current standards. Level of response shall be in
direct relation to the level of hazard or violation, and shall be at the
discretion of the LCUD engineer to take the appropriate measures to confirm
compliance is met for local, state and federal regulations.
   D.   Limitations On The Use Of Garbage Grinders: Waste from garbage grinders
shall not be discharged into LCUD wastewater facilities except when the wastes
are generated in preparation of food normally consumed on the premises and the
grinders shred the waste to a degree that all particles will be carried freely
under normal flow conditions prevailing in the wastewater facilities, and to a
size not to exceed one-half inch (1/2") in any dimension. Garbage grinders
shall not be used for grinding plastic, paper products, inert materials or
garden refuse. All scullery or dish table wastes shall not be put through a
garbage grinder unless the discharge is through an approved grease interceptor,
except that such interceptors shall not be required for buildings used for
noncommercial/residential purposes.
   E.   Maintenance Of Pretreatment Facilities: Such devices as are required in
the preceding subsections shall be of a type and capacity approved by the LCUD,
and shall be so located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and
inspection. All grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be maintained by the
owner, at his expense, in continuously efficient operation at all times. Any
maintenance costs incurred by the LCUD to remove grease, sand, oil, or other
nonapproved waste from county mains will be billed to the owner of the
property.
   F.   Preliminary Treatment Of Wastes: The admission into the public sewers
of any waste containing any quantity of substance having characteristics
described in chapter 6 of this title, shall be subject to special rates and
such conditions as public sewer system requires to treat and dispose of the
special waste discharged. Where necessary, this may include increase in rate
from that for normal residential waste, or such treatment as necessary prior to
discharge into the sewer system and the complete exclusion of certain wastes
harmful to the treatment process.
Plans, specifications and any other pertinent information relating to proposed
preliminary treatment facilities shall be prepared and stamped by an engineer
licensed in Nevada and submitted for the approval by the LCUD and NDEP. No
construction of such facilities shall be commenced until said approvals are
obtained in writing.
   G.   Swimming Pools: It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge the
contents of a swimming pool into a sanitary sewer except in the manner
specified herein. The size pipe carrying discharge water shall not be larger
than two inches (2") and shall not be under a head to exceed twenty feet (20').
If the water is discharged by pumping, the rate of flow shall not exceed a
discharge rate approved by the LCUD. Each swimming pool discharging to a
sanitary sewer shall be equipped with an approved separator to preclude any
possibility of a backflow of wastewater into the swimming pool or piping
system. No discharge of the contents of a swimming pool into a sanitary sewer
shall be made until a permit therefor has been obtained from the LCUD and the
payment by the applicant of a permit fee in the amount fixed by the LCUD. Such
discharge shall be made only at the time and in the manner specified by the
LCUD or its authorized representatives and subject to the rules and/or
regulations of the LCUD.
   H.   Limitations On Point Of Discharge: No person shall discharge any
substances directly into a manhole or other opening in a community sewer.
   I.   Cleaning Of Sewers (Limitations And Notification): No person shall
discharge to the public sewer by means of sewer line cleaning equipment as a
scheduled maintenance operation or under emergency conditions without first
contacting the LCUD. In all cases a means of extracting solid material from the
LCUD mains at a manhole shall be required. Acceptable means of extraction shall
be by trapping, vacuum equipment or other appropriate means, as approved by the
LCUD engineer. (Ord. 507, 1-18-2007)
9.05.12: PERMITS AND FEES:
   A.   Permit Required: No unauthorized person shall excavate, make any
connection with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or
appurtenances or perform any work on any building sewer without first obtaining
a written authorization from the LCUD. Plans for sewerage construction shall
not be approved by LCUD for any facility that will convey industrial wastewater
unless the discharger has first obtained a permit for industrial wastewater
discharge.
   B.   Application For Permit: Any person legally entitled to apply for and
receive a permit shall submit an application on forms provided by the LCUD. The
applicant shall submit to LCUD for approval, construction plans and such
specifications and other details as required, to describe fully the proposed
sewerage facility. The plans shall have been prepared under the supervision of
and shall be signed by an engineer of suitable training registered in the state
of Nevada.
If LCUD determines that the plans, specifications, drawings, description or
information furnished by the applicant is in compliance with the ordinances,
rules and regulations of federal, state, and county, LCUD shall issue the
permit applied for upon payment of the required fees as the board of
commissioners approved in the latest fee resolution. The inspector shall also
issue, when applicable, a permit, upon approval of application and payment of
connection fees. The permit shall authorize its holder to access service in
accordance with all ordinance policy rules and regulations of the LCUD.
   C.   Compliance With Permit/Revisions To Permit: After approval of the
application, evidenced by the issuance of a permit, no change shall be made
from those described in the permit or as shown on the plans and specifications
for which the permit was issued, except with written permission from the LCUD.
   D.   Agreement: The applicant's signature on an application for any permit
shall constitute an agreement to comply with all of the provisions, terms and
requirements of this chapter and other ordinances, rules and regulations of the
LCUD, and with any plans and specifications he has filed with his application,
together with such corrections or modifications permitted by the LCUD. Such
agreement shall be binding upon the applicant and may be altered only by the
LCUD upon the written request for the alteration from the applicant.
   E.   All Work To Be Inspected: All sewer construction work, building sewers,
plumbing and drainage systems shall be inspected by an inspector acting for the
LCUD to ensure compliance with all requirements of the LCUD. No sewer shall be
covered at any point until it has been inspected and passed for acceptance. No
sewer shall be connected to the LCUD's public sewer until the work covered by
the permit has been completed, inspected and approved by the inspector. If the
test proves satisfactory, and all construction work is in compliance with all
applicable rules and regulations of the LCUD, and the sewer has been cleaned of
all debris accumulated from construction operations, the inspector shall issue
a certificate of satisfactory completion.
   F.   Notification: It shall be the duty of the person doing the work
authorized by permit to notify the office of the LCUD, in writing, that said
work is ready for inspection. Such notification shall be given not less than
forty eight (48) hours before the work is to be inspected. It shall be the duty
of the person doing the work to make sure that the work will stand the tests
required by the LCUD before giving the above notification.
   G.   Condemned Work: When any work has been inspected and the work
condemned, the LCUD shall deliver a written notice to that effect to the record
owner of the premises or his authorized agent, instructing the record owner to
repair the sewer or other work authorized by the permit in accordance with the
ordinances, rules and regulations of the LCUD.
   H.   All Costs Paid By Owner: All costs and expenses incident to the
installation and connection of any sewer or other work for which a permit has
been issued shall be borne by the owner and shall be in addition to all fees
and availability of service charges provided for in the sewer ordinance of the
LCUD. The owner shall indemnify the LCUD against any loss or damage that may
directly or indirectly be occasioned by the work.
   I.   Street Excavation Permit: A separate permit must be secured from the
LCUD, the Lyon County road department, or any other person having jurisdiction
thereover by the owners or contractors intending to excavate in a public right
of way for the purpose of installing sewers, repairing or making sewer
connections.
   J.   Liability: The LCUD and its officers, agents and employees shall not be
held responsible for any liability or injury or death to any person or damage
to any property arising from the performance of any work by any such applicant.
The applicant, his engineer and contractor shall be held responsible for, and
the LCUD and its officers, agents and employees shall be held harmless from,
any liability imposed by law upon the LCUD or its officers, agents or
employees, including all costs, expenses, fees and interest incurred in
defending same or in seeking to enforce this provision. As between the
applicant and the LCUD; applicant, his engineer and contractor shall be solely
liable for any defects in the performance of his work or work performed on his
behalf or any failure which may develop therewith.
   K.   Time Limit On Permits: If work under a permit is not commenced within
three hundred sixty five (365) calendar days from the date of issuance, or if
after partial completion the work is discontinued for a period of three hundred
sixty five (365) days, the permit shall become void and no further work shall
be done until a new permit is secured. A new, then current fee shall be paid
upon the issuance of said permit.
   L.   Final Inspection: Final inspection shall be performed and if approved,
shall constitute the completion of the permitted project in accordance with
LCUD ordinances, rules, regulations and policies. (Ord. 507, 1-18-2007)
9.05.13: BILLING AND COLLECTION:
   A.   Billing: The regular billing period will be monthly, or at the
discretion of the LCUD. Before service is activated by LCUD the property owner
must sign the application form as provided by LCUD in which he guarantees
payment of future sewer bills for the service required. The property owner
signing the owner application for utility service form will be held liable for
the appropriate fee for sewer service until LCUD is notified in writing to
terminate service or transfer the account to another property owner. The owner
may assign an agent that the bill will be mailed to, however the owner will
ultimately be responsible for all payments.
   B.   Opening And Closing Bills: Opening and closing bills for less than the
normal billing period shall be no less than the minimum charge for the monthly
service.
   C.   Penalties: All charges shall become due and payable upon presentation.
Payments not received by the due date shown on the bill shall become delinquent
on the next business day after the due date. All charges which become
delinquent shall be subject to a penalty of ten percent (10%) for the first
month delinquent. Customers' payments shall be applied to their oldest balances
due, including penalties, first.
   D.   Represents Lien On Property: Until paid, all rates and charges provided
in this chapter constitute a perpetual lien on and against the property served
and may be foreclosed upon as provided by law.
   E.   Delinquent Charges Collected On Tax Rolls:
      1.   The purpose of this section is to adopt provisions authorized by
Nevada Revised Statutes 244.36605 to have delinquent charges for sewerage
collected on the tax roll in the same manner, by the same persons, and at the
same time, together with and not separately from, Lyon County's general taxes.
      2.   The utilities department shall cause a description of each parcel of
real property with respect to which a sewer charge is delinquent on May 1 and
the amount of the delinquent charge to be prepared and submitted to the county
clerk/treasurer no later than June 1. The description of each parcel and the
amount of the delinquent charge must be submitted in a form approved by the
county treasurer.
      3.   The amount of the charge which is delinquent constitutes a lien
against the lot or parcel of land against which the charge has been imposed as
of the time when the lien of taxes on the roll attaches.
      4.   The county clerk/treasurer shall include the amount of the charges
on bills for taxes levied against the respective lots and parcels of land.
Thereafter the amount of the charges must be collected at the same time and in
the same manner and by the same persons as, together with and not separately
from, the general taxes for the county.
      5.   All laws applicable to the levy, collection and enforcement of
general taxes of the county, including, but not limited to, those pertaining to
the matters of delinquency, correction, cancellation, refund, redemption and
sale, are applicable to delinquent charges for sewerage.
      6.   The county clerk/treasurer may issue separate bills for those
charges and separate receipts for collection on account of those charges.
   F.   Collection By Suit: As an alternative to any of the other procedures
herein provided, LCUD may bring an action against the person or persons who
occupied the premises when the service was rendered for the collection of the
amount of the delinquent rate and all penalties and costs of collection
including a reasonable attorney fee.
   G.   Collection With Utility Charges Of LCUD: Where the person charged is a
user of another utility owned and operated by LCUD, the charges may be billed
and collected together.
   H.   Checks And Electronic Funds Transfers Not Honored By Bank: Checks and
electronic funds transfers presented in payment of bills which are returned by
a bank shall be treated as though no payment had been made, and an
administrative charge as established by the board will be levied by the LCUD,
plus any additional charges levied by the bank. Redemption of returned checks
may be required to be by cash or equivalent. The customer must reimburse the
LCUD for any returned check/electronic funds transfer fees charged by a bank to
the LCUD.
   I.   Service Charges: Any users of the LCUD's sewage facilities shall pay to
the LCUD a sewer service charge established by the board. (Ord. 507, 1-18-2007)
   J.   Multi-Unit Residential Accounts: The base charge for multi- unit
residential accounts using common meters shall be determined by multiplying the
number of units by the multi-family residential rate. No adjustment will be
made for vacant units. (Ord. 568, 7-3-2014)
   K.   Review Of Sewer Service Charges: The board of commissioners may
annually review the service charges set by resolution and determine if the
charges are adequate to meet the costs of operating the sewer system.
   L.   Call Out Service Charges: A customer requesting LCUD assistance with
owner related sewer issues (i.e., blockage, backup on owner's sewer service
line, sewer line tracing, etc.) may be charged for actual costs, labor and
materials at the discretion of the utilities director.
   M.   Protests To Rates And Charges: If any owner shall be dissatisfied with
any sewer charge imposed, he may file a written protest with the utilities
director setting forth his/her objections, provided such protest is filed
within fifteen (15) working days of receipt of the bill being protested.
If the owner is not satisfied with the utilities director's decision, the owner
may appeal that decision to the county manager in writing within five (5)
working days. The county manager shall, within fifteen (15) working days, make
a determination in writing.
If the protester is dissatisfied with the county manager's decision, he/she may
appeal to the board, provided such written appeal is filed within ten (10) days
of receipt of the county manager's decision.
The board, upon receipt of a protest, shall fix a time and place for a hearing
of said protest which shall not be later than thirty (30) calendar days after
receipt of same and cause the protesters to be notified thereof.
Upon the hearing, the board may adjust the sewer charge if it is satisfied with
the reasons and basis of the protest. Action taken on any protest shall be
entered in the minutes of the board.
The protester shall have fifteen (15) calendar days after determination of the
protest by the board within which to pay his/her sewer charge before any
penalty or interest shall be attached or imposed, notwithstanding any other
provision of this chapter concerning the imposition of penalty and interest
charges. (Ord. 507, 1-18-2007)
9.05.14: DISCONNECTION:
   A.   Customer's Request For Discontinuance Of Service: A customer may have
service discontinued by giving not less than two (2) working days' advance
notice, in writing, to LCUD. Sewer base rates shall only be ceased for
"seasonal offs" lasting more than one billing period. Base fees for partial
months in seasonal off status will not be prorated.
In cases of demolition the laterals are to be capped at the main, unless the
laterals are approved for future use by LCUD.
   B.   Discontinuance Of Service By LCUD:
      1.   For Nonpayment Of Bills: A customer's sewer service may be
discontinued for nonpayment of a bill for service furnished if the account
becomes delinquent, provided the LCUD has given the customer at least forty
eight (48) hours' prior notice by mailer or door tag of such intention and the
parcel is not covered under section
9.05.13 of this chapter. During the discontinuance for nonpayment, any
structures will be red tagged by the building department and shall be
uninhabitable.
Premises to which charges have become delinquent may be disconnected, and in
the instance of sewer charges only being delinquent, water service may be
disconnected. If sewer or water service is disconnected, charges for costs,
labor and materials of discontinuing and resuming service as determined by the
utilities director shall apply and must be paid in full prior to resuming
service.
      2.   For Noncompliance With Rules: The LCUD may discontinue water and/or
sewer service to any customer for violation of these rules after it has given
the customer at least two (2) days' written notice.
Where safety of water supply or environment is endangered, or the discharge to
the sewer is dangerous to public health and safety or may cause damage to the
POTW, service may be discontinued or curtailed immediately without notice.
      3.   For Infiltration Or Illegal Connections: Where negligence,
infiltration, illegal connection or discharge of harmful wastes into the
collection system, on or from a customer's premises occurs, LCUD may make such
corrections as may be required at customer's expense or disconnect service, if
such practices are not remedied within five (5) days after the LCUD has given
the customer written notice.
      4.   For Fraudulent Use Of Service: When the LCUD has discovered that a
customer has obtained service by fraudulent means, connected to the sewer
without payment of connection fees, going through the permit process, or has
altered the sewer service for unauthorized use, the service to that customer
may be discontinued without notice and charges may be filed under Nevada
Revised Statutes 704.800. The LCUD will not restore service to such customer
until that customer has complied with the requirements of the LCUD and the LCUD
has been reimbursed for the full amount of the service rendered and the actual
cost of the LCUD incurred by reason of the fraudulent use. If the customer
fails to reimburse LCUD for all costs for services provided by fraudulent use
within the specified time frame, LCUD may file a lien on the property, or
