   B.   Other Constituents: In addition to the listed constituents and toxic
effluent standards promulgated by the U.S. environmental protection agency,
other identified constituents (organic or inorganic) shall not be discharged to
the county's sewer system in excess of the constituent's federally promulgated
maximum contaminant level (MCL), water quality criteria standards, or published
toxicity levels. Discharge of identified constituents in excess of the
federally promulgated maximum contaminant level (MCL), water quality criteria
standards, or published toxicity levels may be approved upon demonstration to
the ECA by a professional engineer registered in Nevada that the proposed
constituent discharge concentration achieved by the implementation of best
management practices (BMP) and best available technology (BAT) shall not have
significant impact, either singly or in combination with other waters, on the
treatment or collection system. (Ord. 505, 1-18-2007)
9.06.32: INDUSTRIAL WASTEWATER TREATMENT SURCHARGE:
   A.   An industrial wastewater treatment surcharge is paid to the county on a
monthly basis by those industrial wastewater dischargers whose contribution of
BOD5 and total suspended solids (TSS) create costs in excess of the value of
their sewer service charges. The individual waste discharge is considered as
creating cost in excess of the value of their sewer service charges when the
concentration of BOD5 and TSS exceed the following:
      BOD5   - 275 mg/l
      TSS   - 200 mg/l
   The treatment surcharge is based on the appropriate county sewerage system's
total maintenance, operation, and capital expenditures for providing industrial
wastewater collection, treatment and disposal services as described in section
9.06.33 of this chapter. The annual industrial wastewater treatment surcharge
is computed by the following formula:
   Rate (in $/1,000 gallons of water consumption) =
   {'{'}(R1 + [(R2)(C2)(8.34)]/1000 + [(R3)(C3)(8.34)]/1000{'}'}/1000(Z)
   Where:
      R1   =   Unit costs associated with wastewater flow in $/MG per year.
      R2   =   Unit costs associated with BOD5 in $/1,000 lb. per year.
      R3   =   Unit costs associated with TSS in $/1,000 lb. per year.
      C2   =   BOD5 concentration in mg/l.
      C3   =   TSS concentration in mg/l.
      Z   =   The estimated ratio between wastewater flow and water
consumption.
   B.   The quantity for total flow is the quantity of water measured at the
water meter. Where no meter exists, the surcharge will be calculated based on
nine hundred fifty (950) gallons per month per fixture unit.
   The quantities for BOD5 and TSS for certain classes of users shall be based
on typical strengths as listed herein:
 
                            BOD5 (mg/l)   Total Suspended
                                           Solids (mg/l)
                                         
Commercial laundry              450          240
Hotel with dining facilities    500          300
Mortuaries                      800          800
Restaurants                     1,000        300
Wholesale bakery                1,000        600
 
   The quantities of BOD5 and TSS for other industrial discharges are
established by sampling and analysis as specified by the ECA in the permit
issued pursuant to sections 9.06.02 through 9.06.20 of this chapter. (Ord. 505,
1-18-2007)
CHAPTER 7
DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS 1
SECTION:
9.07.01: General Information
9.07.02: Improvement Plan Requirements
9.07.03: Design Requirements
9.07.04: Backflow Prevention
9.07.05: Grease Interception And Trash Containment
9.07.06: Sand/Oil Interception And Containment
9.07.07: Industrial Pretreatment Program
9.07.08: Wellhead Protection
 
Notes
  1. Private systems, general improvement districts, special districts and
  cities may recognize codes, design standards and details that are different
1 from what is cited in this chapter. Developers must contact those local
  service providers to determine what development standards will apply to
  developments within the boundaries of the specific service area.
9.07.01: GENERAL INFORMATION:
   A.   Water And Sewer: Water and sewer mains shall be extended for the
following:
      1.   Parcel map development with a property line within four hundred feet
(400') of an existing water or sewer main or as otherwise required in these
standards. Prior to recording a parcel map, the owner/developer shall submit
improvement plans to the service provider and the Lyon County engineer. The
owner/developer shall be responsible for the construction of the water and/or
sewer mains. A licensed class A contractor must be used for water/sewer
infrastructure installation.
      2.   Water and sewer mains shall be extended the entire frontage(s) of
the parcel unless engineering analysis determines it is physically impossible
to do so or it is determined by the service provider that further extension of
the main beyond the parcel can never occur or it is not necessary for
continuity of the system. In such cases, the length of extension shall be
determined by the service provider or designee. Construction of a single-family
residence on a parcel not associated with a subdivision, planned unit
development (PUD) or parcel map development and currently served by an existing
main shall not require extension of the main(s). Construction of a single-
family residence on a corner lot not associated with a subdivision, PUD or
parcel map development shall require extension along one street frontage only.
      3.   The owner or developer will supply a water model that will identify
possible locations of insufficient capacity. Any shortfalls will be addressed
by the developer's engineer. The developer shall be responsible for main
extensions when the design capacity of existing mains is less than that
required to serve a development. Mains shall be extended when existing mains
are physically inaccessible to maintenance crews and equipment, as determined
by the service provider.
      4.   For the purposes of administering these standards for main
extensions and replacements, "developments" are defined as follows:
         a.   Subdivisions, PUDs, parcel map developments;
         b.   New building construction;
         c.   Multi-family, commercial and industrial additions or remodels,
which may result in an increase in the historical water usage or sewer
contribution for the parcel.
      5.   Reclaimed water mains shall not be required to be extended if the
parcel does not receive connection. Connection to reclaimed water mains
requires the developer to obtain approval from local, state agencies and the
service provider.
   B.   Reimbursement Agreements: The owner/developer may apply to the service
provider for future reimbursement from adjacent property owners, which connect
to the main extension per the provisions established by the service provider.
The service provider shall process the developer's application and, upon
approval of a reimbursement agreement by the respective board, the agreement
shall be administered by the respective board.
   C.   Participation In Oversizing Mains: When the oversizing of mains has
been requested by the service provider, the development shall participate in
the installation of oversized water and sewer mains as per the provisions of
this code. (Ord. 506, 1-18-2007)
9.07.02: IMPROVEMENT PLAN REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Main Extensions And Fire Lines: Improvement plans for water, sewer and
reclaimed water main extensions, public and private fire hydrant installations,
and fire sprinkler line installations shall conform to the following
requirements:
      1.   Sewer service lateral sizes and water service line, curb and
corporation stop sizes for subdivision and parcel map development shall be
shown by note on each plan/profile sheet.
      2.   Plans shall indicate dimensions from street centerline or control
line to all existing and proposed mains. All valves, hydrants, flush valve
assemblies, air release valves, manholes and laterals shall be stationed and
dimensioned from street centerline or control line.
      3.   Plans shall indicate proposed use of meter; i.e., domestic or
irrigation.
      4.   Plans shall indicate whether the water service lateral shall be
installed by a properly licensed contractor or by the service provider. (Ord.
506, 1-18-2007)
9.07.03: DESIGN REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Water And Reclaimed Water Design Criteria:
      1.   Main Analysis: Water mains shall be analyzed to determine system
capability to provide adequate flows and pressures. The analysis and
calculations shall be provided to the service provider for review and approval.
Water mains shall be designed to deliver a minimum of sixty (60) pounds per
square inch (psi) at the meter during peak demand periods, a maximum of one
hundred (100) psi, and to provide adequate fire flow as required by the fire
department with a minimum residual pressure of twenty (20) psi. If the project
is an infill development where the existing system is incapable of providing
sixty (60) psi, the service provider may waive the requirement.
Subdivisions, PUDs and large commercial or industrial projects having a
significant impact on the service provider water system as determined by the
service provider shall provide an update of the water model using a format that
is compatible with the current model.
New construction or remodels adjacent to the existing public water system where
little or no additional system improvements are required must provide a report
with current date, project address (with location map), APN number, permit
number, if available, comparing the required fire flow established by the fire
department and the available flow obtained by the actual fire flow data sheet,
which shall be approved.
The report shall address system pressures at the project location to ensure
sixty (60) psi is available at all water meters during peak day demands.
Reclaimed water systems must meet the requirements found in the 2006 or most
current version of the LCUD reclaimed water standards unless a specific
standard has been accepted by the service provider and approved by NDEP for a
specific development.
      2.   Main Size And Material: Mains shall be sized as required by flow
calculations, however, the minimum water main diameter shall be eight inches
(8") unless the service provider approves otherwise.
Water mains shall be PVC C-900 CL 150 or 200 (as required by operating
pressure) unless otherwise required and approved by the service provider.
Reclaimed water (RCW) mains shall be PVC C-900 CL 150 or 200, RCW pipe must be
purple, unless otherwise required and approved by the service provider.
      3.   Standard Details: The installation of all new water and reclaimed
water lines shall conform to the standard details for public works construction
as adopted by the service provider.
      4.   Meters: Each building shall be served by a separate water service
and meter unless otherwise approved by the service provider. All meters shall
be located within the street right of way or in a public utilities easement
(PUE) parallel and adjacent to the street right of way unless otherwise
approved by the service provider. Meters shall not be located within the
driving surface.
Meter sizes available include:
      5/8 inch
      3/4 inch
      1 inch
      11/2 inch
      2 inch
      3 inch
      4 inch
      6 inch
      8 inch
      10 inch
      12 inch
      5.   Services: Services shall be located as per the standard details
unless otherwise approved by the service provider. Reclaimed water meter boxes
shall be manufactured purple. All services, except those located in cul-de-
sacs, shall be installed perpendicular to the main.
Service lines may be:
      3/4 inch
      1 inch
      11/2 inch
      2 inch
      3 inch
      4 inch
      6 inch
      8 inch
      10 inch
      12 inch
A three inch (3") service requires a four inch (4") gate valve with a four inch
(4") line. See the service provider standard details. Service lines must be
sized to accommodate any required fire sprinkler systems. Fire systems must be
approved by the local fire department and meet the requirements of NFPA 13.
      6.   Valves: Water valves on distribution mains shall be spaced at
intervals not to exceed five hundred feet (500') unless approved otherwise by
the service provider. Reclaimed water valves shall be spaced at intervals not
to exceed one thousand three hundred twenty feet (1,320') with service provider
approval. No point within the system being designed shall require more than
three (3) valve closures to discontinue service. Valves shall be located so
that no more than fifteen (15) customers are taken out of service at any one
time. Valves shall be placed a minimum of twenty feet (20') from the end of all
mains, which may be extended in the future unless there is no possibility of
future connections as determined by the service provider. See standard details
titled "Valve Detail And Valve Box Detail".
Reclaimed water valves shall not be located at intersections without approval
by the service provider.
All existing valves necessary to isolate the section of main to be extended
shall be shown on the plans.
      7.   Flush Valve Assemblies: A four inch (4") flush valve assembly or
fire hydrant is required at the end of all pressurized dead end water mains and
stubs longer than ten feet (10') as per the standard detail titled "Flush Valve
Assembly".
      8.   Fire Hydrants: Fire hydrants within a subdivision shall be spaced as
approved by the fire department. Fire hydrants and their associated valve shall
be shown on the plans and constructed as per the standard detail titled "Fire
Hydrant Assembly Detail". The service provider may require a particular
manufacturer, model number and color. A fire hydrant maintenance agreement
between the service provider and fire district may be required.
      9.   Check Valves: Backflow assemblies or check valves may be required on
all private fire hydrant lines per the standard details. Pressure loss
associated with all check valves shall be included in fire flow calculations.
Backflow assemblies shall be installed on the customer's side of the right of
way line unless otherwise approved by the service provider. When a PUE is
parallel to the right of way line, the check valve shall be installed on the
customer's side of the PUE.
      10.   Backflow Assemblies: Double check valve assemblies shall be
installed on all private fire sprinkler lines as per the standard detail titled
"Detail For Double Check Valve Assemblies". Fire systems utilizing chemicals
require a reduced pressure backflow assembly. Pressure loss associated with all
backflow assemblies shall be included in fire flow calculations. The assemblies
shall be tested prior to certificate of occupancy and annually by a certified
AWWA backflow prevention assembly tester as approved by the service provider.
Double check valve assemblies shall be installed on the customer's side of the
right of way line. When a PUE is parallel to the right of way line, the double
check valve assembly shall be installed on the customer's side of the PUE.
Freeze protection may also be required.
      11.   Tapping Sleeves: Tapping sleeves are required when connecting a new
main to an existing main when water service cannot be discontinued. See the
standard detail titled "Tapping Sleeve Detail".
Plans shall include a note indicating that the contractor shall notify the
service provider forty eight (48) hours prior to performing hot taps, either by
fax or mail, and that underground service alert be notified forty eight (48)
hours prior to any excavation.
      12.   Air Release And Vacuum Valves: Air release and/or vacuum valves are
required at all high points in water mains unless adequate relief is provided
and approved by the service provider. See the standard detail titled "Air-
Release Valve Detail". Air release/vacuum valves are required at all high
points in pressurized mains and shall be spaced at two thousand six hundred
foot (2,600') maximum intervals, regardless of whether high points exist in the
main, unless otherwise approved by the service provider. Provide calculations
for sizing air release/vacuum valves for review and approval by the service
provider.
      13.   Separations: Minimum horizontal separation between water lines and
sewer, storm drain and reclaimed water lines shall be ten feet (10'). Minimum
horizontal separation from all other utilities shall be five feet (5'). Minimum
vertical separation shall be eighteen inches (18") unless otherwise approved by
the service provider. See the Lyon County standard detail titled "Typical
Utility Trench".
      14.   Lowering Water Mains: Water mains in conflict with sewer, storm
drain and reclaimed water lines shall be adjusted as per the standard detail
titled "Lowering Water Mains". Other means for separation, such as designing
with vertical curves, shall require approval of the service provider. When
pipelines are deeper than prescribed in Lyon County standard detail LC-W5 or by
the service provider, larger easements may be required on a proportionate basis
to accommodate future access for repairs and/or maintenance.
      15.   Air Gap Separation: Private receiving tanks require an air gap and
shall be installed as per the standard detail titled "Installation For Air-Gap
Separation". The service provider must approve all installations.
      16.   Reduced Pressure Assemblies: Reduced pressure assemblies shall be
per the standard detail titled "Detail For Reduced Pressure Principle
Assemblies" and are required per table 1, "Type Of Backflow Protection
Required", of this chapter. Approval from the service provider is required
prior to installation. These assemblies shall be tested prior to certificate of
occupancy by a certified AWWA backflow prevention assembly tester as approved
by the service provider. (Table 1 may be superseded by a state approved cross
connection control program specific to the service provider.)
      17.   Thrust Blocks: Thrust blocks are required on all new water and
reclaimed water main installations, public and private fire hydrants, and
sprinkler line installations and shall be constructed as shown in the standard
detail titled "Thrust Block Bearing Areas". Restrained joint pipe may be used
in lieu of thrust blocks if approved by the service provider.
      18.   Sampling Stations: Water sampling stations must be installed within
new subdivisions and must be approved along with location, by the service
provider.
   B.   Sewer Design Criteria:
      1.   Main Analysis: Sewer mains shall be analyzed to determine system
capability to provide capacity for the ultimate tributary population with the
calculations provided to the service provider. Projects with less than ten (10)
dwelling units or less than two hundred (200) fixture units are exempt from
these criteria. Flow generation and peaking factors shall be per recommended
standards for wastewater facilities (ten state standards). Sewer mains are
considered at capacity when peak flow is at d/D=0.75. Main analysis shall
include a narrative report submitted to the service provider with maps and
calculations addressing the following:
         a.   Area of project;
         b.   Tributary areas outside project;
         c.   Adjacent areas;
         d.   Contours usually extending a minimum of three hundred feet (300')
beyond the project or as needed to evaluate localized tributary areas;
         e.   Line layout, pipe size and slope;
         f.   Predicted average and peak flows at major junction points
including flow coming from outside the project area;
         g.   Direction of flow;
         h.   Zoning used to predict flows;
         i.   Special areas such as hospitals, schools, large office or
industrial buildings, etc.;
         j.   Boundaries of areas within the project which are tributary to
points of major flow;
         k.   Floodplains;
         l.   Scale;
         m.   Predicted flow from each area;
         n.   Peaking factors;
         o.   Cumulative flow;
         p.   Pipe capacities and depths of flow.
      2.   Sewer Size And Lateral: The minimum size for sewer mains shall be
eight inches (8") and laterals shall be four inches (4") unless otherwise
approved by the service provider. Mains shall be sized as required by flow
calculations. Sewer lines shall be PVC SDR-35 unless otherwise approved by the
service provider.
      3.   Standard Details: The installation of all new sewer lines shall
conform to the standard details for public works construction, as adopted by
the service provider. When pipelines are deeper than prescribed in Lyon County
standard detail LC-W5 or by the service provider, larger easements may be
required on a proportionate basis to accommodate future access for repairs and/
or maintenance.
      4.   Service Lateral: Each parcel shall be served by a separate sewer
service lateral unless otherwise approved by the service provider.
Sewer service laterals shall be located as per the standard detail titled
"Typical Utility Laterals Locations", unless otherwise approved by the service
provider. See standard details titled "Sewer Lateral Connection Detail And
Sewer Service Saddle Detail". All service laterals, except those located in
cul-de-sacs, shall be installed perpendicular to the main.
Sewer service laterals are not to be connected to manholes without prior
approval of the service provider. Laterals six inches (6") and over shall be
connected to a manhole.
      5.   Design Velocity: The design velocity shall be two feet (2') per
second (fps) minimum, ten feet (10') per second (fps) maximum for the design
condition.
      6.   Manning's Formula: The Manning's formula:
   V = 1.49(R2/3 S1/2) n
shall be used in determining slope, velocity, design flow and diameter.
Manning's "n" shall be 0.013 for PVC pipe.
      7.   Slope: Minimum pipe slope shall be as required to achieve the
minimum velocity of two feet (2') per second (fps), but shall not be less than
as listed in the table below, unless otherwise approved by the service
provider;
 
Size       Minimum Slope
           
   6 inc   1.0 percent
   8 inc   0.4 percent
   10 in   0.28 percent
   12 in   0.22 percent
   15 in   0.15 percent
 
 
   The design engineer shall submit velocity and depth calculations for sewers
less than minimum slope for review and approval prior to preparation of design
drawings. For pipe slopes less than 0.4 percent, the design engineer shall
place the following note in a prominent location on each plan/profile sheet
with slopes less than 0.4 percent; "The contractor shall use due care in
installing sewer mains". Minimum pipe slope for dead end sewers shall be 0.5
percent unless it can be shown by calculations that the velocity in the pipe is
two (2) fps or greater. Dead end sewers shall generally end in a manhole.
   Dry sewers which shall be extended at a future date and installed without a
manhole shall be certified as built for line and grade by a Nevada professional
engineer or land surveyor prior to backfill. The engineer shall place a note in
a prominent location on each plan/profile sheet including the as built
requirement. A cleanout may be allowed at the end of the line if approved by
the service provider. Cleanout shall be no smaller than six inches (6").
      8.   Sanitary Sewer Design Standards And Specifications; Alignment:
         a.   Horizontal: Sewer lines less than twenty four inches (24") in
diameter shall be straight between manholes and generally parallel with the
street or easement centerline whenever possible.
         Sewer lines twenty four inches (24") and larger may be considered for
horizontal curvature when approved by the service provider.
         b.   Vertical: Sewer lines with vertical curvature shall not be
allowed.
      9.   Sanitary Sewer Design Standards And Specifications; Manholes And
Laterals: Standard manholes shall be installed at the end of each line with
continuing stub-out; at all intersections of other sewer lines; at all changes
in grade, size or alignment.
         a.   Spacing: Maximum spacing for manholes shall be four hundred feet
(400') for all lines smaller than fifteen inches (15"), and five hundred feet
(500') for lines fifteen inches (15") to twenty four inches (24") and six
hundred feet (600') for twenty four inches (24") and larger, or as required by
the service provider.
         b.   Increasing Size: When a smaller sewer flows into a larger sewer,
the invert of the larger sewer shall be lowered sufficiently to maintain the
same energy gradient. An appropriate method for obtaining this result is to
place the crown at the same elevation for both pipes. The average energy
gradient line shall be derived from anticipated full flow capacities of the
pipes.
         c.   Drop Manholes: A drop connection shall be provided for a sewer
entering a manhole at an elevation two feet (2') or more above the manhole
invert. When the difference in elevation between the incoming sewer and the
manhole invert is less than two feet (2'), the manhole invert shall be filleted
and channeled to prevent deposition of solids. The drop connection shall be
constructed in accordance with the standard detail requirements for manhole
installation. Supporting calculations for hydraulic efficiency through manholes
that do not meet the above requirements shall be submitted to the service
provider for approval. Drop manholes shall be forty eight inches (48") in
diameter, unless otherwise approved by the service provider.
         d.   General: Manholes shall be installed at the end of all sewer
mains, at all intersections of mains, and changes of grade, size, or alignment.
One foot (1') stubs shall be provided at manholes for sewer mains which may be
extended in the future. When extending a sewer main from an existing manhole
without a stub, the existing manhole base shall be removed and replaced, unless
coring is approved by the service provider. Sewer mains entering manholes shall
have a minimum one-tenth (0.1) of a foot of fall across the manhole and a
maximum two- tenths (0.2) of a foot of fall across the manhole. Two-tenths
(0.2) of a foot of fall may be exceeded when matching crowns of different pipe
diameters. Manholes with the angle between the entering sewer main and existing
sewer main less than seventy five degrees (75°) shall be sixty inches (60")
diameter and maintain two-tenths (0.2) of a foot of fall.
   Watertight manhole covers shall be used.
         e.   Dead End Sewers: Dead end sewers shall generally end in a
manhole. Dry sewers which shall be extended at a future date and installed
without a manhole shall be certified as built for line and grade by a Nevada
professional engineer or land surveyor prior to backfill. A cleanout may be
required by the service provider.
         f.   Prior to any extension or connection to the existing system, a
mechanical type pipe plug must be installed in a manhole to prevent flows from
entering existing system from new system until new system has been tested and
accepted. Service provider will inspect all plug installations.
      10.   Separation Of Lines:
         a.   Definitions: As used in the Nevada administrative code (NAC),
chapter 445A, unless the context otherwise requires:
   SEWER MAIN: Includes:
            (1) A sewer main of a sanitary sewer, storm sewer or any other type
of sewer; and
            (2) Any unidentified conduit with a diameter that exceeds six
inches (6").
   SEWER SERVICE LATERAL: Includes:
            (1) A sewer service lateral of a sanitary sewer, storm sewer or any
other type of sewer; and
            (2) Any unidentified conduit with a diameter of not more than six
inches (6").
         b.   Sewer Main Parallel To Water Main Or Water Service Lateral: If a
sewer main parallels a water main or water service lateral:
            (1) Whenever possible, the sewer main must be located lower than
the water main or water service lateral.
            (2) Except as otherwise provided in subsection B10b(3) of this
section, the sewer main must be in a separate trench, and
               (A) Located at least ten feet (10') away from the water main or
water service lateral, as measured horizontally from the exterior walls of the
pipes;
               (B) If compliance with subsection B10b(2)(A) of this section is
not practicable, located:
                  (i) At least five feet (5') away from the water main or water
service lateral; as measured horizontally from the exterior walls of the pipes;
and
                  (ii) At least eighteen inches (18") lower than the water main
or water service lateral, as measured vertically from the exterior walls of the
pipes; or
               (C) If compliance with neither subsection B10b(2)(A) nor B10b(2)
(B) of this section is practicable, located at least six feet (6') away from
the water main or water service lateral, as measured horizontally from the
exterior walls of the pipes. If the sewer main:
                  (i) Is in place at the time a water project is performed, the
sewer main must, except as otherwise provided in subsection B10b(2)(C)(iii) of
this section, be totally encased in at least four inches (4") of cement slurry;
                  (ii) Is not in place at the time a water project is
performed, the sewer main must, except as otherwise provided in subsection B10b
(2)(C)(iii) of this section, be constructed of PVC with joints that comply with
Standard D3212 of the American Society for Testing and Materials; or
                  (iii) Is part of a storm sewer and has a diameter of not less
than twenty four inches (24"), the sewer main must be installed with watertight
joints that use joint sealants or joint gaskets.
            (3) If compliance with the requirements for separation set forth in
subsection B10b(2) of this section are not practicable:
               (A) The water main or water service lateral must be encased in
at least four inches (4") of cement slurry; and
               (B) The sewer main must comply with the requirements of
subsections B10b(2)(C)(i), B10b(2)(C)(ii) and B10b(2)(C)(iii) of this section.
         c.   Sewer Service Lateral Parallel To Water Main Or Water Service
Lateral: If a sewer service lateral parallels a water main or water service
lateral, the sewer service lateral must be in a separate trench, and
            (1) Located:
               (A) At least twelve inches (12") lower than the water main or
water service lateral, as measured vertically from the exterior walls of the
pipes; and
               (B) At least forty eight inches (48") away from the water main
or water service lateral, as measured horizontally from the exterior walls of
the pipes; or
            (2) If compliance with subsection B10c(1) of this section is
impracticable, located in such a manner as is authorized by the health
division.
         d.   Sewer Main Crossing Water Main: If a sewer main crosses a water
main:
            (1) The sewer main must be located at least eighteen inches (18")
lower than the water main, as measured vertically from the exterior walls of
the pipes; or
            (2) If compliance with subsection B10d(1) of this section is
impracticable:
               (A) A reasonable effort must be made to place the pipeline
joints of the sewer main and water main, other than any welded joints, an equal
distance from the point of crossing;
               (B) The sewer main and water main must be:
                  (i) Located at least six inches (6") apart, as measured
vertically from the exterior of the pipes; and
                  (ii) Provided with such structural support as the supplier of
water determines necessary; and
               (C) The area of crossing must be constructed in such a manner
that:
                  (i) The sewer main is constructed of materials that comply
with "Standard Specifications For Public Works Construction" and the American
Water Works Association standards for water system materials;
                  (ii) The sewer main consists of PVC which is constructed with
joints that comply with standard D3212 of the American Society for Testing and
Materials;
                  (iii) The sewer main or water main is totally encased in at
least four inches (4") of cement slurry for a distance of at least ten feet
(10') on each side of the point of crossing; or
                  (iv) The sewer main or water main is installed in a pipe
sleeve that extends, without joints, at least ten feet (10') on each side of
the point of crossing.
         e.   Sewer Main Crossing Water Service Lateral:
            (1) If a sewer main crosses a water service lateral, the sewer main
must be located:
               (A) At least eighteen inches (18") lower than the water service
lateral, as measured vertically from the exterior walls of the pipes; or
               (B) If compliance with subsection B10e(1)(A) of this section is
impracticable, in such a manner as is authorized by the health division.
            (2) If a water service lateral is in place at the time a sewer main
is constructed and must be relocated to comply with this section, the
relocation must be performed:
               (A) With the approval of the supplier of water; or
               (B) If compliance with subsection B10e(2)(A) of this section is
impracticable, in such a manner as is authorized by the health division.
         f.   Sewer Service Lateral Crossing Water Main Or Water Service
Lateral:
            (1) If a sewer service lateral crosses a water main or water
service lateral, the sewer service lateral must be located:
               (A) At least twelve inches (12") lower than the water main or
water service lateral, as measured vertically from the exterior walls of the
pipes; or
               (B) If compliance with subsection B10f(1)(A) of this section is
impracticable, in such a manner as is authorized by the health division.
            (2) If a water main or water service lateral is in place at time a
sewer service lateral is constructed and must be relocated to comply with this
section, the relocation must be performed:
               (A) With the approval of and in accordance with the procedures
and standards of the supplier of water; or
               (B) If compliance with subsection B10f(2)(A) of this section is
impracticable, in such a manner as is authorized by the health division. (Added
to NAC by board of health, effective February 20, 1997.)
         g.   Lines Across Surface Water:
            (1) A supplier of water shall consult with the health authority
before preparing any plans for the construction of a pipeline of the public
water system across any surface water, regardless of whether the crossing will
be over or under the surface of the water.
            (2) If the pipeline will cross over the surface of the water, the
pipe must be adequately supported and anchored, protected from damage and
freezing, and accessible for repair and replacement.
            (3) Except as otherwise provided in subsection B10g(4) of this
section, if the pipeline will cross under the surface of the water, the pipe
must be:
               (A) Covered with at least five feet (5') of backfill; and
               (B) Enclosed in a pipe sleeve or encased with at least four
inches (4") of cement slurry.
            (4) If the pipeline will cross under the surface of a channel of
water that is fifteen feet (15') or more wide:
               (A) The pipe must be constructed with watertight mechanical
joints that are capable of deflection.
               (B) Isolation valves must be located at both ends of the
crossing in such a manner that the length of the crossing can be isolated for
testing, repair and sampling. The isolation valves must be easily accessible
and must not be subject to flooding. All installations must be reviewed and
approved by the service provider and the appropriate state entity.
      Water mains in conflict with sewer, storm drain and reclaimed water lines
shall be adjusted as per the standard detail titled "Lowering Water Mains".
Other means for separation shall require approval of the service provider.
      11.   Interceptor Connections: Sewer service laterals shall not be
directly connected to sewer interceptors and sewer service laterals shall not
be directly connected to sewer interceptor manholes without prior approval of
the service provider. A sewer interceptor is defined as any sewer main larger
than twelve inches (12") in diameter, or as determined by the service provider.
Sewer service laterals may be connected to a parallel sewer main that is
connected to an existing interceptor manhole.
      12.   Inverted Siphons: The design of siphons shall not be undertaken
until approved by the service provider. The siphons shall not have less than
two (2) barrels, with a minimum pipe size of eight inches (8"), and shall be
provided with the necessary appurtenances for convenient flushing and
maintenance. The manholes shall have adequate clearances for rodding.
Sufficient head and pipe sizes shall be designed to obtain minimum velocities
of three feet (3') per second for average flow. The inlet and outlet details
shall be arranged so that normal flow is diverted to one barrel and so that
either barrel may be removed from service for cleaning.
      13.   Sewer Main Televising: All sewer mains and laterals shall have a
television inspection prior to acceptance by the service provider and prior to
paving. All sewer mains and manholes shall be clear of debris prior to
televising. Debris shall not be washed into existing sewer mains and shall be
pumped to an approved disposal location or vacuumed.
      14.   Air Testing: Air testing must be completed per "Orange Book"
standard.
      15.   Well Meters: For new development only, private well water meters
are required for property connected to public sewer and not connected to public
water. Meter location and type shall be approved by the service provider prior
to installation.
      16.   Manholes: Vacuum or hydraulic testing may be required by the
service provider.
   C.   Sewer Lift/Pump Stations:
      1.   General Requirements: Because of the complex technical detail of the
lift stations, the service provider must approve all designs. Lyon County
utility department's standard details for lift station construction may also be
accepted. The standards below are basic.
   These standards apply only to those facilities to be owned and operated by
the service provider. The use of sewage lift stations or pump stations is
allowed only where gravity flows are infeasible. The service provider or
designee shall determine if a lift/pump station is to be owned and operated by
the service provider. The design of stations to be owned and operated by the
service provider is subject to approval by the service provider.
   Special design consideration shall be given to match existing systems and
equipment as determined by the service provider. Lift stations shall not have
any areas requiring routine or preventative maintenance, or normal operations,
designated as a confined space.
   All stations shall generally conform to the following:
      2.   Flows: The pumping system including the discharge piping and mains
shall be designed for a minimum of one hundred ten percent (110%) of the
capacity of the tributary system leading to the station. The capacity shall be
based on peak hour volumes.
      3.   Pumps: No fewer than two (2) pumps shall be provided. When only two
(2) pumps are used, each pump shall pump the capacity of the system.
   For stations with more than two (2) pumps, there shall be a standby pump
with the capacity of the largest unit.
   Pumps shall be designed to operate automatically in alternate cycles with
the idle pump in each cycle to function as standby. Pumps shall be specifically
designed for the conveyance of wastewater.
   Pumps in a dry well/wet well application shall be equipped with motors that
are premium efficiency with TEFC enclosures; double mechanical seals with
external flushing water; seal water systems shall meet service provider
requirements (a standby seal water pump shall be provided).
      4.   Flow Metering: The pump station shall have one magnetic flow meter
with 4-20 MA output installed on the pressure main in a suitable watertight
vault.
      5.   Piping: Dry well/wet well piping applications shall be ductile iron
with grooved or flanged joints.
   Any fasteners used for joining pipes shall be stainless steel. Pump
isolation valves shall be eccentric or full port plug valves. Swing check
valves shall be provided on each pump discharge. The individual pump discharge
shall connect into the main header horizontally to prevent grit buildup in the
check valve. Sewage air relief valves are required at high points in the
discharge line.
      6.   Wet Well: Openings to wet wells shall be sealed to prevent the
escape of gasses. All surfaces of wet wells shall be HDPE lined to prevent
concrete corrosion. Steel used in wet wells shall be stainless. Wet well sizing
shall be in accordance with the "Hydraulic Institute Standards", latest issue.
The wet well shall be sized for no greater than four (4) pump starts per hour
to prevent motor overheating. Openings between the wet well and dry well shall
be sealed gastight.
      7.   Dry Well: Dry well access shall be by straight stairs unless
otherwise approved by the service provider or designee. The dry well shall
contain two (2) sump pumps with one pump on the floor out of the sump. Each
sump pump shall be capable of pumping fifty (50) gallons per minute. The dry
well layout shall allow for wastewater pump removal through a hatch at the
ground level over each pump. The layout shall allow for personnel access to all
sides of the installed equipment. The dry well shall contain an auxiliary space
heater, station dehumidifying unit, and venting fan. Individual equipment
lockouts are required for all motorized equipment. Fall protection must also be
provided for.
      8.   Ventilation: Ventilation shall be in accordance with the latest
edition of NFPA 820, fire protection in wastewater treatment and collection
facilities.
      9.   Flood Protection: Access to all spaces, all electrical panels, and
motors shall be at an elevation above or protected from a 100-year flood.
      10.   Standby Power: A standby generator shall be provided capable of
automatically running the entire station's load if power fails due to a sensed
high or low voltage on any of three (3) legs of four hundred eighty (480) volt
power. The generator shall be located in a weather protective, soundproofed
(hospital rated), vandal proof and lockable housing with access to all engine
and generator components for servicing and maintenance. The generator shall be
fueled by diesel with an aboveground, vandal proof storage tank with a capacity
to provide a forty eight (48) hour continuous run time. The generator engine
block shall be equipped with a block heater and thermostat that shall allow for
instantaneous startup at minus thirty degrees Fahrenheit (-30°F). The engine
shall be protected with shutdown safeguards, gauges and indicator lamps for
over temperature, low oil pressure, over speed and over crank. The engine shall
be equipped with an automatic battery charger, installed on the hot side of the
transfer switch enabling the battery to maintain its charge when idle.
      11.   Applicable Design Codes: The following list of codes and standards
are to be followed as a minimum, unless otherwise approved by the service
provider and/or NDEP:
         a.   International building code (latest edition or as adopted by
service provider);
         b.   Uniform plumbing code (latest edition as adopted by service
provider);
         c.   Uniform mechanical code (latest edition as adopted by service
provider);
         d.   International fire code (latest edition as adopted by service
provider);
         e.   National electrical code (latest edition as adopted by service
provider);
         f.   NFPA article 820 (latest edition as adopted by service provider);
         g.   National fire code (latest edition as adopted by service
provider);
         h.   Occupational safety and health standards (latest edition as
adopted by service provider);
         i.   Hydraulic Institute standards (latest edition as adopted by
service provider);
         j.   Great Lakes-Upper Mississippi River board of state and provincial
public health and environmental managers standards for wastewater facilities
(ten state standards) (latest edition as adopted by service provider).
      12.   Controls: All controls and telemetry shall be above surface grade
in suitable lockable and vandal proof housings. Wastewater pump activation
shall be by SCADA pack control and transducer with high level backup float.
      13.   Alarms: Alarm system shall be of a radio telemetry type and shall
include a sending unit at the lift station and a receiving unit at a designated
facility. The telemetry system shall be compatible and of like type with those
units presently in use at the wastewater reclamation facility or as determined
by the service provider. As a minimum, the following alarms shall be provided:
         a.   High wet well;
         b.   Flooded dry well;
         c.   Loss of power;
         d.   Loss of seal water;
         e.   Wastewater pump failure (by check valve limit switch in addition
to motor overload);
         f.   Low level;
         g.   Generator status.
      14.   Electrical Components: In addition to the requirements of NFPA 820
and the national electric code, electrical enclosures shall be NEMA 4X,
stainless steel out of doors and NEMA 4X fiberglass in dry wells and wet wells
as a minimum. Conduits and boxes located in wet wells shall be PVC coated.
      15.   Land: Suitable land area for the lift station installation and
operation including access shall be provided by dedication to the service
provider. (Ord. 506, 1-18-2007)
9.07.04: BACKFLOW PREVENTION1:
   A.   Type Of Protection Required2: The type of protection that shall be
provided to prevent backflow into the approved water supply shall be
commensurate with the degree of hazard that exists on the consumer's premises.
The minimum types of backflow protection required to protect the approved water
supply, at the user's water connection are given in NAC 445(a), or local
ordinances. Situations which are not covered in the table shall be evaluated on
a case by case basis and the appropriate backflow protection shall be
determined by the service provider.
   B.   Backflow Prevention Assemblies:
      1.   Approved Backflow Prevention Assemblies:
         a.   Only backflow prevention assemblies which have been approved by
the Foundation for Cross Connection Control and Hydraulic Research (FCCCHR)
shall be acceptable for installation by a water user connected to the service
provider's potable water system.
      2.   Backflow Prevention Assembly Installations:
         a.   Backflow prevention assemblies shall be installed in a manner
prescribed in the standard details. Location of the assemblies shall be as
close as is practical to the user's connection, or at a location approved by
the service provider. The service provider shall have the final authority in
determining the required location of a backflow prevention assembly. There
shall be no connections between the meter and the backflow device.
            (1) Air Gap Separation (AG): The air gap separation shall be
located on the user's side of and as close to the service connection as is
practical. All piping from the service connection to the receiving tank shall
be above grade and be entirely visible. No water use shall be provided from any
point between the service connection and the air gap separation. The water
inlet piping shall terminate a distance of at least two (2) pipe diameters from
the supply inlet, but in no case less than one inch (1") above the overflow rim
of the receiving tank.
            (2) Reduced Pressure Principle Backflow Prevention Assembly (RP):
The approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly shall be
installed on the user's side of the service connection. The assembly shall be
installed in accordance with the standard details. The assembly shall be
installed so that it is readily accessible for maintenance and testing. Water
supplied from any point between the service connection and the RP assembly
shall be protected in a manner approved by the service provider. Freeze
protection may be required.
            (3) Double Check Valve Assembly (DC): The approved double check
valve assembly shall be located on the user's side of the connection, and in a
manner where it is readily accessible for testing and maintenance. If a double
check valve assembly is put below grade it must be installed in accordance with
the standard detail.
      3.   Backflow Prevention Assembly Testing And Maintenance:
         a.   The owners of any premises on which, or on account of which,
backflow prevention assemblies are installed, shall have the assemblies tested
by a current AWWA backflow tester. Backflow prevention assemblies must be
tested at least annually and immediately after installation, relocation or
repair. The service provider may require a more frequent testing schedule. No
assembly shall be placed back in service unless it is functioning as required.
A report in a form acceptable to the service provider must be filed with the
service provider each time an assembly is tested, relocated, or repaired. These
assemblies shall be serviced, overhauled, or replaced whenever they are found
to be defective and all costs of testing, repair, and maintenance shall be
borne by the water user.
         b.   The service provider may supply affected water users with a list
of persons acceptable to the service provider to test backflow prevention
assemblies. The service provider shall notify affected customers by mail when
annual testing of an assembly is required and also supply users with the
necessary forms which must be filled out each time an assembly is tested or
repaired.
         c.   Upon request the service provider may test a water user's
backflow prevention assembly to fulfill the requirements of this section. The
water user shall be charged for the test and any maintenance found necessary to
keep the assembly in working order on the next regular water bill.
      4.   Backflow Prevention Assembly Removals:
         a.   Approval must be obtained from the service provider before a
backflow prevention assembly is removed, relocated, or replaced.
            (1) Removal: The use of an assembly may be discontinued and the
assembly removed from service upon presentation of sufficient evidence to the
service provider to verify that a hazard no longer exists or is not likely to
be created in the future.
            (2) Relocations: An assembly may be relocated, following
confirmation by the service provider that the relocation shall continue to
provide the required protection and satisfy installation requirements. A retest
shall be required following the relocation of the assembly.
            (3) Repair: An assembly may be removed for repair, provided the
water use is either discontinued until repair is completed and the assembly is
returned to service, or the service connection is equipped with other backflow
protection approved by the service provider. A retest shall be required
following the repair of the assembly.
            (4) Replacements: An assembly may be removed and replaced provided
the water use is discontinued until the replacement assembly is installed. All
replacement assemblies must be approved by the service provider and must be
commensurate with the degree of hazard involved, and be approved by FCCCHR. A
test shall be required following the replacement of the assembly.

9.07.05: GREASE INTERCEPTION AND TRASH CONTAINMENT:
   A.   Policy and procedure for approval of grease interceptors and trash
containment drain systems related to food service establishments is presented
in this section.
   B.   All new food service establishments or those being remodeled are
required to:
      1.   Install a grease interceptor sized in accordance with the uniform
plumbing code, appendix H, but must be a minimum of seven hundred fifty (750)
gallons;
      2.   Submit plumbing plans depicting all sewer lines discharging to or
bypassing the grease interceptor; and
      3.   Submit, in writing, to the service provider, all calculations
required by the uniform plumbing code, appendix H, for sizing of the
interceptor as prepared by a Nevada licensed civil engineer.
   C.   Grease interceptors must be easily accessible at all times. If the
interceptor is placed in a drive-through lane, it is the owner's responsibility
to stop the flow of traffic during the inspection. This will be a condition of
the owner's industrial wastewater discharge permit.
   Note: Garbage disposals are prohibited in food establishments.
   D.   All new food establishments are required to install a floor drain in
the outside trash containment pad for cleanup purposes and must comply as
follows:
      1.   This drain must discharge to an approved grease interceptor.
      2.   Plans must reflect proper design and grading to ensure that only the
containment pad area water is captured by this floor drain.
      3.   The design must ensure that surface drainage (i.e., storm water or
irrigation runoff) from other areas does not discharge to this floor drain.
      4.   The pad cannot exceed six hundred (600) square feet unless it is
covered.
      5.   Design of this drainage system must be reviewed and approved by the
service provider.
      6.   During abnormally high precipitation or flooding, it is the owner's
responsibility to temporarily block this drain. This will be a condition of the
owner's industrial wastewater discharge permit.
      7.   It is the applicant's responsibility to ensure grading is completed
per the approved plans. Corrections due to construction errors are the
responsibility of the applicant and must be completed as a condition of the
industrial wastewater discharge permit.
   E.   The applicant shall submit plans to the building department and the
local service provider. Prior to the issuance of a building permit, the
applicant shall comply with the conditions of this policy. (Ord. 506, 1-18-
2007)
9.07.06: SAND/OIL INTERCEPTION AND CONTAINMENT:
   A.   Policy and procedure for approval of sand/oil interceptors and
secondary containment: The statement of this policy and procedure pertains to
applicants requesting building permits regarding any business utilizing wash
pads or having the potential to discharge petroleum products or excessive
suspended solids to the public sewer system.
      1.   It is the applicant's responsibility to ensure grading is completed
per the approved plans. Corrections due to construction errors are the
responsibility of the applicant and must be completed as a condition of the
industrial wastewater discharge permit.
   B.   The applicant shall submit plans to the building department and the
local service provider. Prior to the issuance of a building permit, the
applicant shall comply with the conditions of this policy. (Ord. 506, 1-18-
2007)
9.07.07: INDUSTRIAL PRETREATMENT PROGRAM1:
An industrial wastewater discharge permit is issued to each business which
prohibits the discharge of pollutants in excess of federally approved,
technically based local limits. The service provider samples wastewater from
these businesses to determine if they are in compliance with the permit
conditions. Enforcement actions are taken when necessary in accordance with the
federally approved emergency response plan and emergency response guide.
Authority for these actions are provided in this code, through NDEP and 40 CFR.
In addition to this program, is the requirement for, and enforcement of,
secondary containment. Any business that stores a product, new or used, that
has the potential to contaminate soil or ground water must provide a secondary
containment system that will prevent any leak or spill from adversely impacting
the environment. (Ord. 506, 1-18-2007)
9.07.08: WELLHEAD PROTECTION:
All new construction shall comply with the requirements of the Lyon County
wellhead protection ordinance. Examples of certain uses not permitted within
one hundred fifty feet (150') of a public wellhead supplying potable water to
the public water supplies are as follows:
Uses permitted within one hundred fifty feet (150') of a public wellhead shall
be limited to necessary public water supply wellhead equipment including the
following: wellhead facility buildings, water storage tanks, disinfection and
treatment equipment, disinfection and treatment chemical storage and approved
landscaping. All other uses shall be prohibited including, but not limited to:
   A.   Manufacturing or industrial businesses involving the collection,
handling, manufacture, use, storage, transfer or disposal of any hazardous
solid or liquid material or waste having a potential impact on ground water
quality that would change ground water quality to below state drinking water
quality standards, and any land use activities posing a hazard or contamination
threat to existing ground water quality.
   B.   Sewer lines, septic tanks, drain fields or the disposal of waste oil,
oil filters, tires and all other petroleum products.
Exceptions may be allowed upon issuance of a special use permit. (Ord. 506, 1-
18-2007)
ARTICLE A. WELLHEAD PROTECTION PROGRAM
SECTION:
9.07A.01: Short Title And Purpose
9.07A.02: Definitions
9.07A.03: Establishment Of Wellhead Protection Overlay District
9.07A.04: Permitted And Prohibited Uses Within Zone I Of The Wellhead
Protection Area
9.07A.05: Notice Of Proposed Action To Operator Of Public Water System
9.07A.06: Proposed Land Uses Within Zone II Of The Wellhead Protection Area
9.07A.07: Nonconforming Uses
9.07A.08: Enforcement
9.07A.09: Amendments
9.07A.01: SHORT TITLE AND PURPOSE:
   A.   This article shall be known as the WELLHEAD PROTECTION ORDINANCE.
   B.   It is the purpose of this article to promote the public health, safety,
and general welfare, and to minimize public and private losses due to
contamination of the public water supply, and to formalize ground water
protection procedures. Specific goals are to:
      1.   Protect human life and health;
      2.   Ensure that the public is provided with a sustainable safe potable
water supply;
      3.   Minimize expenditure of public money for pollution remediation
projects;
      4.   Clarify regulations on land use; and
      5.   Minimize business interruptions. (Ord. 506, 1-18-2007)
9.07A.02: DEFINITIONS:
When used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings given in this section:
COMMUNITY WATER SYSTEM: A public system, which serves at least fifteen (15)
service connections used by year round residents or regularly serves at least
twenty five (25) year round residents.
COMMUNITY WELLHEAD: The upper terminal of a well, including adapters, ports,
seals, valves and other appurtenances.
CONTAMINANT: An undesirable substance not normally present, or an undesirably
high concentration of a naturally occurring substance.
FACILITY: Any business or corporation that is built, installed, or established
to serve a particular purpose.
HAZARDOUS WASTE DISPOSAL FACILITY: A hazardous waste treatment, storage, or
disposal facility, that receives hazardous material as described in part 40
chapter 260.1 of the code of federal regulations.
HAZARDOUS WASTE OR MATERIAL: Any waste or material, which because of its
quantity, concentration, physical, chemical or infectious characteristics may:
   A.   Cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an
increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness; or
   B.   Pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or to
the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of or
otherwise managed; or
   C.   Any material or substance designated as a hazardous or toxic substance
defined by title 40 part 261.3 of the code of federal regulations, or any
material or substance designated as a hazardous or toxic substance by the state
of Nevada, acting through the division of environmental protection or any
successor agency.
NONCOMMUNITY WATER SYSTEM: A public water system that is not a community water
system.
PUBLIC WATER SYSTEM: A system that provides the public with piped water for
human consumption, if such system has at least fifteen (15) service connections
or regularly serves an average of at least twenty five (25) individuals daily
at least sixty (60) days out of the year. Such term includes:
   A.   Any drinking water source procurement, pumping, treatment, storage, and
distribution facilities under control of the operator of such system, and used
primarily in connection with such system; and
   B.   Any drinking water source procurement, pumping or pretreatment storage
facilities not under such control that are used primarily in connection with
such system.
A public water system is either a "community water system" or a "noncommunity
water system".
TIME OF TRAVEL DISTRICTS (TOT): The time required for a water molecule or
contaminant to move through an aquifer from a specific point to a well or
spring.
UNDERGROUND INJECTION WELL: A well that is used for or intended to be used for
the subsurface emplacement of fluids.
   A.   A bored, drilled or driven shaft whose depth is greater than the
largest surface dimension; or
   B.   A dug hole whose depth is greater than the largest surface dimension;
or
   C.   An improved sinkhole; or
   D.   A subsurface fluid distribution system.
WELL: A penetration in the ground made for the purpose of measuring, testing or
sampling the underground strata or producing ground water. The term includes a
water well, monitoring well or exploratory well; or any excavation or
artificial opening into the ground, which provides an unnatural conduit for
fluids to migrate to the water table.
WELLHEAD PROTECTION OVERLAY DISTRICT: A land use designation on the land use
map, or a zoning designation on a zoning map, that modifies the basic
underlying designation in some specific manner. The wellhead protection overlay
district map will define specific area districts that delineate the surface and
subsurface area surrounding a drinking water well or well field. The map is
delineated using methods established in the NDEP, "Wellhead Protection Program
Guide".
WELLHEAD PROTECTION OVERLAY DISTRICT I: Per NAC 444.792 and/or Nevada Revised
Statutes 439.200, 444.650, a minimum fixed radius extending no less than one
hundred fifty feet (150') from the wellhead supplying potable water to the
public water supplies.
WELLHEAD PROTECTION OVERLAY DISTRICT II: A ten (10) year or twenty (20) year,
whichever is greater, time of travel district (TOT) as defined in this section,
and as defined in the public water system's approved or endorsed wellhead
protection program, recognized by the state of Nevada's wellhead protection
program, administered by the Nevada division of environmental protection. (Ord.
506, 1-18-2007)
9.07A.03: ESTABLISHMENT OF WELLHEAD PROTECTION OVERLAY DISTRICT:
There is hereby established a wellhead protection overlay district identified
and described as all the area within the ten (10) year or twenty (20) year TOT
district around public water supplies as shown on the official zoning map. It
is further established that these areas be composed of two (2) districts,
"wellhead protection overlay district I" and "wellhead protection overlay
district II", as they are defined in this article. The board of commissioners
may record with the county recorder's office a metes and bounds description of
the wellhead protection overlay district. (Ord. 506, 1-18-2007)
9.07A.04: PERMITTED AND PROHIBITED USES WITHIN ZONE I OF THE WELLHEAD
PROTECTION AREA:
   A.   Permitted Uses: Uses permitted within zone I shall be limited to
necessary public water supply wellhead equipment including the following:
Approved landscaping.
Disinfection and treatment chemical storage.
Disinfection and treatment equipment.
Water storage tanks.
Wellhead facility buildings.
   B.   Prohibited Uses: All other uses shall be prohibited including, but not
limited to:
Any land use activities posing a hazard or contamination threat to existing
ground water quality.
Disposal of waste oil, oil filters, tires and all other petroleum products.
Drain fields.
Manufacturing or industrial businesses involving the collection, handling,
manufacture, use, storage, transfer or disposal of any hazardous solid or
liquid material or waste having a potential impact on ground water quality that
would change ground water quality to below state drinking water quality
standards.
Septic tanks.
Sewer lines.
Exceptions may be allowed upon issuance of a special use permit. The planning
commission may instigate a special use permit process during the application
review process. (Ord. 506, 1-18-2007)
9.07A.05: NOTICE OF PROPOSED ACTION TO OPERATOR OF PUBLIC WATER SYSTEM:
Whenever there is a request that requires a special use permit from the
planning commission for land lying within a wellhead protection district,
written notice no less than thirty (30) days before the hearing shall be given
to all entities operating a public or community water supply system within that
overlay district. The planning commission may require a granting of easements
for monitoring wells if the commission deems it appropriate for protection of
the public water supply. (Ord. 506, 1-18-2007)
9.07A.06: PROPOSED LAND USES WITHIN ZONE II OF THE WELLHEAD PROTECTION AREA:
Upon requesting a permit for land use or development within the wellhead
protection overlay district II, applicants will be informed by the permitting
agency regarding the goals of the wellhead protection plan for the associated
PWS. The permitting agency must promptly send a copy of the application to the
PWS. The PWS will then be allowed thirty (30) days to respond to the proposed
development or land use as they pertain to the goals stated in their wellhead
protection program. The PWS may then request more detailed information or
submit a nonbinding advisory statement detailing any suggested restrictions,
modifications and/or justification for denial or approval of the permit. (Ord.
506, 1-18-2007)
9.07A.07: NONCONFORMING USES:
Any legal use existing at the time of the adoption of this article and listed
as a prohibited use herein, shall become a legal nonconforming use and is
required to conform to this article upon any change or transfer of ownership or
upon expansion or improvement except as otherwise provided in the zoning
ordinance. (Ord. 506, 1-18-2007)
9.07A.08: ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be unlawful for any person, corporation, government entity or business
to occupy or use the land within the area designated in the wellhead protection
overlay district of zones I, and/or II, contrary to, or in violation of, any of
the provisions of this article and/or adopted water quality legislation and
pursuant to regulations to protect ground water from potential contaminant
sources as identified in various chapters of the Nevada administrative code.
(Ord. 506, 1-18-2007)
9.07A.09: AMENDMENTS:
Proposed amendments will require advance notice to all entities operating
public or community water supplies that this article affects. (Ord. 506, 1-18-
2007)
CHAPTER 8
APPRAISER SELECTION
SECTION:
9.08.01: Purpose, Interpretation And Application
9.08.02: Appraisals Required

9.08.01: PURPOSE, INTERPRETATION AND APPLICATION:
As required by state law Nevada Revised Statutes 244.2795, the board of county
commissioners establishes these procedures for creating or amending a list of
appraisers qualified to conduct appraisals of real property owned by the county
and offered for sale or lease by the board. This list may also be used to
select an appraiser required for the County to purchase property, as set forth
in NRS 244.275(2).
This chapter does not create a legal right, including but not limited to a
property or other constitutional right, to be placed upon the established
appraiser lists or to be awarded a contract for professional services. (Ord.
619, 9-2-2021)
9.08.02: APPRAISALS REQUIRED:
Before the county may sell or lease county-owned property, the county manager
or a department head authorized by the board to negotiate to sell or lease the
property must obtain two appraisals prepared by appraisers selected from a list
established by section
9.08.04. The selection and appointment of appraisers shall be according to the
procedure established pursuant to section
9.08.06. The qualifications of the appraisers shall be determined pursuant to
9.08.05.
If the board of county commissioners holds a public hearing on the matter of
the fair market value of the real property, one independent appraisal of the
real property is sufficient before selling or leasing it.
Before the county may purchase real property, the value of the same shall be
appraised and fixed by one or more competent real estate appraisers selected by
the board from the list of appraisers established pursuant to
9.08.04. The selection and appointment of appraisers shall be according to the
procedure established pursuant to section
9.08.06. The qualifications of the appraisers shall be determined pursuant to
9.08.05.
Purchases of real property from other federal, state or local governments are
exempt from such requirement of appraisement.
The appraisal or appraisals, as applicable, must have been prepared not more
than 6 months before the date on which the real property is purchased or
offered for sale or lease.
If two or more independent appraisals are obtained, the value is determined by
the average of the appraisals of the real property. (Ord. 619, 9-2-2021)
9.08.03: EXCEPTIONS:
This ordinance applies except as otherwise provided in NRS 244.189, 244.276,
244.279, 244.2815, 244.2825, 244.2833, 244.2835, 244.284, 244.287, 244.290,
278.479 to 278.4965, inclusive, and subsection 3 of NRS 496.080, except as
otherwise required by federal law, except as otherwise required pursuant to a
cooperative agreement entered into pursuant to NRS 277.050 or 277.053 or an
interlocal agreement in existence on or before October 1, 2004, except if the
board of county commissioners is entering into a joint development agreement
for real property owned by the county to which the board of county
commissioners is a party, except for a lease of residential property with a
term of 1 year or less, except for the sale or lease of real property to a
public utility, as defined in NRS 704.020, to be used for a public purpose,
except for the sale or lease of real property to the State or another
governmental entity and except for the sale or lease of real property larger
than 1 acre which is approved by the voters at a primary or general election or
special election. (Ord. 619, 9-2-2021)
9.08.04: LIST OF QUALIFIED APPRAISERS:
A list of appraisers will be established by the board as follows:
   A.    The county manager will send notice to the current certified general
appraisers with offices in Lyon County, NV and immediately surrounding
counties, requesting a response with their qualifications if they are
interested in providing appraisals for the purchase by Lyon County, or sale or
lease of real property owned by Lyon County.
   B.   The county manager will review and compile a list of qualified
appraisers and organize it in random order.
   C.   After an appraiser has completed an appraisal, the appraiser will be
added to the bottom of the list.
   D.   The list may be amended by the county manager to remove names on
written request from the appraiser, on information received from the state of
Nevada that the appraiser is no longer active, or on the board's determination
that there is a basis for removal.
Any appraiser, having Nevada General Appraiser Certification issued by the Real
Estate Division, may request to be included in a list of qualifies appraisers.
Determination of the qualifications of such appraisers will be conducted
pursuant to section 9.08.05. (Ord. 619, 9-2-2021)
9.08.05: QUALIFICATIONS OF APPRAISERS:
The board of county commissioners hereby establishes the following criteria to
be used in determining the qualifications of appraisers. These criteria shall
include, but are not limited to, the following:
   A.   Possession of Nevada General Appraiser Certification issued by the Real
Estate Division;
   B.   Years of experience in appraising real property in Nevada;
   C.   Description of previous projects similar in size and scope to the
particular assignment;
   D.   Professional expertise, based on a resume of qualifications,
certifications and professional expertise of the person performing the work;
   E.   Appraiser's current workload to determine ability to perform the work
required for the particular project;
   F.   Competitiveness of fees;
   G.   Ability to obtain professional liability insurance as required by the
county;
   H.   Willingness to indemnify the county for errors, omissions and
negligence; Lack of any conflict of interest as specified in Section
9.08.06; and
   I.   Any other criteria deemed appropriate under the circumstances of the
particular assignment. (Ord. 619, 9-2-2021)
9.08.06: SELECTION AND APPOINTMENT OF APPRAISERS:
The two appraisers at the top of the list will be chosen by the county manager
to appraise the property the county is intending to sell or lease. The one
appraiser at the top of the list will be chosen by the county manager to
appraise the property the county is intending to purchase. The appraisers
chosen must submit a proposal with a time frame of less than three months, a
fee quote, their qualification for the particular assignment and a statement
that they do not have a conflict in appraising the property.
A conflict is created when the appraiser or a person related to the appraiser
within the third degree of consanguinity or affinity has an interest in the
property or property adjoining the property to be appraised. If an appraiser
cannot meet these requirements the appraiser is considered not qualified for
the appraisal and the county manager may pick the next appraiser on the list.
An appraiser that is found not qualified for a job retains the same position on
the list for the next job. (Ord. 619, 9-2-2021)
9.08.07: SEVERABILITY PROVISION:
If any section of this ordinance or portion thereof is for any reason held
invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such
holding shall not invalidate the remaining parts of this ordinance. (Ord. 619,
9-2-2021)
9.08.08: SUNSET PROVISION:
This ordinance is effective until the date of repeal of the state law requiring
the board of county commissioners to obtain appraisals when purchasing or
offering any real property for lease or sale and to adopt an ordinance creating
a list of appraisers. (Ord. 619, 9-2-2021)
TITLE 10
RESERVED
TITLE 11
RESERVED
TITLE 12
RESERVED
TITLE 13
RESERVED
TITLE 14
COUNTY PARKS
CHAPTER 1
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
14.01.01: Definitions
14.01.01: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this title, unless the context otherwise requires, the words and
terms defined in this chapter have the meanings ascribed to them herein:
APPLICANT: A person or entity seeking a permit.
CAMPING: No person shall set up or leave equipment designed or intended for use
for sleeping in any county park except in areas designated and posted for that
purpose.
   A.   No person under the age of eighteen (18) may camp in any county park
unless accompanied by a parent or guardian or is part of a group permitted to
occupy a county park and is supervised by at least one responsible adult per
fifteen (15) juveniles.
DIRECTOR: The county manager and/or their designee.
FAIRGROUNDS: The Lyon County Fairgrounds.
OBSCENE: Has the meaning ascribed to that word in Nevada Revised Statutes
201.235(4).
OPEN SPACE: An area designated by the board that is typically used for
floodwater control, detention or storage and may also be designed and operated
as multipurpose recreational facilities.
PERMIT: A written authorization from the director, issued pursuant to the
provisions of this title, to conduct a special event in a county park.
PERMITTEE: A person or entity which has received a permit to conduct a special
event.
RANGE MASTER: A person designated by the director to supervise the safe
operation and use of a shooting facility, or, if no such person shall be
designated, the director.
SHOOTING FACILITY: An area designed and used for archery or sport shooting,
including, but not limited to, sport shooting that involves the use of rifles,
shotguns, pistols, silhouettes, skeet, trap, black powder or other similar
items.
SPECIAL EVENT: A group activity which is not normally conducted in the county
park system.
VANDALISM: Any wilful or intentional disruption, damage, removal, defacement,
or injury to any property in any county park. "Vandalism" does not include
maintenance of the county park system by employees or those contracted by the
county to perform such maintenance. (Ord. 498, 2-16-2006, eff. 3-13-2006; amd.
Ord. 587, 6-2-2016, eff. 6-22-2016)
CHAPTER 2
FIRES IN PARKS
SECTION:
14.02.01: Generally
14.02.02: Fire Danger
14.02.03: Fireworks
14.02.01: GENERALLY:
   A.   Only a person eighteen (18) years of age or older may light or maintain
a fire in a county park. Fires may only be lit and maintained in designated
areas, and only if means to extinguish the fire are readily available.
   B.   No person may leave a county park before extinguishing any fire which
he has built, lighted, or maintained in such a park, unless said fire is being
maintained by a person eighteen (18) years of age or older.
   C.   No person may leave a fire unattended within any county park. (Ord.
498, 2-16-2006, eff. 3-13-2006)
14.02.02: FIRE DANGER:
Upon existence of extreme fire danger, the director or his designee may
prohibit smoking or fires in designated areas within any county park, or may
close such areas to the public. (Ord. 498, 2-16-2006, eff. 3-13-2006)
14.02.03: FIREWORKS:
No person may possess, discharge, set off or cause to be discharged in or into
any portion of a county park any firecrackers, torpedoes, rockets, fireworks,
explosives, or other substance harmful to the life or safety of any person,
without written permission from the director. (Ord. 498, 2-16-2006, eff. 3-13-
2006)
CHAPTER 3
ANIMALS IN PARKS
SECTION:
14.03.01: Dogs
14.03.02: Other Animals
14.03.03: Exceptions
14.03.01: DOGS:
No person who owns, harbors, keeps, or who has possession, charge, care,
custody or control of any dog shall cause, permit, suffer, or allow such dog to
enter or remain in any park or portion thereof, unless the park or area has
been posted for such purpose.
In areas where dogs are allowed, all dogs must be licensed and have all tags
and vaccinations and meet any other requirements found in title 7, chapter 1,
"Animals And Animal Services", of this code. (Ord. 587, 6-2-2016, eff. 6-22-
2016)
14.03.02: OTHER ANIMALS:
Unless designated and posted for such purposes, no person shall ride, lead, or
keep any animal within a county park. (Ord. 498, 2-16-2006, eff. 3-13-2006)
14.03.03: EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   "Service animals", as the term is defined in Nevada Revised Statutes
426.097, and "service animals in training", as the term is defined in Nevada
Revised Statutes 426.099, are permitted in county parks.
   B.   The director may give written permission to a person or group to have
